headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Fourth Quarter 2014 General Dynamics Earnings Conference Call. My name is Sean Pillai, and I will be your facilitator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being reco
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Fourth Quarter 2014 General Dynamics Earnings Conference Call. My name is Sean Pillai, and I will be your facilitator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded for replay purposes. I would now like to turn the conference over to your host for today, Ms. Erin Linnihan. Please proceed.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sean Pillai, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to the General Dynamics' Fourth Quarter Conference Call.As always, any forward-looking statements made today represent our estimates regarding the company's outlook. These estimates are subject
componenttext:
Thank you, Sean Pillai, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to the General Dynamics' Fourth Quarter Conference Call.
As always, any forward-looking statements made today represent our estimates regarding the company's outlook. These estimates are subject to some risks and uncertainties.  Additional information regarding these factors is contained in the company's 10-K and 10-Q filings.
With that, I would like to turn the call over to our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Phebe Novakovic.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Erin. Earlier today, we reported fourth quarter earnings from continuing operations of $2.19 per fully diluted share on revenue of $8.36 billion and earnings from continuing operations of $737 million. It was our strongest revenue performance in t
componenttext:
Thanks, Erin. Earlier today, we reported fourth quarter earnings from continuing operations of $2.19 per fully diluted share on revenue of $8.36 billion and earnings from continuing operations of $737 million. It was our strongest revenue performance in the past 12 quarters, the highest operating earnings ever and the highest earnings from continuing operations. For us, it was a powerful quarter. Incidentally, we beat analyst consensus by $0.06. 
For the year, we had fully diluted earnings per share of $7.83 on revenue of $30.85 billion and earnings from continuing operations of $2.7 billion, a return on sales of 8.7%. It was a year of solid achievement from both an operating perspective and development of significant backlog.
As you can see from schedule H to the press release, funded backlog grew from $38.3 billion at year-end 2013 to $52.9 billion at the end of last year. The story for total backlog is much the same. We were at $45.9 billion at the end of 2013 and sit at $72.4 billion at the end of 2014. As a result, we are well positioned for growth in 2016 and 2017.
Free cash flow from operations was a negative $254 million in the quarter, however, for the year, we had free cash flow from operations of $3.2 billion or [ph] 120% of earnings from continuing operations. This outpaced 2013 by $532 million.
Let me give you some detail on the quarter and the year in each of the business groups. First, Aerospace. Revenue and earnings were up nicely over the year-ago quarter. Sales were up $105 million, 4.9% and earnings were up $64 million, a significant 18.4% on very strong margin improvement. This is particularly impressive among considers that G&A and net R&D were up $40 million over the year-ago quarter. On a sequential basis, sales were up $49 million but earnings were up $1 million on a 40 basis point improvement in operating margins. 
I should add that Jet remained nicely profitable in the quarter with a better contribution on both the year-ago and sequential comparison basis.
The order activity in the quarter was robust as one would expect with the announcement of 2 new aircraft. As you can observe on exhibit H, funded backlog, total backlog and total potential contract value including options are all up significantly.
Even if we were to ignore the orders related to the 2 new aircraft, total orders from current production aircraft were the highest of the year. All large cabin aircraft had a dollar base book-to-bill greater than 1 to 1.
For the year, revenues were $8.65 billion and operating earnings were $1.61 billion on an operating margin of 18.6%. This is a year-over-year improvement of 6.5% on sales, 13.8% on earnings and 120 basis points on operating margin. All in all, a very good year at Aerospace with strong operating leverage.
At Combat Systems, sales were up $23 million or 1.4% and earnings were up $21 million or 8.4% on 110 basis point improvement in operating margin over the year-ago quarter. Sequentially, the story is similar. Sales were up $219 million and earnings were up $39 million. 
For the year, sales were down $100 million or 1.7% and earnings were down $46 million or 5.1%. This compares quite favorably to the guidance we've provided at this time last year. You may recall that we guided to a 4 [ph] to 4.5 revenue decline as opposed to the 1.7% decline that occurred. We also guided to operating margins of 14%, which we beat by 100 basis points.
Overall, Combat Systems is a story of solid additions to backlog, better-than-anticipated revenue and outstanding costs and margin performance. This is a business group that has clearly stabilized.
Marine group revenue in the quarter exceeded $2 billion for the first time ever. Operating earnings of $193 million were the second highest ever recorded. Revenue was up $410 million or 25.2% compared to the year-ago quarter and up $220 million or 12.1%, sequentially. Revenues for the year were up $600 million, almost 9%, very nice growth. 
Operating earnings were up $34 million or 21.4% against the year-ago quarter and up $23 million or 13.5% sequentially. For the full year, earnings were up $37 million or 5.6% on a 30 basis point decline on operating margin, attributable to mix shift, which was consistent with our guidance to you.
In the Marine group, we guided you at this time last year to a revenue increase of 2.5%, which we obviously exceeded. We forecasted margins at 9.5% and round up at 9.6%. All in all, a very good year for the Marine group.
IS&T is a business group where we saw less-than-expected revenue decline and improved operating performance. Revenue in the quarter was $2.47 billion, down $223 million or 8.3% against the year-ago quarter. Revenue was up 9.8% sequentially and down $1.1 billion or 10.8% for the year. Remember that this is dramatically less than the 20% revenue decline we forecasted in our guidance to you at this time last year.
Operating earnings of $212 million in the quarter were 8.2% better than the fourth quarter a year ago. On a sequential basis, operating earnings were up $10 million or 5%. For the year, earnings were down only $10 million or 1.3%, which is very good performance in the face of a 10.8% revenue decline. 
On this call a year ago, I gave your guidance with respect to operating margins in the 8.2% range, which we beat by 40 basis points. All in all, we beat forecasted revenue by $1 billion and operating margins by 40 basis points. When that happens, the result is very pleasant upside surprise.
So companywide, on this call a year ago, our guidance for 2014 was to expect revenues of $30 billion, operating margin rate of 12%, a tax rate of 31% and a return on sales of 8%. We round up the year with revenues of $30.85 billion and operating margin rate of 12.6%, an effective tax rate of 29.7% and a return on sales of 8.7%.
We provided EPS guidance of $6.80 to $6.85. We round up at $7.83. About $0.62 of the improvement came from better-than-planned operating performance, $0.13 from slightly lower-than-planned tax rate and the balance from share count as a result of share repurchases.
So let me provide you some thoughts about 2015, initially by business group and then on a companywide rollup. In Aerospace, we expect revenues to be approximately $9.4 billion, up about 8.3%. Margin rate should be approximately 18%, somewhat down from 2014 attributable in part to less favorability at Jet, nonetheless, up about 4.5% in earnings.
In Combat Systems, we expect both revenue and earnings to be essentially flat with growth resuming in 2016 and beyond. The Marine group is expected to have revenue growth of 2% to 2.5% and a margin rate in the 9.5% range, resulting in a very modest improvement to operating earnings.
Finally, in IS&T, we expect a revenue decline of about 5.5% but improved margin rate of slightly more than 9%. This will result in improved operating earnings year-over-year. We expect the last year to be our low watermark for revenue. In part, we are seeing some of the decline we anticipated last year being delayed into this year. Once again, we should see revenue growth in 2016 and 2017.
All of this rolls up to an operating plan of about $31.3 billion to $31.5 billion of revenue, EBIT rate around 12.8% and a return on sales of roughly 8.7%. This plan is purely from operations, assumes a 30.5% tax rate, assumes we buy enough shares to hold the share count steady with a year-end figures so as not to permit dilution from option exercise. This rolls up to an EPS guidance of $8.05 to $8.10 per fully diluted share. This compares with last year's guidance of $6.80 to $6.85 at the same time on the same basis. So much like last year, beating our guidance must come from outperforming the operating plan and the effect of share repurchases.
So how should one think about the quarterly progression of EPS? Whatever your model is for the year divided by 4 and the first and second quarters will be light by about $0.10, the third quarter about right on and the fourth quarter about $0.20 better. By the way, quarterly progression is notoriously difficult.
With respect to capital deployment, we're anticipating using all of our free cash flow in 2015 for dividends and share repurchases. While we don't anticipate a robust year from a free cash flow perspective in light of the advanced payments on international orders that we have received last year, we intend to treat the free cash available for dividends and share repurchases on a -- on some normalized basis. In short, we will use balance sheet cash as necessary to normalize the year.
I would now like to call turn the call over to our Chief Financial Officer, Jason Aiken.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Phebe, and good morning. I'll take just a minute and cover a few miscellaneous financial items before the question-and-answer period.Net interest expense in the quarter was $19 million versus $23 million in the fourth quarter of 2013. And for
componenttext:
Thank you, Phebe, and good morning. I'll take just a minute and cover a few miscellaneous financial items before the question-and-answer period.
Net interest expense in the quarter was $19 million versus $23 million in the fourth quarter of 2013. And for the year, interest expense was $86 million, consistent with the year before. For 2015, we expect net interest expense of around $82 million, a decline from 2014 resulting from the repayment of $500 million of fixed rate notes that matured last week.
At the end of the year, our balance sheet reflects a net cash position, that's cash in excess of debt, of $477 million. This was down by about $1 billion from the end of 2013 reflecting the cash we used from the balance sheet for capital deployment activities, which I'll address in just a minute.
Our effective tax rate was 29.5% for the quarter and 29.7% for the year, and that's a bit lower than we have been forecasting. As you'll recall, our most recent productions were in the neighborhood of 30% to 30.5%. The lower outcome is attributable to the R&D tax credit extension in late December.
For 2015, as Phebe mentioned, we expect an effective tax rate of around 30.5%.
And finally on the income statement, you'll notice we took a charge in the quarter in discontinued operations. This is related to the sale of our AxleTech business, which we first reported in the second quarter when we made the decision to sell that business. The charge we took at that time is predicated on a 2014 closing of the sale. The regulatory review process for the transaction delayed the closing until the 5th of January. And as a result, we were not able to take advantage of some tax benefits we had anticipated so we adjusted the loss on the sale in the fourth quarter.
Switching gears, we contributed $515 million to our pension plans in 2014. And for 2015, we expect that amount to decline to approximately $185 million as a result of the interest rate released from the highway and transportation funding act of 2014.
On the capital deployment front, to summarize our activities for the year, we delivered on our commitment to return capital to our shareholders while maintaining a strong balance sheet. In total, we expended [ph] approximately $3.4 billion on share repurchases in 2014. And when you combine our share repurchases with our dividend payments, we spent $4.2 billion in shareholder friendly actions in 2014 or 1.3x our free cash flow from operations for the year.
Erin, that concludes my remarks and I'll turn the time back over to you for the Q&A.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015

componenttext: Thanks, Jason [Operator Instructions]

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Phebe, could you give us a little bit more detail on the free cash flow outlook? It sounds like it's going to be large. Can you maybe peg at this as a percent of net income in 2015? And what exactly -- how much of that is an advanced drawdown in terms of
componenttext: Phebe, could you give us a little bit more detail on the free cash flow outlook? It sounds like it's going to be large. Can you maybe peg at this as a percent of net income in 2015? And what exactly -- how much of that is an advanced drawdown in terms of the pressure on free cash flow?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we tend not to give you specifics on the percent of net income on free cash flow but suffice it to say, it's going to be less robust as a result of our drawdown and our deposits. But we will intend to normalize our free cash flow using our cash on the
componenttext: So we tend not to give you specifics on the percent of net income on free cash flow but suffice it to say, it's going to be less robust as a result of our drawdown and our deposits. But we will intend to normalize our free cash flow using our cash on the balance sheet to effect any capital deployment. I think that's about as much color as we usually give you and as much as we're prepared to give you.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ron Epstein of Bank of America near Lynch.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ron Epstein of Bank of America near Lynch.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a quick question for you on Gulfstream. How do you expect the -- I guess, the sales profile for the business to go when you are leading into the ramp-up of the new models, right? Maybe a better way to see it, the transition between the old models and
componenttext: Just a quick question for you on Gulfstream. How do you expect the -- I guess, the sales profile for the business to go when you are leading into the ramp-up of the new models, right? Maybe a better way to see it, the transition between the old models and the new models, would you expect the profile of the business to continue to grow?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. We do expect the profile to continue to grow in the near years but at less of a rate than it will grow when we introduced an entry into service of the new airplanes. So we have growth between now and entry into service of the G500 and we expect accel
componenttext: Yes. We do expect the profile to continue to grow in the near years but at less of a rate than it will grow when we introduced an entry into service of the new airplanes. So we have growth between now and entry into service of the G500 and we expect accelerated growth going forward from there.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Robert Spingarn of Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Robert Spingarn of Credit Suisse.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to talk a little bit about Marine and the strength you talked about there, your very strong fourth quarter and how things do trend as we go through '15, especially on some of the development work you're doing on upcoming programs.
componenttext: I wanted to talk a little bit about Marine and the strength you talked about there, your very strong fourth quarter and how things do trend as we go through '15, especially on some of the development work you're doing on upcoming programs.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. 2014 growth was driven by higher-than-expected volume on Block IV [indiscernible] of both, more on planned repair work and additional commercial volume. And we anticipate that those growth elements to continue into next year albeit at a less  -- les
componenttext: Okay. 2014 growth was driven by higher-than-expected volume on Block IV [indiscernible] of both, more on planned repair work and additional commercial volume. And we anticipate that those growth elements to continue into next year albeit at a less  -- less of a rate of increase. Our developmental over, primarily on the higher replacement ballistic missile submarine continues a pace for the sole source on that contract and were year-over-year increasing work on that contract and it's going very well. So we like where we're positioned there.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And would you say the fourth quarter itself, you said I think the strongest revenue -- quarterly revenues you've seen. How do we think about just the timing there?
componenttext: And would you say the fourth quarter itself, you said I think the strongest revenue -- quarterly revenues you've seen. How do we think about just the timing there?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we have continued to see growth this year at about 2% to 2.5%, which is I think very good in this environment. And that growth will continue in to the out years as we get more volume on Block IV. Additionally, we'll continue to do additional work on
componenttext: Well, we have continued to see growth this year at about 2% to 2.5%, which is I think very good in this environment. And that growth will continue in to the out years as we get more volume on Block IV. Additionally, we'll continue to do additional work on our commercial volume. Repair work fluctuates but have year-over-year been growing and we began work on the fourth MLP. So we've got growth engines for Marine group. We did obviously last year, we do into this year and we do in the future. We've been telling a growth story for the last 2 years at Marine group and you saw it manifest itself in 2014. It's going to continue to 2015 and into the foreseeable future.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Cai Von Rumohr off Cowen & Company.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Cai Von Rumohr off Cowen & Company.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I guess I'm a little confused at Gulfstream. If your sales go up to 9 4, a nice sales gains and we're getting improving profitability on the G650. Why the margins down? I mean Jet isn't that big a part of the business. And what's -- maybe give us a lit
componenttext: So I guess I'm a little confused at Gulfstream. If your sales go up to 9 4, a nice sales gains and we're getting improving profitability on the G650. Why the margins down? I mean Jet isn't that big a part of the business. And what's -- maybe give us a little color on the delivering mix, if you could.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So we have a slightly -- so there's a couple of things that are compressing margins slightly in 2015. We have a slightly unfavorable mix shift in green production between large cabin and mid-cabin. We're keeping large cabin production about the same
componenttext: Sure. So we have a slightly -- so there's a couple of things that are compressing margins slightly in 2015. We have a slightly unfavorable mix shift in green production between large cabin and mid-cabin. We're keeping large cabin production about the same rate as we did last year at about 115 units. We're increasing mid-cabin by 10 units. So there's a somewhat unfavorable mix shift between large and midsized green. We've got less of a contribution at Jet primarily and exclusively driven by mixed shift. We've got higher R&D in this upcoming year. Remember that we're building multiple test aircraft that carry with them no revenue and earnings. And then the final issue that's impacting margin somewhat in 2015 is we have a higher preowned. So those are the 4 components that are driving the margin variability.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: But the R&D, I mean is that up as a percent of sales? Because if the G650 is still improving in profitability? Or is the profitability declining on the G450 and G550?
componenttext: But the R&D, I mean is that up as a percent of sales? Because if the G650 is still improving in profitability? Or is the profitability declining on the G450 and G550?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. So that's kind of 2-part question. Net R&D is up slightly. The G650 profitability continues to increase and the G450 and G550 profitability staying exactly where it has been. We have a greater mixed shift this year, mix of mid-cabin, which carries wit
componenttext: No. So that's kind of 2-part question. Net R&D is up slightly. The G650 profitability continues to increase and the G450 and G550 profitability staying exactly where it has been. We have a greater mixed shift this year, mix of mid-cabin, which carries with it lower earnings -- lower margins. Okay? I think you need to think about it that way. We talked before about the variability of margins at Gulfstream and this is an example of it. There's nothing unexpected from our point of view. There's nothing systemic. This is simply the ebb and flow of production, R&D and preowned.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Myles Walton of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Myles Walton of Deutsche Bank.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: You mentioned that the -- that all the large cabin programs have book-to-bill above 1. And so the question is really twofold. One is where the demands you're seeing the biggest pockets of strength and whether you're seeing any dilution of strength in the
componenttext: You mentioned that the -- that all the large cabin programs have book-to-bill above 1. And so the question is really twofold. One is where the demands you're seeing the biggest pockets of strength and whether you're seeing any dilution of strength in the oil-rich countries or Russia, in particular. And the in the other piece of it is, is 2015 the year where you're delivering more G650s than the G450 and G550s in the mix?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So let me talk a little bit about demand and give you a little bit of color there. The demand for our in-product, area in production airplanes was quite handsome for the last quarter. The G650 then the G280 increased. And interestingly but not surprisingl
componenttext: So let me talk a little bit about demand and give you a little bit of color there. The demand for our in-product, area in production airplanes was quite handsome for the last quarter. The G650 then the G280 increased. And interestingly but not surprisingly, when we got inside the demand curve for the G650 inside the 3-year delivery window, Q4 orders were particularly strong. G280 was again strong. The G450 and G550 demand has slowed slightly. It's okay, not superheated but good enough. And we continue to see strong demand, primarily in North America and somewhat in Asia and also in the Mid East. Heretofore, we have seen no impact on oil prices on our backlog or frankly in our demand. If you're asking what percentage of our backlog may have some exposure to energy-related or happen to have some energy-related exposures, it's about 5% but we haven't seen any impact yet. Now with that, we're seeing historically low operating costs, which is a -- usually drives increased flight hours and that's a potential upside for our service business. So we tend not to give you deliveries any -- with any more specificity than we already have with respect to models. We break it up by large cabin and mid-cabin and I don't intend to change that in a moment.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Doug Harned of San Ford Bernstein.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Doug Harned of San Ford Bernstein.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to just follow up on that. On the G450 -- excuse me, on the G550, when you look forward here, where are you today in terms of months of backlog? Something you've given us in the past. And how are you thinking about pricing as you approach the G50
componenttext: I wanted to just follow up on that. On the G450 -- excuse me, on the G550, when you look forward here, where are you today in terms of months of backlog? Something you've given us in the past. And how are you thinking about pricing as you approach the G500 and G600 coming into operation?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think you know that we don't talk about pricing. That's competitively sensitive. But let me give you a sense of where we are and first available. In general, for new customers, for the G650 and G650ER, first available is fourth quarter 2017. Tha
componenttext: Yes. So I think you know that we don't talk about pricing. That's competitively sensitive. But let me give you a sense of where we are and first available. In general, for new customers, for the G650 and G650ER, first available is fourth quarter 2017. That moved to the right, a quarter from third quarter of last year as a result of our good order activity. The G550 is about 12 months out. The G450, late this year. So that moved a couple of months, just a few months into the last [ph]. The G280 is also available, first available late this year, and not that anybody asked but the G150 is first quarter 2016. So it's important to recall, the deals are often in the works that move customers around in the backlog for earlier slots but the above is about approximate window for new buyers. So I hope that helps you.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And you can't you comment on the trajectory on pricing with the model change, I guess, is that...
componenttext: And you can't you comment on the trajectory on pricing with the model change, I guess, is that...

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Look, we have continued to hold price on products and you could expect that over time, there is some price variability but we're not about to get to any specifics. That's just not good competitive place to be in a highly competitive market.
componenttext: Look, we have continued to hold price on products and you could expect that over time, there is some price variability but we're not about to get to any specifics. That's just not good competitive place to be in a highly competitive market.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Robert Stallard of Royal Bank of Canada.

componenttext: Phebe, on IS&T, you've guided down 5.5% for this year. Can you give us an idea of how much of that is already in the backlog and the sort of level of conservatism you might have based into that given the fluctuating situation with the DoD budget?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Given the what situation?
componenttext: Given the what situation?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Fluctuating.
componenttext: Fluctuating.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Oh, fluctuating. So we had about 3/4 of our guidance for IS&T. In our backlog, that's exactly where we've been historically including recently. We've got good -- we've got a high level of RFP, request for proposal activity, and are bidding on a number of
componenttext: Oh, fluctuating. So we had about 3/4 of our guidance for IS&T. In our backlog, that's exactly where we've been historically including recently. We've got good -- we've got a high level of RFP, request for proposal activity, and are bidding on a number of contracts. So we are -- we're pretty comfortable that we can hit our revenue guidance. And I've -- from our point of view, we have seen less fluctuation in the DoD budget with respect to our IS&T units recently than we had a couple of years ago. So we think that, that's somewhat stabilized. And as I told you, we anticipated 2014 to be our low watermark, some [indiscernible] it was better than we thought it was going to be. And I think some of that decrease bled [ph] into 2015.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Sam Pearlstein of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Sam Pearlstein of Wells Fargo.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can you talk, I guess, to -- I'm going to try and put 2 things in there. But first on Marine, I'm somewhat surprised that you're not seeing any more margin pressure given what I would think would be more Block IV work and more Ohio replacement work in the
componenttext: Can you talk, I guess, to -- I'm going to try and put 2 things in there. But first on Marine, I'm somewhat surprised that you're not seeing any more margin pressure given what I would think would be more Block IV work and more Ohio replacement work in the year just in terms of the mix. So I guess what are you doing to offset that? And then just related to Combat, you talked about growth resuming in 2016. Is this a business that we should now expect to see kind of growth in this still 15% kind of margin runway kind of far in to the future?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. Let me address your questions in the order that they were asked. We talked've frequently about margin variability at the Marine group. It's really a mixed shift. And you quite accurately point out that we are experiencing a mixed shift really frank
componenttext: Right. Let me address your questions in the order that they were asked. We talked've frequently about margin variability at the Marine group. It's really a mixed shift. And you quite accurately point out that we are experiencing a mixed shift really frankly across our portfolio. More Block IV, less Block III, more commercial work coming off of the MLP program and first-of-class ships on the DDG-1000 and DDG-51 restart. That said, these businesses have continued to perform very, very well on cost cutting efficiency and their performance has been quite good and I frankly expect to see margin expansion, primarily driven by Block IV as we have increased margin potential and earnings potential from our profitability and efficiency as we move down our learning curve. So Marine group continues to function very, very well and I like their growth story. Combat Systems growth, we had that significant backlog and now, for us, it's all a question of performing on that backlog. And I think this group has demonstrated its operational excellence and will continue to do so. So I expect in -- I've given you my guidance for 2015 but as I project out into the future and think about the business, this is going to be -- we're going to see some growth in Combat and I would expect fully anticipate given the operational excellence of this group to see margin expansion. But I'm not going to bake any of that in now on some of these programs. We're still in fairly new starts and low rate production. But everything we see, this is a group that will continue to cut costs and improve its efficiency.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Hunter Keay of Wolfe Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Hunter Keay of Wolfe Research.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Phebe, can you talk a little bit about the variables that drive the decision to take up rate? As we look here across the global landscape, questions about the global economic growth possibly decelerating, particularly in the emerging markets. You have a v
componenttext: Phebe, can you talk a little bit about the variables that drive the decision to take up rate? As we look here across the global landscape, questions about the global economic growth possibly decelerating, particularly in the emerging markets. You have a very strong U.S. dollar right now that might be having an impact in some of your operating expenses. And so as that filters in to sort of potential cannibalization within the product lines, [indiscernible] your G650 question than anything else. But can you talk about, maybe at a higher level if you prefer, what factors you guys look at the understanding about how to think about when thinking about production rates?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we have historically and as we talked about before, we've historically set our production rate and we've continued that practice based on what we see in demand and to optimize around our economic efficiency, our supplier base. And we've been very judic
componenttext: So we have historically and as we talked about before, we've historically set our production rate and we've continued that practice based on what we see in demand and to optimize around our economic efficiency, our supplier base. And we've been very judicious year-over-year in setting our production rates and our delivery. So as I mentioned, we continue to see  very strong demand, particularly for the G650. Our pipeline on the G650 is very good, the G280 also. So we really haven't seen much impact in emerging markets, certainly not this year. North America remains very strong with us, Asia Pacific and then -- and we're also seeing some increased demand in the Middle East. I would also tell you that about 60% of our backlog is with public and private companies including Fortune 500, so they tend to be very stable and reliable and predictable. And as I said, our pipeline continues to show interest on their part. So I hope that, that kind of addressed it. If you look at a complex number of factors that are demanded, what our goals are for operating efficiency, our supply chain, we manage prudently.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Peter Arment of Sterne Agee.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Peter Arment of Sterne Agee.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: A question on just the international demand. I know you gave us some good color on Gulfstream's impact tied to the energy end market. You've won a lot of orders in terms of Combat this past year. How are we thinking about the international demand versus s
componenttext: A question on just the international demand. I know you gave us some good color on Gulfstream's impact tied to the energy end market. You've won a lot of orders in terms of Combat this past year. How are we thinking about the international demand versus some of the defense business that you have? And any risk tied to see some of the lower-priced oil on that?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: The lower-priced oil. I've been a big believer and I think history has demonstrated that demand for defense products is driven by threat and perceived threat and you just have to open up the paper to see that the world is an increasingly unsafe place. So
componenttext: The lower-priced oil. I've been a big believer and I think history has demonstrated that demand for defense products is driven by threat and perceived threat and you just have to open up the paper to see that the world is an increasingly unsafe place. So we see it in increased level of interest in parts of Europe and the Middle East that as you might anticipate, governments begin to rethink their spending priorities in light of some of the threats that they see, both actualized and potential. So we have a pretty robust pipeline that's continuing. And our IS&T unit and Combat, now I will tell you that the Marine group has almost no one ever has much international exposure. Just the nature of our Navy shipbuilding program.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of George Shapiro of Shapiro Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of George Shapiro of Shapiro Research.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to pursue the margin at Gulfstream a little bit more. This quarter, effectively, you had 60% incrementals and if I add back the $40 million higher R&D in G&A, you would have 100% conversion. So can you tell me what was so strong this quarter that
componenttext: I wanted to pursue the margin at Gulfstream a little bit more. This quarter, effectively, you had 60% incrementals and if I add back the $40 million higher R&D in G&A, you would have 100% conversion. So can you tell me what was so strong this quarter that all of next year is probably going to decline if your numbers are right to 15% kind of incremental margins. And also, you had no preowned this quarter, you had 3 for the year versus 11 in '13. So why does '15 [ph] preowned go up?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, that's a compound question, George. So let me see if I can at least address what I think the essence is. The same -- having less preowned this year clearly was an upper to our margins. Preowned tends to carry no revenue. And we forecast preowned and
componenttext: Well, that's a compound question, George. So let me see if I can at least address what I think the essence is. The same -- having less preowned this year clearly was an upper to our margins. Preowned tends to carry no revenue. And we forecast preowned and demand based on what we see in our backlogs. And sometimes that comes to fruition and sometimes not. So this has been a pretty sustained pattern over time with respect to preowned. It tends to be lumpy and we won't know until the quarter of execution whether, in fact, anticipated preowneds come into our market or they are sold before they get to Gulfstream. So that makes preowned a little bit tougher to articulate. We had -- the performance at Gulfstream this year was extremely strong and we had a favorable completion mix in the fourth quarter that we are reversing somewhat going into next year. So we talked multiple times about the policy of being able to predict with great specificity the Gulfstream or Aerospace margins. And I will tell you, Jet had a very strong year this year and that contribution will be less next year primarily driven by a mixed shift as they move in to some additional completion work and that come down their learning curve. So all of these factors are -- plan in the Gulfstream can Aerospace margins.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Could you point to some -- you've mixed things in the fourth quarter that caused such an extraordinarily high conversion that won't repeat.
componenttext: Could you point to some -- you've mixed things in the fourth quarter that caused such an extraordinarily high conversion that won't repeat.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, again, gosh, George, I tried gutless contribution from Jet and we had a favorable delivery mix, large cabin to mid-cabin. And that's a pretty -- those are pretty big movers. And less preowned and that's a big one. Preowned tends to carry ve
componenttext: Well, I think, again, gosh, George, I tried gutless contribution from Jet and we had a favorable delivery mix, large cabin to mid-cabin. And that's a pretty -- those are pretty big movers. And less preowned and that's a big one. Preowned tends to carry very little or low [indiscernible] negative margin. So that's, in my mind, explains it. That realities of completion. Okay, George?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Howard Rubel of Jefferies.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Howard Rubel of Jefferies.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Rather than be too granular here, I wanted to take a step back. As you look at your outlook and what you've asked your senior executives to do, where -- as you look at the various risks might you see either challenges or opportunities? And I'll use 2 exam
componenttext: Rather than be too granular here, I wanted to take a step back. As you look at your outlook and what you've asked your senior executives to do, where -- as you look at the various risks might you see either challenges or opportunities? And I'll use 2 examples and then hopefully you can add to that. One is some of your operations have European- or Canadian-based costs and you sell in dollars or there maybe some upside there, although I know you had some. And then also you embarked on a very aggressive research and development campaign at Gulfstream and how have you assessed the risks and where have you felt like you've made progress? So it's a bit of specifics and then wrapped in a little bit of the 8 05 to 8 10 is a nice start for the year but I'm sure we won't end there.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So, look, just to reiterate, we've given you guidance based on the same assumptions that we used last year and our ability to do better is simply going to be as a result of cap -- share repurchases and outperforming our plan. If you look at our outlook, i
componenttext:
So, look, just to reiterate, we've given you guidance based on the same assumptions that we used last year and our ability to do better is simply going to be as a result of cap -- share repurchases and outperforming our plan. If you look at our outlook, it's informed by the last 2 years where we focused on operations, reduced our costs and results built our backlog. So we are poised for growth as a result of that backlog. For several years to come, it's a very nice positioned to be. We are going to see some good growth in '16 and '17, and the business is poised for that. We've been focusing on operations in what we basically called the back to basics, which is blocking and tackling. That work is never done, so we're going to continue to attack our costs to a relentless focus on our cost performance and reengineering our business that will make us more competitive, reduces our costs, makes more competitive and that, too, will help growth. So we have positioned ourselves nicely and I think will continue to do so going forward. Our opportunities are, because of our improved competitiveness, increased growth primarily both overseas and we've talked about that before. We've got another opportunity as margin expansion going forward as we focus on our continuous improvement. We've got -- when I think about risks, you implicitly asked about a foreign currency risk. We are less exposed to foreign currency variability and -- than companies in other sectors, for example. And the [ph] 60% of our business is with U.S. government and Gulfstream's exposures to the U.S. economy. We have -- there's some translation difficulty year-over-year with respect to currency fluctuation. We've embedded those in our plan. We also have some nice natural hedges, both in Europe and in Canada. So has the strong dollar affected any of our demand? Not really. And we certainly haven't seen it in our backlog. We had a translation -- we had to adjust our Combat backlog as a result of that negative translation but that's on work that's many years out. But in terms of sales, we're not just seeing any particular impact. It's a potential? Sure, but it's not affecting us. You asked about R&D as a risk. So the key when you introduce, I think, you invest in the business and new product development and you introduced new product is that you have managed that R&D and the engineering development and design effectively. And Gulfstream has a proven history of doing that and we are continuing to see that same kind of excellent execution and our design and engineering efforts at Gulfstream. So we don't see any risk that's outside what we have fully seen in the past with respect to R&D but we managed this -- we managed our R&D at Gulfstream and the design and engine
[Audio Gap]
[indiscernible] and back in a moment.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Joe Nadol of JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Joe Nadol of JPMorgan.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I have a couple, but very easy. One's more just sort of a clarification. On the Combat side, you're saying flat. You have this being orders obviously in your backlog that were from international customers last year. Can you give us some help with how m
componenttext: So I have a couple, but very easy. One's more just sort of a clarification. On the Combat side, you're saying flat. You have this being orders obviously in your backlog that were from international customers last year. Can you give us some help with how much you expect international, if it's the case, to be up? And then U.S. down in 2015? And the second one is just more broadly speaking looking at the whole company. Can you speak a little bit, wherever you feel comfortable, about the bookings that you're expecting across the company this year? Particularly interested is if you -- is there any of these larger Combat opportunities that are still out there that might hit kind of $1 billion-plus opportunities? And then also particularly interested in the 500 and 600 and what the tempo you expect on bookings there might be?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Complex questions. But let me address that in the order in which you ask them. We are seeing stabilization at -- in our U.S. land force's exposure at Combat Systems directly in line with our expectations. And so we don't really see any, at least, su
componenttext: Okay. Complex questions. But let me address that in the order in which you ask them. We are seeing stabilization at -- in our U.S. land force's exposure at Combat Systems directly in line with our expectations. And so we don't really see any, at least, surprises that we can see in the near term. International orders or international sales this year comprise about all [ph] in excess of 55% of Combat sales and will increase to 60 over time, not at the expense of domestic activity but just as a revenue expansion. So we do -- we still have a lot of, I'd say, a number of international orders in our pipeline that are of decent size that is our -- it is our expectation that given our competitiveness and our cost structure, we're going to be highly competitive in those competitions. So we have additional upside in building our backlog at Combat. But I'm not prepared to give you any specifics on whether that makes it a book-to-bill of 1 to 1 in any 1 given year. That will depend on a lot of things on when these competitions are decided. But we've got a lot of proposal activity out there. And with respect to 550 or 500 and 600 tempo, both of those R&D programs are proceeding at pace, no major changes since the last time we talked to you about it. Our pipeline is very robust and I expect sales to increase as we orders do increase as we get closer and closer to the entry into service as a 500 and then the 600. So there is no -- there will be no stumbling Blocks heretofore and our profiles and R&D and production of the test airplanes remain right on plan. So we're very pleased with that and we are pleased with the interest that both of these models have generated.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015

componenttext: Similar to Joe, one clarification question and then one -- one on the growth for Combat Systems out into '16 and '17. Can you offer up a little bit more insight on the type of growth that you might be expecting there? And then if you wouldn't mind, just driving down into IS&T, where are you seeing relative areas of strength in '15 and weakness in '15, just what's the mix doing vary?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So on our -- I don't want to get into specifics about '16 and '17 other than we are -- at Combat other than we have the backlog and are poised for reasonable growth. Growth that we will manage according to our terms and conditions of our contract and also
componenttext: So on our -- I don't want to get into specifics about '16 and '17 other than we are -- at Combat other than we have the backlog and are poised for reasonable growth. Growth that we will manage according to our terms and conditions of our contract and also our supply chain. So I would expect growth but I'm -- but not of a double-digit nature. So don't think about it that way. We're not going to burn off that backlog that quickly. It's not efficient and it's not in accordance with the terms and conditions of our contract. The second part of your question?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: The mix at IS&T, where are you seeing [indiscernible]
componenttext: The mix at IS&T, where are you seeing [indiscernible]

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Oh, mix in IS&T. So we have, as you know, over the last 2 years, our IT services business has composed a larger percentage of revenues. That is somewhat changing as a percent of revenue. You may now combine 2 of our non-IT businesses and AIS and C4 system
componenttext: Oh, mix in IS&T. So we have, as you know, over the last 2 years, our IT services business has composed a larger percentage of revenues. That is somewhat changing as a percent of revenue. You may now combine 2 of our non-IT businesses and AIS and C4 systems into Mission Systems. And over time, they're -- it is our anticipation that they will grow as a larger percentage of our IS&T sales than IT. But both of those businesses are poised very, very well for, again, single-digit growth but still growth. And I would add that I'm very pleased with their margin performance. It's particularly interesting that the year that we had some revenue decline, considerable revenue decline, we outperformed on margins. And this year, we expect revenue decline and again higher margins and this time, bring with it higher earnings than last year. So that's a pretty wholesome story from my perspective.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Phebe, on that, just one point of clarification. Do you anticipate then at the end of 2015 to be kind of in a flat revenue environment year-over-year? Or creeping into positive territory on IS&T?
componenttext: Phebe, on that, just one point of clarification. Do you anticipate then at the end of 2015 to be kind of in a flat revenue environment year-over-year? Or creeping into positive territory on IS&T?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: We're projecting a positive territory, positive growth. In fact, for every single one of our businesses.
componenttext: We're projecting a positive territory, positive growth. In fact, for every single one of our businesses.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Carter Copeland of Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Carter Copeland of Barclays.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just I will stick to one and I want to switch gears and go back to the cash flow and capital deployment discussion. And the question is, is there an upper bound to how much balance sheet you might use to normalize your free cash flow deployment? Should we
componenttext: Just I will stick to one and I want to switch gears and go back to the cash flow and capital deployment discussion. And the question is, is there an upper bound to how much balance sheet you might use to normalize your free cash flow deployment? Should we think of this as whatever the GAAP [ph] to 100% conversion is, is what you used in the balance sheet? Or could it be more extensive than that?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Every year, we provided the same kind of guidance with respect to capital deployment and that is that we've, at least in the last 2 years and again this year, have anticipated deploying all of our free cash flow and share repurchases and dividends and we
componenttext: Every year, we provided the same kind of guidance with respect to capital deployment and that is that we've, at least in the last 2 years and again this year, have anticipated deploying all of our free cash flow and share repurchases and dividends and we anticipate doing that again this year. But as with every other year, we give you the overall strategy and then the execution, the tactical execution comes during the course of the year. So think about in general terms that we'll use our balance sheet to view quite, I think accurately put it, normalize our cash flow for share repurchases. But I see no fundamental reason or benefit from tapping into our balance sheet beyond that for share repurchases. Some of you have requested that we do just some that, not to review all but some out in the environment have requested that we go into our balance sheet early on and buy significant number of shares. And I argued then and I'll continue to argue now, I don't think that's judicious nor prudent. And I think that this year is a perfect example of why you don't want to have expended all your bullets in prior years. Think about all this as telling you what we're going to do at the beginning of the year and doing it and having a very, very reliable results and execution of our capital deployment in the year. So this year [ph] will look very similar with respect to what our capital deployment intent is. Free cash flow and a little bit off -- and some off the balance sheet, depending again on where they are in free cash flow.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015

componenttextpreview: Phebe, maybe another one on the balance sheet. I appreciate your comments about not wanting to spend all of your bullets. But maybe longer term, what's the defense budget environment were to improve, would that change the way that you thought about using
componenttext: Phebe, maybe another one on the balance sheet. I appreciate your comments about not wanting to spend all of your bullets. But maybe longer term, what's the defense budget environment were to improve, would that change the way that you thought about using your balance sheet relative to some of your peers?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: The way I think about the balance sheet is we have a strong balance sheet that gives us flexibility and agility and opportunity both in the year of execution and going forward. And I intend to preserve that flexibility and I intend to preserve the strengt
componenttext: The way I think about the balance sheet is we have a strong balance sheet that gives us flexibility and agility and opportunity both in the year of execution and going forward. And I intend to preserve that flexibility and I intend to preserve the strength of that balance sheet, with some variability in any given year but not taking off cash off of that balance sheet to change our overall fire power. So as I sit here today, that is our strategy and we will adopt accordingly in the future if circumstances might change.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015

componenttext: No. This -- the quarterly distribution of EPS that I gave you in my remarks is atypical about performance that we tend to start out quite, built throughout the year and have a strong fourth quarter. So that's very consistent with the ebb and flow of our business, all right?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Fourth Quarter 2014 General Dynamics Earnings Conference Call. My name is Chantilly, and I will be your facilitator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being record
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Fourth Quarter 2014 General Dynamics Earnings Conference Call. My name is Chantilly, and I will be your facilitator for today's call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference is being recorded for replay purposes.
I would now like to turn the conference over to your host for today, Ms. Erin Linnihan. Please proceed.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Chantilly, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to the General Dynamics' Fourth Quarter Conference Call.As always, any forward-looking statements made today represent our estimates regarding the company's outlook. These estimates are subject t
componenttext:
Thank you, Chantilly, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to the General Dynamics' Fourth Quarter Conference Call.
As always, any forward-looking statements made today represent our estimates regarding the company's outlook. These estimates are subject to some risks and uncertainties. Additional information regarding these factors is contained in the company's 10-K and 10-Q filings.
With that, I would like to turn the call over to our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Phebe Novakovic.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Erin. Earlier today, we reported fourth quarter earnings from continuing operations of $2.19 per fully diluted share on revenue of $8.36 billion and earnings from continuing operations of $737 million. It was our strongest revenue performance in t
componenttext:
Thanks, Erin. Earlier today, we reported fourth quarter earnings from continuing operations of $2.19 per fully diluted share on revenue of $8.36 billion and earnings from continuing operations of $737 million. It was our strongest revenue performance in the past 12 quarters, the highest operating earnings ever and the highest earnings from continuing operations. For us, it was a powerful quarter. Incidentally, we beat analyst consensus by $0.06.
For the year, we had fully diluted earnings per share of $7.83 on revenue of $30.85 billion and earnings from continuing operations of $2.7 billion, a return on sales of 8.7%. It was a year of solid achievement from both an operating perspective and the development of significant backlog.
As you can see from schedule H to the press release, funded backlog grew from $38.3 billion at year-end 2013 to $52.9 billion at the end of last year. The story for total backlog is much the same. We were at $45.9 billion at the end of 2013 and sit at $72.4 billion at the end of 2014. As a result, we are well positioned for growth in 2016 and 2017.
Free cash flow from operations was a negative $254 million in the quarter, however, for the year, we had free cash flow from operations of $3.2 billion or 120% of earnings from continuing operations. This outpaced 2013 by $532 million.
Let me give you some detail on the quarter and the year in each of the business groups. First, Aerospace. Revenue and earnings were up nicely over the year-ago quarter. Sales were up $105 million, 4.9%; and earnings were up $64 million, a significant 18.4% on very strong margin improvement. This is particularly impressive when one considers that G&A and net R&D were up $40 million over the year-ago quarter. On a sequential basis, sales were off $49 million, but earnings were up $1 million on a 40-basis-point improvement in operating margins.
I should add that Jet remained nicely profitable in the quarter, with a better contribution on both a year-ago and sequential comparison basis.
The order activity in the quarter was robust, as one would expect with the announcement of 2 new aircraft. As you can observe on exhibit H, funded backlog, total backlog and total potential contract value, including options, are all up significantly.
Even if we were to ignore the orders related to the 2 new aircraft, total orders from current production aircraft were the highest of the year. All large cabin aircraft had a dollar-based book-to-bill greater than 1 to 1.
For the year, revenues were $8.65 billion and operating earnings were $1.61 billion on an operating margin of 18.6%. This is a year-over-year improvement of 6.5% on sales, 13.8% on earnings and 120 basis points on operating margin. All in all, a very good year at Aerospace, with strong operating leverage.
At Combat Systems, sales were up $23 million or 1.4%, and earnings were up $21 million or 8.4% on 110-basis-point improvement in operating margin over the year-ago quarter. Sequentially, the story is similar. Sales were up $219 million and earnings were up $39 million.
For the year, sales were down $100 million or 1.7%, and earnings were down $46 million or 5.1%. This compares quite favorably to the guidance we've provided at this time last year. You may recall that we guided to a 4% to 4.5% revenue decline as opposed to the 1.7% decline that occurred. We also guided to operating margins of 14%, which we beat by 100 basis points.
Overall, Combat Systems is a story of solid additions to backlog, better-than-anticipated revenue and outstanding cost and margin performance. This is a business group that has clearly stabilized.
Marine group revenue in the quarter exceeded $2 billion for the first time ever. Operating earnings of $193 million were the second highest ever recorded. Revenue was up $410 million or 25.2% compared to the year-ago quarter and up $220 million or 12.1%, sequentially. Revenues for the year were up $600 million, almost 9%, very nice growth.
Operating earnings were up $34 million or 21.4% against the year-ago quarter and up $23 million or 13.5%, sequentially. For the full year, earnings were up $37 million or 5.6% on a 30-basis-point decline in operating margin, attributable to mix shift, which was consistent with our guidance to you.
In the Marine group, we guided you at this time last year to a revenue increase of 2.5%, which we obviously exceeded. We forecasted margins at 9.5% and wound up at 9.6%. All in all, a very good year for the Marine group.
IS&T is a business group where we saw less-than-expected revenue decline and improved operating performance. Revenue in the quarter was $2.47 billion, down $223 million or 8.3% against the year-ago quarter. Revenue was up 9.8% sequentially and down $1.1 billion or 10.8% for the year. Remember that this is dramatically less than the 20% revenue decline we forecasted in our guidance to you at this time last year.
Operating earnings of $212 million in the quarter were 8.2% better than the fourth quarter a year ago. On a sequential basis, operating earnings were up $10 million or 5%. For the year, earnings were down only $10 million or 1.3%, which is very good performance in the face of a 10.8% revenue decline.
On this call a year ago, I gave you guidance with respect to operating margins in the 8.2% range, which we beat by 40 basis points. All in all, we beat forecasted revenue by $1 billion and operating margins by 40 basis points. When that happens, the result is a very pleasant upside surprise.
So company-wide, on this call a year ago, our guidance for 2014 was to expect revenues of $30 billion, operating margin rate of 12%, a tax rate of 31% and a return on sales of 8%. We wound up the year with revenues of $30.85 billion, an operating margin rate of 12.6%, an effective tax rate of 29.7% and a return on sales of 8.7%.
We provided EPS guidance of $6.80 to $6.85. We wound up at $7.83. About $0.62 of the improvement came from better-than-planned operating performance, $0.13 from the slightly lower-than-planned tax rate and the balance from share count as a result of share repurchases.
So let me provide you some thoughts about 2015, initially by business group and then on a company-wide roll-up. In Aerospace, we expect revenues to be approximately $9.4 billion, up about 8.3%. Margin rate should be approximately 18%, somewhat down from 2014, attributable in part to less favorability at Jet, nonetheless, up about 4.5% in earnings.
In Combat Systems, we expect both revenue and earnings to be essentially flat, with growth resuming in 2016 and beyond. The Marine group is expected to have revenue growth of 2% to 2.5% and a margin rate in the 9.5% range, resulting in a very modest improvement to operating earnings.
Finally, in IS&T, we expect a revenue decline of about 5.5% but improved margin rate of slightly more than 9%. This will result in improved operating earnings year-over-year. We expected last year to be our low watermark for revenue. In part, we are seeing some of the decline we anticipated last year being delayed into this year. Once again, we should see revenue growth in 2016 and 2017.
All of this rolls up to an operating plan of about $31.3 billion to $31.5 billion of revenue, EBIT rate around 12.8% and a return on sales of roughly 8.7%. This plan is purely from operations, assumes a 30.5% tax rate, assumes we buy enough shares to hold the share count steady with the year-end figures so as not to permit dilution from option exercise. This rolls up to an EPS guidance of $8.05 to $8.10 per fully diluted share. This compares with last year's guidance of $6.80 to $6.85 at the same time on the same basis. So much like last year, beating our guidance must come from outperforming the operating plan and the effect of share repurchases.
So how should one think about the quarterly progression of EPS? Whatever your model is for the year, divided by 4, and the first and second quarters will be light by about $0.10, the third quarter about right on and the fourth quarter about $0.20 better. By the way, quarterly progression is notoriously difficult.
With respect to capital deployment, we anticipate using all of our free cash flow in 2015 for dividends and share repurchases. While we don't anticipate a robust year from a free cash flow perspective in light of the advanced payments on international orders that we have received last year, we intend to treat the free cash available for dividends and share repurchases on a -- on some normalized basis. In short, we will use balance sheet cash as necessary to normalize the year.
I would now like to turn the call over to our Chief Financial Officer, Jason Aiken.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Phebe, and good morning. I'll take just a minute and cover a few miscellaneous financial items before the question-and-answer period.Net interest expense in the quarter was $19 million versus $23 million in the fourth quarter of 2013. And for
componenttext:
Thank you, Phebe, and good morning. I'll take just a minute and cover a few miscellaneous financial items before the question-and-answer period.
Net interest expense in the quarter was $19 million versus $23 million in the fourth quarter of 2013. And for the year, interest expense was $86 million, consistent with the year before. For 2015, we expect net interest expense of around $82 million, a decline from 2014 resulting from the repayment of $500 million of fixed rate notes that matured last week.
At the end of the year, our balance sheet reflects a net cash position, that's cash in excess of debt, of $477 million. This was down by about $1 billion from the end of 2013 reflecting the cash we used from the balance sheet for capital deployment activities, which I'll address in just a minute.
Our effective tax rate was 29.5% for the quarter and 29.7% for the year, and that's a bit lower than we had been forecasting. As you'll recall, our most recent projections were in the neighborhood of 30% to 30.5%. The lower outcome is attributable to the R&D tax credit extension in late December. For 2015, as Phebe mentioned, we expect an effective tax rate of around 30.5%.
And finally, on the income statement, you'll notice we took a charge in the quarter in discontinued operations. This is related to the sale of our AxleTech business, which we first reported in the second quarter when we made the decision to sell that business. The charge we took at that time was predicated on the 2014 closing of the sale. The regulatory review process for the transaction delayed the closing until the 5th of January. And as a result, we were not able to take advantage of some tax benefits we had anticipated, so we adjusted the loss on the sale in the fourth quarter.
Switching gears, we contributed $515 million to our pension plans in 2014. And for 2015, we expect that amount to decline to approximately $185 million as a result of the interest rate released from the Highway and Transportation Funding Act of 2014.
On the capital deployment front, to summarize our activities for the year, we delivered on our commitment to return capital to our shareholders while maintaining a strong balance sheet. In total, we expended approximately $3.4 billion on share repurchases in 2014. And when you combine our share repurchases with our dividend payments, we spent $4.2 billion in shareholder-friendly actions in 2014 or 1.3x our free cash flow from operations for the year.
Erin, that concludes my remarks, and I'll turn the time back over to you for the Q&A.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jason. [Operator Instructions] Chantilly, could you please remind participants how to enter the queue?
componenttext: Thanks, Jason. [Operator Instructions] Chantilly, could you please remind participants how to enter the queue?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
