componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of David Strauss of UBS.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Phebe, could you give us a little bit more detail on the free cash flow outlook? It sounds like it's going to be large. Can you maybe peg it as a percent of net income in 2015? And what exactly -- how much of that is an advanced drawdown in terms of the p
componenttext: Phebe, could you give us a little bit more detail on the free cash flow outlook? It sounds like it's going to be large. Can you maybe peg it as a percent of net income in 2015? And what exactly -- how much of that is an advanced drawdown in terms of the pressure on free cash flow?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we tend not to give you specifics of the percentage of net income on our free cash flow, but suffice it to say, it's going to be less robust as a result of our drawdown in our deposits. But we will intend to normalize our free cash flow using our cash
componenttext: So we tend not to give you specifics of the percentage of net income on our free cash flow, but suffice it to say, it's going to be less robust as a result of our drawdown in our deposits. But we will intend to normalize our free cash flow using our cash on the balance sheet to affect any capital deployment. I think that's about as much color as we usually give you and as much as we're prepared to give you.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ron Epstein of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ron Epstein of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a quick question for you on Gulfstream. How do you expect the, I guess, the sales profile for the business to go when you are leading into the ramp-up of the new models, right? So maybe a better way to say it, in the transition between kind of the ol
componenttext: Just a quick question for you on Gulfstream. How do you expect the, I guess, the sales profile for the business to go when you are leading into the ramp-up of the new models, right? So maybe a better way to say it, in the transition between kind of the old models and the new models, would you expect the profile of the business to continue to grow?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, we do expect the profile to continue to grow in the near years, but at less of a rate than it will grow when we introduce an entry into service of the new airplanes. So we have growth between now and entry into service of the G500, and we expect acce
componenttext: Yes, we do expect the profile to continue to grow in the near years, but at less of a rate than it will grow when we introduce an entry into service of the new airplanes. So we have growth between now and entry into service of the G500, and we expect accelerated growth going forward from there.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Robert Spingarn of Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Robert Spingarn of Credit Suisse.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to talk a little bit about Marine and the strength you talked about there, your very strong fourth quarter and how things do trend as we go through '15, especially on some of the development work you're doing on upcoming programs.
componenttext: I wanted to talk a little bit about Marine and the strength you talked about there, your very strong fourth quarter and how things do trend as we go through '15, especially on some of the development work you're doing on upcoming programs.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. 2014 growth was driven by higher-than-expected volume on Block IV in Electric Boat, more on planned repair work and additional commercial volume. And we anticipate that those growth elements to continue into next year, albeit at a less great -- less
componenttext: Okay. 2014 growth was driven by higher-than-expected volume on Block IV in Electric Boat, more on planned repair work and additional commercial volume. And we anticipate that those growth elements to continue into next year, albeit at a less great -- less of a rate of increase. Our developmental work, primarily on Ohio Replacement ballistic-missile submarine, continues apace. We're the sole source on that contract, and we're year-over-year increasing work on that contract, and it's going very well. So we like where we're positioned there.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And would you say -- the fourth quarter itself, you said I think the strongest revenue -- quarterly revenues you've seen. How do we think about just the timing there?
componenttext: And would you say -- the fourth quarter itself, you said I think the strongest revenue -- quarterly revenues you've seen. How do we think about just the timing there?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we have continued to see growth this year at about 2% to 2.5%, which is, I think, very good in this environment. And that growth will continue into the out-years as we get more volume on Block IV. Additionally, we continue to do additional work on o
componenttext: Well, we have continued to see growth this year at about 2% to 2.5%, which is, I think, very good in this environment. And that growth will continue into the out-years as we get more volume on Block IV. Additionally, we continue to do additional work on our commercial volume. Repair work fluctuates but has, year-over-year, been growing, and we begin work on the fourth MLP. So we've got growth engines for Marine group. We did obviously last year, we do into this year and we do in the future. We've been telling a growth story for the last 2 years at Marine group, and you saw it manifest itself in 2014. It's going to continue to 2015 and into the foreseeable future.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Cai Von Rumohr of Cowen and Company.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Cai Von Rumohr of Cowen and Company.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I guess I'm a little confused at Gulfstream. If your sales go up to 9.4% [ph], a nice sales gain, and we're getting improving profitability on the 650, why are the margins down? I mean, Jet just isn't that big a part of the business. And what's -- mayb
componenttext: So I guess I'm a little confused at Gulfstream. If your sales go up to 9.4% [ph], a nice sales gain, and we're getting improving profitability on the 650, why are the margins down? I mean, Jet just isn't that big a part of the business. And what's -- maybe give us a little more color on the delivery mix, if you could.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So we have a slightly -- so there are a couple of things that are compressing margins slightly in 2015. We have a slightly unfavorable mix shift in green production between large cabin and mid-cabin. We're keeping large-cabin production at about the
componenttext: Sure. So we have a slightly -- so there are a couple of things that are compressing margins slightly in 2015. We have a slightly unfavorable mix shift in green production between large cabin and mid-cabin. We're keeping large-cabin production at about the same rate as we did last year, at about 115 units. We're increasing mid-cabin by 10 units. So there's a somewhat unfavorable mix shift between large and mid-sized green. We've got less of a contribution at Jet primarily, and exclusively driven by mix shift. We've got higher R&D in this upcoming year. Remember that we're building multiple test aircraft that carry with them no revenue and earnings. And then the final issue that's impacting margin somewhat in 2015 is we have higher preowned. So those are the 4 components that are driving the margin variability.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: But the R&D, I mean, is that up as a percent of sales? Because if the -- is the G650 still improving in profitability? Or is the profitability declining on the 450 and 550?
componenttext: But the R&D, I mean, is that up as a percent of sales? Because if the -- is the G650 still improving in profitability? Or is the profitability declining on the 450 and 550?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. So that's a kind of 2-part question. Net R&D is up slightly. The 650 profitability continues to increase, and the 450 and 550 profitability is staying exactly where it has been. We have a greater mix shift this year, a mix of mid-cabin, which carries
componenttext: No. So that's a kind of 2-part question. Net R&D is up slightly. The 650 profitability continues to increase, and the 450 and 550 profitability is staying exactly where it has been. We have a greater mix shift this year, a mix of mid-cabin, which carries with it lower earnings -- lower margins. Okay? So I think you need to think about it that way. We've talked before about the variability of margins at Gulfstream, and this is an example of it. There's nothing unexpected from our point of view. There's nothing systemic. This is simply the ebb and flow of production, R&D and preowned.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Myles Walton of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Myles Walton of Deutsche Bank.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: You mentioned that the -- that all of the large-cabin programs have book-to-bill above 1. And so the question is really twofold. One is, where are the demands you're seeing the biggest pockets of strength, and whether you're seeing any dilution of strengt
componenttext: You mentioned that the -- that all of the large-cabin programs have book-to-bill above 1. And so the question is really twofold. One is, where are the demands you're seeing the biggest pockets of strength, and whether you're seeing any dilution of strength in the oil-rich countries or Russia, in particular? And then the other piece of it is, is 2015 the year where you're delivering more G650s than the 450 and 550s in the mix?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So let me talk a little bit about demand and give you a little bit of color there. The demand for our end-product, early-in-production airplanes was quite handsome for the last quarter. The 650 and the 280 increased. And interestingly but not surprisingly
componenttext: So let me talk a little bit about demand and give you a little bit of color there. The demand for our end-product, early-in-production airplanes was quite handsome for the last quarter. The 650 and the 280 increased. And interestingly but not surprisingly, when we got inside the demand curve for the 650 inside the 3-year delivery window, Q4 orders were particularly strong. 280 was again strong. The 450 and 550 demand has slowed slightly. It's okay, not superheated, but good enough. And we continue to see strong demand, primarily in North America and somewhat in Asia and also in the Mid East. Heretofore, we have seen no impact on oil prices on our backlog or, frankly, in our demand. If you're asking what percentage of our backlog may have some exposure to energy-related -- or happen to have some energy-related exposures, it's about 5%, but we haven't seen any impact yet. Now I would add, we're seeing historically low operating costs, which is a -- usually drives increased flight hours, and that's a potential upside for our service business. So we tend not to give you deliveries any -- with any more specificity than we already have with respect to models. We break it up by large cabin and mid-cabin, and I don't intend to change that in a moment.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Doug Harned of Sanford Bernstein.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Doug Harned of Sanford Bernstein.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to just follow up on that. On the G450 -- excuse me, on the G550, when you look forward here, where are you today in terms of months of backlog? It's something that you've given us in the past. And how are you thinking about pricing as you approa
componenttext: I wanted to just follow up on that. On the G450 -- excuse me, on the G550, when you look forward here, where are you today in terms of months of backlog? It's something that you've given us in the past. And how are you thinking about pricing as you approach the G500 and G600 coming into operation?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So I think you know that we don't talk about pricing. That's competitively sensitive. But let me give you a sense of where we are in first available. In general, for new customers, for the G650 and G650ER, first available is fourth quarter 2017. That
componenttext: Yes. So I think you know that we don't talk about pricing. That's competitively sensitive. But let me give you a sense of where we are in first available. In general, for new customers, for the G650 and G650ER, first available is fourth quarter 2017. That moved to the right, a quarter from third quarter of last year as a result of our good order activity. The G550 is about 12 months out. The G450, late this year. So that moved a couple of months, just a few months into the left. The G280 is also available, first available late this year. And not that anybody asked, but the G150 is first quarter 2016. So it's important to recall, the deals are often in the works that move customers around in the backlog for earlier slots, but the above is about approximate window for new buyers. So I hope that helps you.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: And you can't really comment on the trajectory on pricing with the model change, I guess? Is that...
componenttext: And you can't really comment on the trajectory on pricing with the model change, I guess? Is that...

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. Look, we have continued to hold price on all products, and you could expect that over time, there is some price variability, but we're not about to get into any specifics. That's just not a good competitive place to be in a highly competitive market.
componenttext: No. Look, we have continued to hold price on all products, and you could expect that over time, there is some price variability, but we're not about to get into any specifics. That's just not a good competitive place to be in a highly competitive market.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Robert Stallard of Royal Bank of Canada.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Robert Stallard of Royal Bank of Canada.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Phebe, on IS&T, you've guided down 5.5% for this year. Can you give us an idea of how much of that is already in the backlog and the sort of level of conservatism you might have based into that given the fluctuating situation with the DoD budget?
componenttext: Phebe, on IS&T, you've guided down 5.5% for this year. Can you give us an idea of how much of that is already in the backlog and the sort of level of conservatism you might have based into that given the fluctuating situation with the DoD budget?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Given the what situation?
componenttext: Given the what situation?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Fluctuating.
componenttext: Fluctuating.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Oh, fluctuating. So we had about 3 quarters of our guidance for IS&T. In our backlog, that's exactly where we had been historically, including recently. We've got good -- we've got a high level of RFP, request for proposal, activity, and are bidding on a
componenttext: Oh, fluctuating. So we had about 3 quarters of our guidance for IS&T. In our backlog, that's exactly where we had been historically, including recently. We've got good -- we've got a high level of RFP, request for proposal, activity, and are bidding on a number of contracts. So we're pretty comfortable that we can hit our revenue guidance. And I've -- from our point of view, we have seen less fluctuation in the DoD budget with respect to our IS&T units recently than we had a couple of years ago. So we think that that's somewhat stabilized. And as I told you, we anticipated 2014 to be our low watermark. It was better than we thought it was going to be, and I think some of that decrease bled into 2015.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Sam Pearlstein of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Sam Pearlstein of Wells Fargo.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can you talk, I guess, to -- I'm going to try and put 2 things in there. But first on Marine, I'm somewhat surprised that you're not seeing more margin pressure, given what I would think would be more Block IV work and more Ohio Replacement work in the ye
componenttext: Can you talk, I guess, to -- I'm going to try and put 2 things in there. But first on Marine, I'm somewhat surprised that you're not seeing more margin pressure, given what I would think would be more Block IV work and more Ohio Replacement work in the year just in terms of the mix. So I guess, what are you doing to offset that? And then just related to Combat, you talked about growth resuming in 2016. Is this a business that we should now expect to see kind of growth and this still 15% kind of margin runway kind of far into the future?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Right. Let me address your questions in the order that they were asked. We've talked frequently about margin variability at the Marine group, but it's really a mix shift. And you quite accurately point out that we are experiencing a mix shift really, fran
componenttext: Right. Let me address your questions in the order that they were asked. We've talked frequently about margin variability at the Marine group, but it's really a mix shift. And you quite accurately point out that we are experiencing a mix shift really, frankly, across our portfolio. More Block IV, less Block III, more commercial work coming off of the MLP program and first-of-class ships on the DDG 1000 and DDG 51 restart. That said, these businesses have continued to perform very, very well on cost-cutting efficiency, and their performance has been quite good. And I, frankly, expect to see margin expansion primarily driven by Block IV, as we have increased margin potential and earnings potential from our profitability and efficiency as we move down our learning curve. So Marine group continues to function very, very well, and I like their growth story. Combat Systems' growth, we have that significant backlog. And now, for us, it's all a question of performing on that backlog. And I think this group has demonstrated its operational excellence and will continue to do so. So I expect in -- I've given you my guidance for 2015, but as I project out into the future and think about the business, this is going to be -- we're going to see some growth in Combat, and I would expect and fully anticipate, given the operational excellence of this group, to see margin expansion. But I'm not going to bake any of that in now on some of these programs. We're still in fairly new starts and low-rate production. But for everything we see, this is a group that will continue to cut costs and improve its efficiency.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Hunter Keay of Wolfe Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Hunter Keay of Wolfe Research.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Phebe, can you talk a little bit about the variables that drive the decision to take up rate? As we look here across the global landscape, questions about global economic growth possibly decelerating, particularly in emerging markets, you have a very stro
componenttext: Phebe, can you talk a little bit about the variables that drive the decision to take up rate? As we look here across the global landscape, questions about global economic growth possibly decelerating, particularly in emerging markets, you have a very strong U.S. dollar right now. That might be having an impact in some of your operating expenses. And sort of as that filters into sort of potential cannibalization within the product lines, more of a G650 question than anything else, but can you talk about, maybe at a higher level, if you prefer, what factors you guys look at when deciding how to think about taking up production rates?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we have historically, and as we talked about before, we've historically set our production rates and we've continued that practice based on what we see in demand and to optimize around our economic efficiency, our supplier base. And we've been very jud
componenttext: So we have historically, and as we talked about before, we've historically set our production rates and we've continued that practice based on what we see in demand and to optimize around our economic efficiency, our supplier base. And we've been very judicious year-over-year in setting our production rates and our delivery. So as I mentioned, we continue to see very strong demand, particularly for the 650. Our pipeline on the 650 is very good, the 280 also. So we really haven't seen much impact in the emerging markets, certainly not this year. North America remains very strong with us, Asia-Pacific and then -- and we're also seeing some increased demand in the Middle East. I would also tell you that about 60% of our backlog is with public and private companies, including Fortune 500s, and they tend to be very stable and reliable and predictable. And as I said, our pipeline continues to show interest on their part. So I hope that, that kind of addressed it. We look at a complex number of factors: what our demand is, what our goals are for our operating efficiency, our supply chain, we manage prudently.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Peter Arment of Sterne Agee.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Peter Arment of Sterne Agee.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Phebe, a question on just the international demand. I know you gave us some good color on Gulfstream's impact, particularly tied to the energy end market. You won a lot of orders in terms of Combat this past year. How are we thinking about the internation
componenttext: Phebe, a question on just the international demand. I know you gave us some good color on Gulfstream's impact, particularly tied to the energy end market. You won a lot of orders in terms of Combat this past year. How are we thinking about the international demand for some of the defense business that you have? And any risks tied to see some of the lower-price of oil on that?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: The lower-priced oil. I've been a big believer, and I think history has demonstrated, that demand for defense products is driven by threat and perceived threat, and you just have to open up the paper to see that the world is an increasingly unsafe place.
componenttext: The lower-priced oil. I've been a big believer, and I think history has demonstrated, that demand for defense products is driven by threat and perceived threat, and you just have to open up the paper to see that the world is an increasingly unsafe place. So we see an increased level of interest in parts of Europe and the Middle East. As you might anticipate, governments begin to rethink their spending priorities in light of some of the threats that they see, both actualized and potential. So we have a pretty robust pipeline that's continuing in our IS&T unit and for Combat. Now I will tell you that the Marine group has almost no and never has had much international exposure. It's just the nature of our Navy shipbuilding program.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of George Shapiro of Shapiro Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of George Shapiro of Shapiro Research.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to pursue the margin at Gulfstream a little bit more. This quarter, effectively, you had 60% incrementals. And if I add back the $40 million higher R&D and G&A you had, you would have 100% conversion. So can you tell me what was so strong this qu
componenttext: I wanted to pursue the margin at Gulfstream a little bit more. This quarter, effectively, you had 60% incrementals. And if I add back the $40 million higher R&D and G&A you had, you would have 100% conversion. So can you tell me what was so strong this quarter that all of next year is probably going to decline, if your numbers are right, to 15% kind of incremental margins? And also, you had no preowned this quarter, you had 3 for the year versus 11 in '13. So why does '15 preowned go up?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, that's a compound question, George. So let me see if I can at least address what I think the essence is. The same -- having less preowned this year clearly was an upper to our margins. Preowned tends to carry no revenue. And we forecast preowned dem
componenttext: Well, that's a compound question, George. So let me see if I can at least address what I think the essence is. The same -- having less preowned this year clearly was an upper to our margins. Preowned tends to carry no revenue. And we forecast preowned demand based on what we see in our backlog. And sometimes that comes to fruition and sometimes not. So this has been a pretty sustained pattern over time with respect to preowned. It tends to be lumpy. And we won't know until the quarter of execution whether, in fact, anticipated preowneds come into our market or they are sold before they get to Gulfstream. So that makes preowned a little bit tougher to articulate. We had -- the performance at Gulfstream this year was extremely strong, and we had a favorable completion mix in the fourth quarter that we are reversing somewhat going into next year. So we've talked multiple times about the fallacy of being able to predict with great specificity the Gulfstream or Aerospace margins. And I will tell you, Jet had a very strong year this year. And that contribution will be less next year, primarily driven by a mix shift as they move into some additional completion work and they come down their learning curve. So all of these factors are planned at Gulfstream and Aerospace margins.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Could you point to some unique things in the fourth quarter that caused such an extraordinarily high conversion that won't repeat?
componenttext: Could you point to some unique things in the fourth quarter that caused such an extraordinarily high conversion that won't repeat?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I think, again -- gosh, George, I've tried. We've got less contribution from Jet and we had a favorable delivery mix, large cabin to mid-cabin. And that's a pretty -- those are pretty big movers. So -- and less preowned, and that's a big one. Preown
componenttext: Well, I think, again -- gosh, George, I've tried. We've got less contribution from Jet and we had a favorable delivery mix, large cabin to mid-cabin. And that's a pretty -- those are pretty big movers. So -- and less preowned, and that's a big one. Preowned tends to carry very little with no or negative margins. So that, in my mind, explains it. I think the reality that we're facing. Okay, George?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Howard Rubel of Jefferies.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Howard Rubel of Jefferies.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Rather than be too granular here, I wanted to take a step back. As you look at your outlook and what you've asked your senior executives to do, where -- as you look at the various risks, might you see either challenges or opportunities? And I'll use 2 exa
componenttext: Rather than be too granular here, I wanted to take a step back. As you look at your outlook and what you've asked your senior executives to do, where -- as you look at the various risks, might you see either challenges or opportunities? And I'll use 2 examples and then hopefully you can add to that. One is, some of your operations have European- or Canadian-based costs and you sell in dollars, so there may be some upside there, although I know you hedge some. And then also you're embarked on a very aggressive research and development campaign at Gulfstream. And how have you assessed the risk and where have you felt like you've made progress? So it's a bit of specifics and then wrapped in a little bit of -- the $8.05 to $8.10 is a nice start for the year, but I'm sure we won't end there.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So look, just to reiterate, we've given you guidance based on the same assumptions that we used last year. And our ability to do better is simply going to be as a result of cap -- share repurchases and outperforming our plan. If you look at our outlook, i
componenttext: So look, just to reiterate, we've given you guidance based on the same assumptions that we used last year. And our ability to do better is simply going to be as a result of cap -- share repurchases and outperforming our plan. If you look at our outlook, it's informed by the last 2 years, where we focused on operations, reduced our costs and, in result, built our backlog. So we are poised for growth as a result of that backlog for several years to come. It's a very nice position to be. We are going to see some good growth in '16 and '17, and the business is poised for that. We've been focusing on operations in what we basically call the back to basics, which is blocking and tackling. That work is never done, so we're going to continue to attack our costs to a relentless focus on our cost performance and reengineering our business that will make us more competitive, reduces our costs and makes us more competitive and that, too, will help growth. So we have positioned ourselves nicely and I think will continue to do so going forward. Our opportunities are, because of our improved competitiveness, increased growth primarily both overseas, and we've talked about that before. We've got another opportunity of margin expansion going forward as we focus on our continuous improvement. We've got -- when I think about risks, you implicitly asked about a foreign currency risk. We are less exposed to foreign currency variability and -- than companies in other sectors. For example, 60% of our business is with the U.S. government, and Gulfstream's exposure is to the U.S. economy. We have -- there's some translation difficulty year-over-year, with respect to currency fluctuations. We've embedded those in our plan. We also have some nice natural hedges, both in Europe and in Canada. So has the strong dollar affected any of our demand? Not really. And we certainly haven't seen it in our backlog. We had a translation -- we had to adjust our Combat backlog as a result of that negative translation, but that's on work that's many years out. So -- but in terms of sales, we're not just seeing any particular impact. Is it potential? Sure, but it's not affecting us. So I -- oh, no, you asked about R&D as a risk. So the key when you introduce, I think, you invest in a business and new product development and you introduce new product is that you have managed that R&D and the engineering and development and design effectively. And Gulfstream has a proven history of doing that, and we are continuing to see that same kind of excellent execution in our design and engineering efforts at Gulfstream. So we don't see any risk that's outside what we have always seen in the past with respect to R&D, but we managed this -- we manage R&D at Gulfstream in their design and engineering activities very, very closely. And we really have -- again, we've set the expectations accordingly, and we've got a great team there. It's all about the execution, and so far, so good. So I hope that sort of passes where you were headed.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, one's more just sort of a clarification. On the Combat side, you're saying flat. You have these big orders, obviously, in your backlog that were from international customers last year. Can you give us some help with how much you expect international
componenttext: Well, one's more just sort of a clarification. On the Combat side, you're saying flat. You have these big orders, obviously, in your backlog that were from international customers last year. Can you give us some help with how much you expect international, if it's the case, to be up, and then U.S. down in 2015? And the second one is just, more broadly speaking, looking at the whole company. Can you speak a little bit, wherever you feel comfortable, about the bookings that you're expecting across the company this year? Particularly interested is if you -- if there are any of these larger Combat opportunities that are still out there that might hit kind of $1 billion-plus opportunities? And then also particularly interested in the 500 and 600 and what the tempo you expect on bookings there might be?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Complex questions, but let me address them in the order in which you asked them. We are seeing stabilization at -- in our U.S. land forces' exposure at Combat Systems directly in line with our expectations. And so we don't really see any, at least,
componenttext: Okay. Complex questions, but let me address them in the order in which you asked them. We are seeing stabilization at -- in our U.S. land forces' exposure at Combat Systems directly in line with our expectations. And so we don't really see any, at least, surprises that we can see in the near term. International orders or international sales this year comprise about, oh, in excess of 55% of Combat sales and will increase to 60% over time, not at the expense of our domestic activity, but just as a revenue expansion. So we do -- we still have a lot of, I'd say, a number of international orders in our pipeline that are of decent size that it's our -- it is our expectation that given our competitiveness and our cost structure, we're going to be highly competitive in those competitions. So we have additional upside in building our backlog at Combat. But I'm not prepared to give you any specifics on whether that makes it a book-to-bill of 1:1 in any 1 given year. That will depend on a lot of things on when these competitions are decided. And -- but we've got a lot of proposal activity out there. And with respect to, I think, 550 -- or 500 and 600 tempo, both of those R&D programs are proceeding apace, with no major changes since the last time we talked to you about it. Our pipeline is very robust, and I expect sales to increase as -- orders to increase as we get closer and closer to the entry into service of the 500 and then the 600. So there is no -- there have been no stumbling blocks heretofore. And our profiles in R&D and production of the test airplanes remain right on plan. So we're very pleased with that, and we are pleased with the interest that both of these models have generated.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015

componenttext: So on our -- I don't want to get into specifics about '16 and '17 other than we are -- at Combat other than we have the backlog and are poised for reasonable growth, growth that we will manage according to our terms and conditions of our contract and also our supply chain. So I would expect growth, but I'm -- but not of a double-digit nature, so don't think about it that way. We're not going to burn off that backlog that quickly. It's not efficient and it's not in accordance with the terms and conditions of our contract. The second part of your question?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: The mix at IS&T, where are you seeing strength...
componenttext: The mix at IS&T, where are you seeing strength...

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Oh, mix in IS&T. So we have, as you know, over the last few years, our IT services business has composed a larger percentage of our revenues. That is somewhat changing as a percent of revenue. We, you may know, combined 2 of our non-IT businesses, AIS and
componenttext: Oh, mix in IS&T. So we have, as you know, over the last few years, our IT services business has composed a larger percentage of our revenues. That is somewhat changing as a percent of revenue. We, you may know, combined 2 of our non-IT businesses, AIS and C4 Systems, into Mission Systems. And over time, they're -- it is our anticipation that they will grow as a larger percentage of our IS&T sales than IT. But both of those businesses are poised very, very well for, again, single-digit growth, but still growth. And I would add that I'm very pleased with their margin performance. It's particularly interesting that the year that we had some revenue decline, considerable revenue decline, we outperformed on margins. And this year, we expect revenue decline and, again, higher margins and this time, bring with it higher earnings than last year. So that's a pretty wholesome story from my perspective.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just I will stick to one, and I wanted to switch gears and go back to the cash flow and capital deployment discussion. And the question is, is there an upper bound to how much balance sheet you might use to normalize your free cash flow deployment? Should
componenttext: Just I will stick to one, and I wanted to switch gears and go back to the cash flow and capital deployment discussion. And the question is, is there an upper bound to how much balance sheet you might use to normalize your free cash flow deployment? Should we think of this as whatever the gap to 100% conversion is, is what you'll use in the balance sheet? Or could it be more extensive than that?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Every year, we provided the same kind of guidance with respect to capital deployment, and that is that we've, at least in the last 2 years and again this year, have anticipated deploying all of our free cash flow in share repurchases and dividends, and we
componenttext: Every year, we provided the same kind of guidance with respect to capital deployment, and that is that we've, at least in the last 2 years and again this year, have anticipated deploying all of our free cash flow in share repurchases and dividends, and we anticipate doing that again this year. But as with every other year, we give you the overall strategy and then the execution, the tactical execution comes during the course of the year. So think about in general terms that we'll use our balance sheet, to, as you quite, I think, accurately put it, normalize our cash flow for share repurchases. But I see no fundamental reason or benefit from tapping into our balance sheet beyond that for share repurchases. Some of you had requested that we do some -- not necessarily of you all, but some out in the environment had requested that we go into our balance sheet early on and buy a significant number of shares. And I argued then and I'll continue to argue now, I don't think that's judicious nor prudent. And I think that this year is a perfect example of why you don't want to have expended all your bullets in prior years. Think about us as telling you what we're going to do at the beginning of the year and doing it and having very, very reliable results and execution of our capital deployment in the year. So this year ought to look very similar with respect to what our capital deployment intent is. Free cash flow and a little bit -- and some off the balance sheet, depending again on where we are in free cash flow.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q4 2014 Earnings Call, Jan 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, now the way I think about the balance sheet is we have a strong balance sheet that gives us flexibility and agility and opportunity, both in the year of execution and going forward. And I intend to preserve that flexibility and I intend to preserve
componenttext: Okay, now the way I think about the balance sheet is we have a strong balance sheet that gives us flexibility and agility and opportunity, both in the year of execution and going forward. And I intend to preserve that flexibility and I intend to preserve the strength of that balance sheet, with some variability in any given year, but not take enough cash off that balance sheet to change our overall firepower. So as I sit here today, that is our strategy, and we will adapt accordingly in the future as circumstances may change.

componenttext: No. This -- the quarterly distribution of EPS that I gave you in my remarks is very typical of our performance, that we tend to start out light, build throughout the year and have a strong fourth quarter. So that's very consistent with the ebb and flow of our business, all right?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to quarter 1 2015 General Dynamics Earnings Conference Call. My name is Emma, and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference will be recorded for replay purposes. A
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to quarter 1 2015 General Dynamics Earnings Conference Call. My name is Emma, and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference will be recorded for replay purposes. And now, I'd like to now turn the call over to Erin Linnihan, Vice President of Investor Relations. Please proceed, ma'am.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Emma, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to General Dynamics' first quarter conference call.As always, any forward-looking statements made today represent our estimates regarding the company's outlook. These estimates are subject to some ris
componenttext:
Thank you, Emma, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to General Dynamics' first quarter conference call.
As always, any forward-looking statements made today represent our estimates regarding the company's outlook. These estimates are subject to some risks and uncertainties. Additional information regarding these factors is contained in the company's 10-K and 10-Q filings.
With that, I would like to turn the call over to our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Phebe Novakovic.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Erin. Earlier today, we reported first quarter earnings from continuing operations of $2.14 per fully diluted share on revenue of $7.8 billion, operating earnings of slightly over $1 billion and net earnings of $716 million. We beat analyst consen
componenttext:
Thanks, Erin. Earlier today, we reported first quarter earnings from continuing operations of $2.14 per fully diluted share on revenue of $7.8 billion, operating earnings of slightly over $1 billion and net earnings of $716 million. We beat analyst consensus by $0.20 and where we'll ahead of analyst expectations on revenue as well. We were also better than our previous guidance and our own expectations.
I should point out that we enjoyed an effective tax rate of 29% as opposed to consensus of around 30.5%. This accounted for approximately $0.05 of the outperformance. Jason Nacca will fully discuss the tax rate for later.
I should further note that the diluted weighted average share count was 334.7 million for the quarter compared to consensus of approximately 332 million. So none of the outperformance comes from a lower-than-expected share count.
I have asked Jason to give you a little more insight into our share repurchase activity when I conclude my remarks.
All in all, this is a truly strong quarter from an operating perspective as evidenced by the operating margin of 13.2% and a return on revenue of 9.2%.
It was a good quarter from a cash perspective as well. We had $745 million net cash provided by operating activity. After capital expenditures of $98 million, we had $647 million of free cash flow from operations, about 90% of net income.
The general comparisons quarter-over-quarter are pretty compelling compared to the first quarter 2014. Revenue was up $519 million or 7.1%. Total distance revenue was up 10.1%, pretty remarkable.
Our operating earnings was slightly more than $1 billion, up 17.5% over the prior year's quarter, leading to a 120 basis point improvement in margins. This very strong operating leverage is an important part of our story. Net earnings were up more than operating earnings, primarily due to the previously mentioned lower tax rate.
Finally, EPS was top 25.1% over the year ago quarter as a result of better operating earnings, lower tax rate and lower share count.
Let me provide some commentary and a little perspective around the results of our operating segments. First, aerospace. Sales are down by $17 million compared to Q1 2014, less than 1% and down $132 million sequentially against a strong fourth quarter. On the other hand, earnings outpaced the year ago quarter by $27 million, about 6.7% on 140 basis point expansion in operating margin.
Operating earnings were also up $19 million sequentially. The 20.4% operating margin for the group represents the high with both companies contributing. A word of caution here. We are out of the gate fast but this pace is not sustainable from a margin perspective. 
Orders were not overly strong in the quarter but need to be viewed in the context of a very robust fourth quarter 2014. It was a quarter where the sales pipeline was replenished and strengthened, part of a normal cycle after a strong quarter [ph]. This is consistent with what we saw in the first quarter of 2014 following the strong fourth quarter 2013.
We're off to a very good start in the Aerospace Group. Marine Systems.
Revenue of $1.94 billion was up $342 million or 21.4% compared to the year ago quarter and down $97 million sequentially as one would expect against the fourth quarter 2014. Operating earnings were up $22 million or 13.3% against the year ago quarter and down $5 million sequentially. We had particularly good performance at Electric Boat at NASSCO. 
Some of the more striking comparisons are found at Combat Systems. Compared to the first quarter of 2014, sales were up $105 million or 8.3%, and earnings were up $65 million or 46.8% on a 400 basis point improvement in operating margins.
Recall that the results in the first quarter of 2014 were impacted by a $29 million restructuring charge at European Land Systems as a result of reductions in the Austrian operations, which were consolidated into Spain and Switzerland. If we disregard that charge, margins would have been 13.4% on a pro forma basis. Even on that basis, the improvement in this year's operating margin is a significant 160 basis points.
Sequentially, revenue was down $251 million and operating earnings were down $67 million, as anticipated in the business that always has a very strong fourth quarter, largely related to contract delivery.
All up, continued strong performance of Combat Systems. It's been a long time since we've been able to report an increase in revenue in this group. 
IS&T. The big upside surprise incurred in this group. You might recall that our guidance was to expect a revenue decline of 5.5% year-over-year. Well, that certainly did not happen in the first quarter. Revenue in the quarter was up $89 million or 3.9% against the year ago quarter and off only $98 million against the powerful fourth quarter 2014. Operating earnings of $217 million in the quarter was $34 million more than the year ago quarter, up 18.6% on 120 basis point improvement in margin.
On a sequential basis, operating earnings were up $5 million on a 60 basis point improvement in margins. Once again, nice operating leverage. The 9.2% operating margins were the best that this group has achieved in a while and is very encouraging. The trend is in the right direction.
So we're off to a very good start to the year, nicely ahead of our expectation. We do not, as a practice, change guidance at the end of the first quarter. It is our practice and has been for 3 years, to give you a full review of our expectation at the midpoint of the year. Suffice it to say that we're ahead of the operating plan upon which our guidance was based. We will work to consolidate our improvements and to continue to outperform. 
I'd like to now turn the call over to our CFO, Jason Aiken.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Phebe, and good morning. I want to start with a subject that we haven't talked about a lot in the past and that's foreign exchange rates. With our increasing international revenue base and the continued strengthening of the dollar, we're seeing
componenttext:
Thank you, Phebe, and good morning. I want to start with a subject that we haven't talked about a lot in the past and that's foreign exchange rates. With our increasing international revenue base and the continued strengthening of the dollar, we're seeing an impact in our reported results. Now to be clear, this doesn't involve anally economic gain or loss in any of our contracts. What I'm referring to is the translation of our international operating results from their local currencies to US dollars for reporting purposes.
Absent the movement of foreign currency translation rates, the growth in our revenues and earnings over the first quarter of 2014 would have been even more robust than the numbers you see. Specifically, our U.S. dollar reported revenue with an operating earnings in the quarter were reduced by approximately $120 million and $20 million, respectively compared with the exchange rates that prevailed in the first quarter of last year.
In addition, our backlog was reduced by approximately $450 million from year-end due to the same translation issue. Setting the FX impact aside, our Combat Systems backlog would have been essentially unchanged from year-end and our IS&T backlog would have been up slightly more than recorded.
Moving on to a couple of items on our income statement. Net interest is in the quarter was $21 million versus $22 million in the first quarter of 2014. During the quarter, we repaid $500 million of maturing fixed rate notes with proceeds from marketable securities on hand. At the end of the first quarter, our balance sheet reflects a net cash position, that's cash in excess of debt, of $1 billion, essentially unchanged from year end.
As Phebe mentioned earlier, our effective tax rate was a bit lower than we had forecast and a bit lower than analyst consensus of around 30.5%. The effective rate was 29% for the quarter versus 30.1% a year ago and the primary driver was some R&D tax credit claims that were settled during the quarter.
For the year, we're now anticipating an effective tax rate more in the ballpark of 29.5%. On the capital deployment front, you may recall that in the first quarter of last year, we repurchased a little over or 14 million shares, including about 11 million shares under an accelerated share repurchase program. Since the end of the first quarter of 2014, our diluted share count is down another 12.5 million shares, the result of almost 20 million additional shares we purchased in the past 4 quarters, and that includes approximately 4.7 million shares repurchased in the first quarter of this year. Altogether, was spent $826 million on share repurchases and dividends during the first quarter or 1.3x our free cash flow from operations.
Erin, that concludes my remarks. And I'll turn the time back over to you for the Q&A.

componenttext: Can you talk a little bit more about aerospace and the margin? I mean, you said that it was not sustainable but there were a couple of headwinds that you identified before about what might hold the margins back this year and so, I guess what of that did we not see in the quarter?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So as we talked about before, aerospace margins tend to be lumpy and estimating them with precision is kind of like putting a tail on a moving donkey. But that said, in the quarter, we had a very favorable service mix, high service levels with a good mix.
componenttext: So as we talked about before, aerospace margins tend to be lumpy and estimating them with precision is kind of like putting a tail on a moving donkey. But that said, in the quarter, we had a very favorable service mix, high service levels with a good mix. We recognized some tax credits, a supplier settlement in jet. So it was really more on the upside than really any headwinds. But at their risk of getting out ahead of our second quarter guidance, I've already noted you that our quarter 1 margins were above our expectations. And we're going to beat the guidance we gave you in January, I'm just not sure by what amounts. So I'd want to reserve those -- that commentary to the second quarter.

componenttext: It's actually Jon Ravivon for Jason. Phebe, just a notional question or a high-level question about your net cash position. What are you seeing in terms of deployment opportunities here and given your very attractive balance sheet?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we're in a net cash position at the moment, which Jason referred to, and we tend to solve for no net debt position, not trying to stay net cash. I think we gave you our guidance and our intentions on the January call. We will deploy, in the absence
componenttext: Well, we're in a net cash position at the moment, which Jason referred to, and we tend to solve for no net debt position, not trying to stay net cash. I think we gave you our guidance and our intentions on the January call. We will deploy, in the absence of any alternatives and if there aren't any, we will deploy all of our free cash flow and then some to share repurchases and dividends. And that strategy hasn't changed.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Carter Copeland from Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Carter Copeland from Barclays.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Phebe, Jason. Phebe, I wondered if you might elaborate a little bit on the big surprise in the top line in IS&T, obviously it's a shorter cycle business, quite a big revenue delta from what you had talked about in the prior quarter. I wonder if you can ju
componenttext: Phebe, Jason. Phebe, I wondered if you might elaborate a little bit on the big surprise in the top line in IS&T, obviously it's a shorter cycle business, quite a big revenue delta from what you had talked about in the prior quarter. I wonder if you can just give us some color on what it was that shifted or came in into the quarter? How should we think about, thinking of the impacts on the remainder of the year in terms of performance? And just any color you could give would be great.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we had an increased sales activity across both mission systems and our DDIT business. Our mission systems, it was driven in part by the lower cost structure that we anticipated as a result of combining AIS and C4 which made us more competitive. And tha
componenttext: So we had an increased sales activity across both mission systems and our DDIT business. Our mission systems, it was driven in part by the lower cost structure that we anticipated as a result of combining AIS and C4 which made us more competitive. And that tends to be a pretty quick turnaround business, so some of the orders quickly turned into sales. We had a good book-to-bill by the way, in that program or in that whole group, so that also positions us well for greater growth. And as we combined those 2 businesses, we grew some additional sales volume that comes in by the strength of going to market. On the IT business, say, one of most of they have been bidding on and they have power in the market space. And so look, I don't have a sense of where we're going to end up in that business in particular, given all the puts and takes by the end of the year, but we'll have a real good sense of that by the end of next quarter. But a solid, solid beat on revenues and we're very pleased.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Robert Stallard from Royal Bank of Canada.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Robert Stallard from Royal Bank of Canada.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Phebe, I was wondering if you could comment on the aerospace side in terms of the large cabin market and maybe give us a feel of what some of the different regions are doing, particularly looking overseas outside of the U.S.
componenttext: Phebe, I was wondering if you could comment on the aerospace side in terms of the large cabin market and maybe give us a feel of what some of the different regions are doing, particularly looking overseas outside of the U.S.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. The activity level, I would call it careful. In other words, we've got plenty of pipeline but slow to contract. Not unlike what we've seen in prior quarters. In short, North American and the Mid East are okay. Russia, Latin America and China are slo
componenttext: Sure. The activity level, I would call it careful. In other words, we've got plenty of pipeline but slow to contract. Not unlike what we've seen in prior quarters. In short, North American and the Mid East are okay. Russia, Latin America and China are slower at the moment. 6 50 and -- 6 50 ER demand is robust. So we're holding on our own and then some. I think, however, it's important to understand the theory of the case behind how we run this business, how we have historically and how we will continue to do so. The only decline we worry about is the decline in earnings. So accordingly, we always pool production down in the face of the weak quarters, we have no intention of doing so this year. Given our large 6 50 backlog, we can, to some degree, feather in more 6 50s to cover potential downfalls and of course, we already take cost out of that business. So I think, the way to think about Gulfstream for the next 2 years is, it's not necessarily at a strong revenue growth story. Growth will return when our new airplanes are under service. And this is pretty much in line with what we had anticipated and predictable in a business that continues to refresh its product line with clean sheet design airplanes. So I said it will be helpful to just give you a little sense of when we see changes in demand, how we act. But as I say, the first quarter was cautious, coming after a robust fourth quarter, and this is pretty much what we have seen in the first quarters for the last couple of years.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Myles Walton from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Myles Walton from Deutsche Bank.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Phebe, just maybe pick up on that last question. I think you said the next couple of years. And just on the G500 entering the service, it does seem like you're certainly ahead of where you could be. But without pulling forward the schedule on this confere
componenttext: Phebe, just maybe pick up on that last question. I think you said the next couple of years. And just on the G500 entering the service, it does seem like you're certainly ahead of where you could be. But without pulling forward the schedule on this conference call, green deliveries, would they be a source of good revenue growth for you in 2017 like the 6 50 was in 2011?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we'll start to recognize activity in 2017 in anticipation of entering the service in the first quarter of 2018. And it's really this, the next 2 years, and then it's a transition period. I think that's how you should think about it, and we anticip
componenttext: Yes. So we'll start to recognize activity in 2017 in anticipation of entering the service in the first quarter of 2018. And it's really this, the next 2 years, and then it's a transition period. I think that's how you should think about it, and we anticipated that as well. And you would expect that given that we've got our new airplanes coming on.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then just slide one in, which was on the inventory of used aircraft. You sold one in the quarter to date, the level of used inventory that you're holding rise fall or stay the same?
componenttext: And then just slide one in, which was on the inventory of used aircraft. You sold one in the quarter to date, the level of used inventory that you're holding rise fall or stay the same?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. It was the same.
componenttext: No. It was the same.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Doug Harned from Sanford Bernstein.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Doug Harned from Sanford Bernstein.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just continuing on the Gulfstream. When you look at the transition period and think about what the trajectory might be for 450 and 550 deliveries. Could you give us a sense on how you envision that going or sort of what the backlogs are right now for thos
componenttext: Just continuing on the Gulfstream. When you look at the transition period and think about what the trajectory might be for 450 and 550 deliveries. Could you give us a sense on how you envision that going or sort of what the backlogs are right now for those airplanes? And then when you think about it, as you said before, you have the ability to take 650 up given a lot of strong demand for that airplane. Do you see the potential to increase rates some on 650 within that next 2-year period?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we tend, we haven't given you the backlog and broken it off by aircraft model. But again, let's just talk about the theory of the case. When you're bringing in new aircraft, the trick is to feather in that production with the existing plane and so that
componenttext: So we tend, we haven't given you the backlog and broken it off by aircraft model. But again, let's just talk about the theory of the case. When you're bringing in new aircraft, the trick is to feather in that production with the existing plane and so that you have a nice smooth transition and that's what we're striving for and that's what we'll achieve. Again, there's no reason to think that, that isn't going to happen. The 650 has a quite a significant order book and in fact, the deliveries now, the next available airplanes have actually slipped to the fourth quarter of '17. So that healthy and long backlog, gives us some flexibility, nice flexibility, to feather in some more 650s to offset that transition period, the feathering in that we moved to the new airplanes. So it wouldn't be altogether a bad thing either to reduce the wait time on those 650s and the 650 ER, given the demand.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So you're seeing the potential to the demand out there to do some earlier 650 deliveries if you want to?
componenttext: So you're seeing the potential to the demand out there to do some earlier 650 deliveries if you want to?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. But I want to be prudent about it. It's not wise to eat through your backlog but to the extent that we can and want to, we will feather in some additional 650s. I think that makes sense.
componenttext: Sure. But I want to be prudent about it. It's not wise to eat through your backlog but to the extent that we can and want to, we will feather in some additional 650s. I think that makes sense.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Robert Spingarn from Credit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Robert Spingarn from Credit Suisse.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jason, I have one for you, if I could. It's on the free cash flow, which was really quite strong in the quarter. I think Phebe said last quarter that international advanced timing would put some pressure on free cash flow this year and it did in the quart
componenttext: Jason, I have one for you, if I could. It's on the free cash flow, which was really quite strong in the quarter. I think Phebe said last quarter that international advanced timing would put some pressure on free cash flow this year and it did in the quarter, but the collections looked very strong. Could you talk about working capital and how we should think about the cadence of free cash flow as we go forward through the year?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. We were, as you said, off to a strong start in the first quarter and to be quite frank, stronger than we even had expected. As we signaled coming into the year, we were expecting a bit of a softer cash flow outlook. And as you, I think, would expect
componenttext: Sure. We were, as you said, off to a strong start in the first quarter and to be quite frank, stronger than we even had expected. As we signaled coming into the year, we were expecting a bit of a softer cash flow outlook. And as you, I think, would expect in response to that, our business has turned toward sort of a war on operating capital and went after it hard in the first quarter. And really, that is the story you can see even despite a pretty big drawdown in the customer advances related to some of those international programs. Otherwise, excluding that, OWC was down in the quarter. So really strong performance out of the gate. I would caution you that we don't necessarily expect the first quarter to be reflective of the full year. We're still expecting a tough road ahead with some of the headwinds that we talked about. But really, our focus is all about that management at OWC and going after the collection, as well as the supply side.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Is there any particular timing we should think about where some of this strength reverses? I mean, I guess for the year, you'll do about 100% as you normally do, or a little better. But is there a weak quarter in here?
componenttext: Is there any particular timing we should think about where some of this strength reverses? I mean, I guess for the year, you'll do about 100% as you normally do, or a little better. But is there a weak quarter in here?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would suggest the second half is where the most pressure is on that front. So we'll be managing that through the balance of the year.
componenttext: I would suggest the second half is where the most pressure is on that front. So we'll be managing that through the balance of the year.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Cai Von Rumohr from Cowen and Cole.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Cai Von Rumohr from Cowen and Cole.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So aerospace. Maybe if you could kind of give us the numbers you give us on the lead times for each of the programs and a little color. You mentioned the supplier settlement. Maybe kind of, if you could quantify any one time, or is it bolstered through th
componenttext: So aerospace. Maybe if you could kind of give us the numbers you give us on the lead times for each of the programs and a little color. You mentioned the supplier settlement. Maybe kind of, if you could quantify any one time, or is it bolstered through the numbers in the first quarter at aerospace?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So as I noted, the 650 and 650 ER are out to the fourth quarter of '17. G550, 450, about 12 months where they have been. G280 and 150, G280 at the end of this year, 150 first quarter next year. So pretty much consistent with what we've been reporting
componenttext: Yes. So as I noted, the 650 and 650 ER are out to the fourth quarter of '17. G550, 450, about 12 months where they have been. G280 and 150, G280 at the end of this year, 150 first quarter next year. So pretty much consistent with what we've been reporting all along. As I tried to explain earlier, we had a number of moving targets in the Gulfstream margin, provided considerable margin improvement, service mix, we took in some tax credits. We did have that supplier settlement, I'm not going to give any particular numbers on any of that. And debt performed well. So a couple of those are one timers but I'm not going to quantify them for you. I don't think that's productive. We're very particular with respect to our suppliers. We're very proprietary about talking about our relationship with our suppliers.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can you quantify the total of all of those without giving any of the granularity?
componenttext: Can you quantify the total of all of those without giving any of the granularity?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, we've led you to about 18% for the year. I didn't give you any quarter by quarter. As I explained to you before, we get real lumpiness in aerospace margins, which we've talked about. So I'm not prepared to change the year guidance but you can
componenttext: Yes. I mean, we've led you to about 18% for the year. I didn't give you any quarter by quarter. As I explained to you before, we get real lumpiness in aerospace margins, which we've talked about. So I'm not prepared to change the year guidance but you can back in to some of that. But as I said, this is -- Gulfstream has an awful lot of moving parts in both debt and aviation. So we have seen, for the last couple of years, a lot of lumpiness. We're not going to see that 20% repeated going forward. As I explained to you, we're going to outperform on just -- my guidance adjustment don't know by how much yet. And I have a pretty good sense of that about halfway through the year.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
