componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Peter Arment from Sterne Agee.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Phebe, maybe just to stay on aerospace. You mentioned Jet Aviation continues to be a positive contributor. Could you give us a little more color on what you're seeing there? And then also related to that, are using any kind of a slowdown in utilization ra
componenttext: Phebe, maybe just to stay on aerospace. You mentioned Jet Aviation continues to be a positive contributor. Could you give us a little more color on what you're seeing there? And then also related to that, are using any kind of a slowdown in utilization rates in the large cabin tied to kind of the energy market, just given these so often in the way we've seen in the last 6 months?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: We've continued to build that business. They've been a positive contributor on both cash and earnings for about the last 2.5, 3 years. We've seen no change in demand as a result of -- or no decrease in demand as the result of changing oil prices. In fact,
componenttext: We've continued to build that business. They've been a positive contributor on both cash and earnings for about the last 2.5, 3 years. We've seen no change in demand as a result of -- or no decrease in demand as the result of changing oil prices. In fact, we're seeing higher demand. Backlog, the pipeline is good and we're adding to the backlog. So expect that business is increasingly well positioned.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Howard Rubel from Jefferies.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Howard Rubel from Jefferies.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't want to leave Marine alone here. I mean -- I mean, you did spend a little time there so I figured, it's probably worn off a little on you. But there's a couple of things that stand out. One was the backlog growth. Second was, you got into ELA J po
componenttext: I don't want to leave Marine alone here. I mean -- I mean, you did spend a little time there so I figured, it's probably worn off a little on you. But there's a couple of things that stand out. One was the backlog growth. Second was, you got into ELA J post shakedown availability which sort of sets you up from producing interesting things. And it looks like NASSCO did pretty well and the commercial is hard to do. So maybe you could talk a little about some of the variances. And is this a sustainable rate you're seeing in Marine, or was there some deliveries or some other material items that sort of tweaked the numbers?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think what you can expect is, Marine is, will replicate its behavior in the past, which is pretty steady heading. There was no one particular element that drove margin performance. With respect to the sales growth, that's coming from a couple of places.
componenttext: I think what you can expect is, Marine is, will replicate its behavior in the past, which is pretty steady heading. There was no one particular element that drove margin performance. With respect to the sales growth, that's coming from a couple of places. We have increased sales at NASSCO on commercial work. And remember, we're moving to, into the Block IV, which brings with it higher revenue. And also, we're seeing increased revenue on the engineering and design for the Ohio replacement. So all of those are long-term programs that will continue to carry revenue and predictive earnings with them.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And just to follow up for a moment. How is it that, I mean, what have you done there to make sure, for example, that NASSCO, that there's some opportunities to continue the business? Because I know that's always challenging from time to time. And then als
componenttext: And just to follow up for a moment. How is it that, I mean, what have you done there to make sure, for example, that NASSCO, that there's some opportunities to continue the business? Because I know that's always challenging from time to time. And then also, making sure that Ohio replacements stays on schedule.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So with respect to NASSCO, they've got a nice backlog, commercial and government maybe, new construction. And recall, repair continues to grow for NASSCO. We have a by-coastal presence. Back when I was the EVP of the Marine group, we bought a couple
componenttext: Yes. So with respect to NASSCO, they've got a nice backlog, commercial and government maybe, new construction. And recall, repair continues to grow for NASSCO. We have a by-coastal presence. Back when I was the EVP of the Marine group, we bought a couple of East Coast repair yards that have done beautifully. And so we've really increased our firing power in repair and we are performing very nicely. So the repair business is moving to and the Navy is moving to, from cost plus contracts to fixed price and repair in selected instances and that's a real upside potential for us. We're very pleased with that. So the repair business is robust. NASSCO is performing very well and I think they keep their cost base low with continuous improvement and that is a highly functioning shipyard. So I like where they stand. They're competitive in the commercial market space. And then of course, Electric Boat is as well continues to drive down its cost structure. And we'll see over time, increased margin improvement as we get further into Block IV and continue our improvement. Every time we start a new block, we have some compression in margins that we've given back some of the goodness of the prior block to the Navy. But over the last decade plus, reduced our cost structure and continue to improve margins. So we're very, very well positioned.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. I was asking if you can dig a little bit more in the growth in Combat. It sounded like you did come through ahead of your expectations. Is that solid in the U.K. program starting to ramp? And does that actually accelerate from here? And then
componenttext: Okay, great. I was asking if you can dig a little bit more in the growth in Combat. It sounded like you did come through ahead of your expectations. Is that solid in the U.K. program starting to ramp? And does that actually accelerate from here? And then a separate question. Praxis reported that you pulled out a couple of programs in the quarter. Competitions, TX and Man Pack, if you could just touch on those as well.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So you would expect, with the prodigious increase in backlog that we experienced last year that we're beginning to -- we would begin to see that backlog turned into sales and revenue increase and that's what you see in the next group across the port
componenttext: Sure. So you would expect, with the prodigious increase in backlog that we experienced last year that we're beginning to -- we would begin to see that backlog turned into sales and revenue increase and that's what you see in the next group across the portfolio. On our Canadian, Middle East contract, we are finishing up our design efforts in the initial variants and we're going to be begin production later this year. The deliveries in '16. On the U.K. program, we're working some small quantities of preproduction but again, that will begin to ramp up. And there is, the Army is increasing its capitalization in their wheeled and tracked vehicles. So all of that is upside and that we recognize some of that. So look, that backlog will start flowing into sales and the key there is to perform on that backlog. So let me talk to that, you asked the second question, which is kind of interesting. That we have pulled out some competitions. Let me give you a sort of a theory of the case here. We are not going to compete for programs that respond to RFPs where we do not believe that we can get a fair and sufficient return. Chasing revenues that don't have good earnings that are going to help us or our shareholders. So this really has more to do with the discipline on how we run our company rather than the response on any particular program. We're just not going to -- we're just not going to compete in programs where we think that we can can't make a fair return and a good return.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ron Epstein from Bank of America.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ron Epstein from Bank of America.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015

componenttext: I just wanted to touch base quickly on, if you could remind us what you're thinking about capital allocation? Particularly if there's some new properties flowing in the market. I mean, there might be opportunity for you guys to do some vertical integration. Just, what are you thinking about M&A and vis-a-vis cash return to shareholders?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015

componenttext: Yes. Ron, I'm not thinking about M&A, because I'm not seeing anything. So it's, again, not on my radar screen. And our intent, with respect to capital deployment, remains the same for this year. We're going to return some capital to our shareholders and share repurchases and dividend. So I think that's pretty much consistent with what we've been doing and what we've been saying. Okay?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015

componenttext: Could you give us a quick update on how things are proceeding with the G600 program, the development there and the developments on the G500 program?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we're proceeding well on both. The near-term G500, we had our first flight this quarter and we're on track with no particular surprises. In the G600, we're starting to build the first prototype. So all is well. We're on track and in line with what our
componenttext: So we're proceeding well on both. The near-term G500, we had our first flight this quarter and we're on track with no particular surprises. In the G600, we're starting to build the first prototype. So all is well. We're on track and in line with what our expectations are.

componenttext: Okay. That's great. Just curious, is there any chance that the 500 can happen sooner, just going to happen sooner?

componenttext: Phebe, I wanted to follow-up on your question in your response to David's question earlier. And also, the comment on TX specifically, or just more broadly about how you're not going to invest -- and not going to bid on programs that don't provide fair or decent returns to our shareholders. Was there something about the comment about TX specifically, but was there something about the way that particular program was structured that didn't appeal to you? Or was it more a comment more broadly about, sort of the level of investment it would require from you guys, given that's not true in your core wheelhouse to participate in that program with the sort of use return. The latter? It was the latter?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: [indiscernible] fit in a nutshell. It's not in our core. We had -- we have been thinking about participating and the Air Force was interested in off-the-shelf trainer. But once the requirement started to change, there's just no way that becomes an attract
componenttext: [indiscernible] fit in a nutshell. It's not in our core. We had -- we have been thinking about participating and the Air Force was interested in off-the-shelf trainer. But once the requirement started to change, there's just no way that becomes an attractive program for us. And so I think the appropriate response and good discipline with would be to require that we just politely bow out.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015

componenttext: Phebe, I just wanted to go further on capital deployment. I like what I'm hearing about stay away from M&A, frankly. componenttext: So, look, we came out of the gate strong on cash, but as I -- what I told the Street in January as the way to think about 2015 cash is that we're going to have a lighter cash year than we typically do have and I'm not prepared to change that. componenttext: We're seeing a little bit more activity on the budget side, but it really is our win rate has improved. As we continue to take cost out of our business, we become more competitive. headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Quarter 1 2015 General Dynamics Earnings Conference Call. My name is Emma, and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded for replay purposes.A
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Quarter 1 2015 General Dynamics Earnings Conference Call. My name is Emma, and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded for replay purposes.
And now I'd like to turn the call over to Erin Linnihan, Staff Vice President of Investor Relations. Please proceed, ma'am.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Emma, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to the General Dynamics' First Quarter Conference Call.As always, any forward-looking statements made today represent our estimates regarding the company's outlook. These estimates are subject to some
componenttext:
Thank you, Emma, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to the General Dynamics' First Quarter Conference Call.
As always, any forward-looking statements made today represent our estimates regarding the company's outlook. These estimates are subject to some risks and uncertainties. Additional information regarding these factors is contained in the company's 10-K and 10-Q filings.
With that, I would like to turn the call over to our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Phebe Novakovic.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Erin. Earlier today, we reported first quarter earnings from continuing operations of $2.14 per fully diluted share on revenue of $7.8 billion, operating earnings of slightly over $1 billion and net earnings of $716 million. We beat analyst consen
componenttext:
Thanks, Erin. Earlier today, we reported first quarter earnings from continuing operations of $2.14 per fully diluted share on revenue of $7.8 billion, operating earnings of slightly over $1 billion and net earnings of $716 million. We beat analyst consensus by $0.20 and we're well ahead of analysts' expectations on revenue as well. We were also better than our previous guidance and our own expectations.
I should point out that we enjoyed an effective tax rate of 29% as opposed to consensus of around 30.5%. This accounted for approximately $0.05 of the outperformance. Jason Aiken will more fully discuss the tax rate a little later.
I should further note that the diluted weighted average share count was 334.7 million for the quarter compared to consensus of approximately 332 million. So none of the outperformance comes from a lower-than-expected share count.
I have asked Jason to give you a little more insight into our share repurchase activity when I conclude my remarks.
All in all, this is a truly strong quarter from an operating perspective as evidenced by the operating margin of 13.2% and a return on revenue of 9.2%.
It was a good quarter from a cash perspective as well. We had $745 million net cash provided by operating activity. After capital expenditures of $98 million, we had $647 million of free cash flow from operations, about 90% of net income.
The general comparisons quarter-over-quarter are pretty compelling compared to the first quarter 2014. Revenue was up $519 million or 7.1%. Total defense revenue was up 10.1%, pretty remarkable.
Our operating earnings was slightly more than $1 billion, up 17.5% over the prior year's quarter, leading to 120 basis point improvement in margins. This very strong operating leverage is an important part of the story. Net earnings were up more than operating earnings, primarily due to the previously mentioned lower tax rate.
Finally, EPS was up 25.1% over the year-ago quarter as a result of better operating earnings, lower tax rate and lower share count.
Let me provide some commentary and a little perspective around the results of our operating segments. 
First, Aerospace. Sales are down by $17 million compared to Q1 2014, less than 1%; and down $132 million sequentially against a strong fourth quarter. On the other hand, earnings outpaced the year-ago quarter by $27 million, about 6.7% on 140 basis point expansion in operating margin.
Operating earnings were also up $19 million sequentially. The 20.4% operating margin for the group represents the high with both companies contributing. A word of caution here. We are out of the gate fast but this pace is not sustainable from a margin perspective. 
Orders were not overly strong in the quarter but need to be viewed in the context of a very robust fourth quarter 2014. It was a quarter where the sales pipeline was replenished and strengthened, part of a normal cycle after a strong order quarter. This is consistent with what we saw in the first quarter of 2014, following a strong fourth quarter of 2013. We're off to a very good start in the Aerospace group. 
Marine Systems. Revenue of $1.94 billion was up $342 million or 21.4% compared to the year-ago quarter and down $97 million sequentially, as one would expect, against the fourth quarter 2014. Operating earnings were up $22 million or 13.3% against the year-ago quarter and down $5 million sequentially. We had a particularly good performance at Electric Boat and NASSCO.
Some of the more striking comparisons are found at Combat Systems. Compared to the first quarter of 2014, sales were up $105 million or 8.3% and earnings were up $65 million or 46.8% on a 400 basis point improvement in operating margins.
Recall that the results in the first quarter of 2014 were impacted by a $29 million restructuring charge at European Land Systems as a result of reductions in the Austrian operations, which were consolidated into Spain and Switzerland. If we disregard that charge, margins would have been 13.4% on a pro forma basis. Even on that basis, the improvement in this year's operating margin is a significant 160 basis point.
Sequentially, revenue was down $251 million and operating earnings were down $67 million, as anticipated in the business that always has a very strong fourth quarter, largely related to contract delivery. All up [ph], continued strong performance at Combat Systems. It's been a long time since we've been able to report an increase in revenue in this group.
IS&T, the big upside surprise incurred in this group. You might recall that our guidance was to expect a revenue decline of 5.5% year-over-year. Well, that certainly did not happen in the first quarter. Revenue in the quarter was up $89 million or 3.9% against the year-ago quarter and off only $98 million against the powerful fourth quarter 2014. Operating earnings of $217 million in the quarter were $34 million more than the year-ago quarter, up 18.6% on 120 basis point improvement in margin.
On a sequential basis, operating earnings were up $5 million on a 60 basis point improvement in margins. Once again, nice operating leverage. The 9.2% operating margins were the best that this group has achieved in a while and is very encouraging. The trend is in the right direction.
So we're off to a very good start to the year, nicely ahead of our expectations. We do not, as a practice, change guidance at the end of the first quarter. It is our practice and has been for 3 years to give you a full review of our expectation at the midpoint of the year. Suffice it to say that we're ahead of the operating plan upon which our guidance was based, we will work to consolidate our improvements and to continue to outperform.
I'd like to now turn the call over to our CFO, Jason Aiken.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Phebe, and good morning. I want to start with a subject that we haven't talked about a lot in the past, and that's foreign exchange rates. With our increasing international revenue base and the continued strengthening of the dollar, we're seein
componenttext:
Thank you, Phebe, and good morning. I want to start with a subject that we haven't talked about a lot in the past, and that's foreign exchange rates. With our increasing international revenue base and the continued strengthening of the dollar, we're seeing an impact in our reported results. Now to be clear, this doesn't involve any economic gain or loss in any of our contracts. What I'm referring to is the translation of our international operating results from their local currencies to U.S. dollars for reporting purposes.
Absent the movement of foreign currency translation rates, the growth in our revenues and earnings over the first quarter of 2014 would have been even more robust than the numbers you see. Specifically, our U.S. dollar reported revenue and operating earnings in the quarter were reduced by approximately $120 million and $20 million, respectively, compared with the exchange rates that prevailed in the first quarter of last year.
In addition, our backlog was reduced by approximately $450 million from year-end due to the same translation issue. Setting the FX impact aside, our Combat Systems backlog would have been essentially unchanged from year-end and our IS&T backlog would have been up slightly more than reported.
Moving on to a couple of items on our income statement. Net interest expense in the quarter was $21 million versus $22 million in the first quarter of 2014. During the quarter, we repaid $500 million of maturing fixed rate notes with proceeds from marketable securities on hand. At the end of the first quarter, our balance sheet reflects a net cash position, that's cash in excess of debt, of $1 billion, essentially unchanged from year-end.
As Phebe mentioned earlier, our effective tax rate was a bit lower than we had forecast and a bit lower than analyst consensus of around 30.5%. The effective rate was 29% for the quarter versus 30.1% a year ago, and the primary driver was some R&D tax credit claims that were settled during the quarter.
For the year, we're now anticipating an effective tax rate more in the ballpark of 29.5%. On the capital deployment front, you may recall that in the first quarter of last year, we repurchased a little over 14 million shares, including about 11 million shares under an accelerated share repurchase program. Since the end of the first quarter of 2014, our diluted share count is down another 12.5 million shares, the result of almost 20 million additional shares repurchased in the past 4 quarters. And that includes approximately 4.7 million shares repurchased in the first quarter of this year.
Altogether, we spent $826 million on share repurchases and dividends during the first quarter or 1.3x our free cash flow from operations.
Erin, that concludes my remarks, and I'll turn the time back over to you for the Q&A.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Could you talk a little bit more about Aerospace and the margin? I mean, you said that it was not sustainable but there were a couple of headwinds that you had identified before about what why -- what might hold the margins back this year. And so I guess,
componenttext: Could you talk a little bit more about Aerospace and the margin? I mean, you said that it was not sustainable but there were a couple of headwinds that you had identified before about what why -- what might hold the margins back this year. And so I guess, what of that did we not see in the quarter?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So as we talked about before, Aerospace margins tend to be lumpy, and estimating them with precision is kind of like putting a tail on a moving donkey. But that said, in the quarter, we had a very favorable service mix, high service levels with a good mix
componenttext: So as we talked about before, Aerospace margins tend to be lumpy, and estimating them with precision is kind of like putting a tail on a moving donkey. But that said, in the quarter, we had a very favorable service mix, high service levels with a good mix. We recognized some tax credits, a supplier settlement in jet. So it was really more on the upside than really any headwinds. But at the risk of getting out ahead of our second quarter guidance, I've already noted you that our quarter 1 margins were above our expectations. And we're going to beat the guidance I gave you in January. I'm just not sure by what amount. So I want to reserve those -- that commentary to the second quarter.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jason Gursky from Citi.

componenttext: It's actually Jon Raviv on for Jason. Phebe, just a notional question or a high-level question about your net cash position. What are you seeing in terms of deployment opportunities here given your very attractive balance sheet?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we're in a net cash position at the moment, which Jason referred to, and we tend to settle for no net debt position, not trying to stay net cash. I think we gave you a guidance and our intentions in the January call. We will deploy, in the absence o
componenttext: Well, we're in a net cash position at the moment, which Jason referred to, and we tend to settle for no net debt position, not trying to stay net cash. I think we gave you a guidance and our intentions in the January call. We will deploy, in the absence of any alternatives and there aren't any, we will deploy all of our free cash flow and then some to share repurchases and dividends. And that strategy hasn't changed.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from Carter Copeland from Barclays.
componenttext: Your next question comes from Carter Copeland from Barclays.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Phebe, I wondered if you might elaborate a little bit on the big surprise in the top line in IS&T. Obviously, it's your shorter-cycle business. Quite a big revenue delta from what you had talked about in the prior quarter. I wonder if you could just give
componenttext: Phebe, I wondered if you might elaborate a little bit on the big surprise in the top line in IS&T. Obviously, it's your shorter-cycle business. Quite a big revenue delta from what you had talked about in the prior quarter. I wonder if you could just give us some color on what it was that shifted or came in into the quarter. How should we think about thinking of the impacts on the remainder of the year in terms of performance? And just any color you could give would be great.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we had an increased sales activity across both Mission Systems and our GDIT business. On Mission Systems, it was driven in part by the lower cost structure that we anticipated as a result of combining AIS and C4, which made us more competitive. And tha
componenttext: So we had an increased sales activity across both Mission Systems and our GDIT business. On Mission Systems, it was driven in part by the lower cost structure that we anticipated as a result of combining AIS and C4, which made us more competitive. And that tends to be a pretty quick turnaround business, so some of the orders quickly turned into sales. We had a good book-to-bill, by the way, in that program -- or in that whole group, so that also positions us well for greater growth. And as we combined those 2 businesses, we're seeing some additional sales volume that comes in by the strength of going to market. On the IT business, they have won most of what they have been bidding on and they are a power in their marketplace. And so look, I don't have a sense of where we're going to end up in that business in particular given all the puts and takes by the end of the year, but we'll have a real good sense of that by the end of next quarter. But a solid, solid beat on revenues, and we're very pleased.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Robert Stallard from Royal Bank of Canada.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Robert Stallard from Royal Bank of Canada.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Phebe, I was wondering if you could comment on the Aerospace side in terms of the large-cabin market and maybe give us a feel of what some of the different regions are doing, particularly looking overseas, outside the U.S.
componenttext: Phebe, I was wondering if you could comment on the Aerospace side in terms of the large-cabin market and maybe give us a feel of what some of the different regions are doing, particularly looking overseas, outside the U.S.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. The activity level, I would call it careful. In other words, we've got plenty of pipeline but slow to contract, not unlike what we've seen in prior quarters. In short, North America and the Mid East are okay. Russia, Latin America and China are slow
componenttext: Sure. The activity level, I would call it careful. In other words, we've got plenty of pipeline but slow to contract, not unlike what we've seen in prior quarters. In short, North America and the Mid East are okay. Russia, Latin America and China are slower at the moment. 650 and 650ER demand is robust. So we're holding our own and then some. I think, however, it's important to understand the theory of the case behind how we run this business, how we have historically and how we will continue to do so. The only decline we worry about is the decline in earnings. So accordingly, we always pull production down in the face of weak orders, we have no intention of doing so this year. Given our large 650 backlog, we can, to some degree, feather in more 650s to cover potential downfalls. And of course, we always take cost out of that business. So I think the way to think about Gulfstream for the next 2 years is not necessarily at a strong revenue growth story. Growth will return when the new airplanes enter into service. And this is pretty much in line with what we had anticipated and predictable in a business that continues to refresh its product line with clean-sheet design airplanes. So I thought it will be helpful to just give you a little sense of when we see changes in demand how we act. But as I say, the first quarter was cautious, coming after a robust fourth quarter. And this is pretty much what we have seen in the first quarters for the last couple of years.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Myles Walton from Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Myles Walton from Deutsche Bank.

componenttext: Phebe, just maybe pick up on that last question. I think you said the next couple of years. And just on the G500 entering the service, it does seem like you're certainly ahead of where you could be. But without pulling forward the schedule on this conference call, green deliveries, will they be a source of good revenue growth for you in 2017 like the 650 was in 2011?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we'll start to recognize activity in 2017 in anticipation of entering the service in the first quarter of 2018. And it's really the next 2 years and then it's a transition period. I think that's how you should think about it, and we anticipated th
componenttext: Yes. So we'll start to recognize activity in 2017 in anticipation of entering the service in the first quarter of 2018. And it's really the next 2 years and then it's a transition period. I think that's how you should think about it, and we anticipated that as well. And you would expect that given that we've got our new airplanes coming on.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Doug Harned from Sanford Bernstein.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just continuing on with Gulfstream. When you look at the transition period and think about what the trajectory might be for 450 and 550 deliveries. Could you give us a sense on how you envision that going or sort of what the backlogs are right now for tho
componenttext: Just continuing on with Gulfstream. When you look at the transition period and think about what the trajectory might be for 450 and 550 deliveries. Could you give us a sense on how you envision that going or sort of what the backlogs are right now for those airplanes? And then when you think about it, as you said before, you have the ability to take 650 up given a lot of strong demand for that airplane. Do you see the potential to increase rates some on 650 within that next 2-year period?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we tend -- we haven't given you the backlog and broken it up by aircraft model. But again, let's just talk about the theory of the case. When you're bringing in new aircraft, the trick is to feather in that production with the existing plane and so tha
componenttext: So we tend -- we haven't given you the backlog and broken it up by aircraft model. But again, let's just talk about the theory of the case. When you're bringing in new aircraft, the trick is to feather in that production with the existing plane and so that you have a nice, smooth transition. And that's what we're striving for and that's what we'll achieve. I have -- again, there's no reason to think that, that isn't going to happen. The 650 has quite a significant order book. And in fact, the deliveries now -- the next available airplanes have actually slipped to the fourth quarter of '17. So that healthy and long backlog gives us some flexibility -- nice flexibility to feather in some more 650s to offset that transition period, the feathering in as we move to the new airplanes. So it wouldn't be altogether a bad thing either to reduce the wait time on those 650s and the 650ER given demand.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So you are seeing the potential to the demand out there to do some earlier 650 deliveries if you want to?
componenttext: So you are seeing the potential to the demand out there to do some earlier 650 deliveries if you want to?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. But we're going to be prudent about it. It's not wise to eat through your backlog. But to the extent that we can and want to, we will feather in some additional 650s. So I think that makes sense.
componenttext: Sure. But we're going to be prudent about it. It's not wise to eat through your backlog. But to the extent that we can and want to, we will feather in some additional 650s. So I think that makes sense.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Robert Spingarn from Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Robert Spingarn from Crédit Suisse.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jason, I've got one for you, if I could. It's on the free cash flow, which was really quite strong in the quarter. I think Phebe said last quarter that international advanced timing would put some pressure on free cash flow this year. And it did in the qu
componenttext: Jason, I've got one for you, if I could. It's on the free cash flow, which was really quite strong in the quarter. I think Phebe said last quarter that international advanced timing would put some pressure on free cash flow this year. And it did in the quarter, but the collections looked very strong. Could you talk about working capital and how we should think about the cadence of free cash flow as we go forward through the year?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. We were, as you said, off to a strong start in the first quarter and, to be quite frank, stronger than even we had expected. As we signaled coming into the year, we were expecting a bit of a softer cash flow outlook. And as you, I think, would expec
componenttext: Sure. We were, as you said, off to a strong start in the first quarter and, to be quite frank, stronger than even we had expected. As we signaled coming into the year, we were expecting a bit of a softer cash flow outlook. And as you, I think, would expect in response to that, our businesses turned toward sort of a war on operating working capital and went after it hard in the first quarter. And really, that is the story, you could see even despite a pretty big drawdown in the customer advances related with some of those international programs. Otherwise -- excluding that, OWC was down in the quarter, so really strong performance out of the gate. I would caution you that we don't necessarily expect the first quarter to be reflective of the full year. We're still expecting a tough road ahead with some of the headwinds that we talked about. But really, our focus is all about that management of OWC and going after the collection as well as the supply side.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Is there any particular timing we should think about where some of the strength reverses? I mean, I guess, for the year, you'll do about 100% as you normally do or a little better. But is there a weak quarter in here?
componenttext: Is there any particular timing we should think about where some of the strength reverses? I mean, I guess, for the year, you'll do about 100% as you normally do or a little better. But is there a weak quarter in here?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: We're -- I would suggest the second half is where the most pressure is on that front. So we'll be managing that through the balance of the year.
componenttext: We're -- I would suggest the second half is where the most pressure is on that front. So we'll be managing that through the balance of the year.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015

componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Cai Von Rumohr from Cowen and Co.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Aerospace, maybe if you could kind of give us the numbers you gave us on the lead times for each of the programs and a little color. You mentioned the supplier settlement. Maybe kind of if you could quantify any onetimers that bolstered the numbers in
componenttext: So Aerospace, maybe if you could kind of give us the numbers you gave us on the lead times for each of the programs and a little color. You mentioned the supplier settlement. Maybe kind of if you could quantify any onetimers that bolstered the numbers in the first quarter at Aerospace.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So as I noted, the 650 and 650ER are out to the fourth quarter '17; G550, 450, about 12 months where they have been. G280 and 150, G280 at the end of this year, 150 first quarter next year. So pretty much consistent with what we've been reporting all
componenttext: Yes. So as I noted, the 650 and 650ER are out to the fourth quarter '17; G550, 450, about 12 months where they have been. G280 and 150, G280 at the end of this year, 150 first quarter next year. So pretty much consistent with what we've been reporting all along. As I tried to explain earlier, we had a number of moving targets in the Gulfstream margin, provided considerable margin improvement, service mix. We took in some tax credits. We did have that supplier settlement. I'm not going to give you any particular numbers on any of that -- these. And jet performed well. So a couple of those are onetimers, but I'm not going to quantify them for you. I don't think that's productive. We're very particular with respect to our suppliers. We're very proprietary about talking about our relationship with our suppliers.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can you quantify the total of all of those without giving any of the granularity?
componenttext: Can you quantify the total of all of those without giving any of the granularity?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. I mean, we're -- we've led you to about 18% for the year. I didn't give you any quarter-by-quarter. As I explained to you before, we get real lumpiness in Aerospace margins, which we've talked about. So I'm not prepared to change the year guidance bu
componenttext: Yes. I mean, we're -- we've led you to about 18% for the year. I didn't give you any quarter-by-quarter. As I explained to you before, we get real lumpiness in Aerospace margins, which we've talked about. So I'm not prepared to change the year guidance but you can back in just some of that. But as I said, this is -- Gulfstream has an awful lot of moving parts and so does Jet Aviation. So we have seen for the last couple of years a lot of lumpiness. We're not going to see that 20% repeated going forward. And as I explained to you, we're going to outperform just my guidance. I just don't know by how much yet. And I'll have a pretty good sense of that halfway through the year.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015

componenttext: Phebe, maybe just to stay on Aerospace. You mentioned Jet Aviation continues to be a positive contributor. Can you give us a little more color on what you're seeing there? And then also related to that, are you seeing any kind of slowdown in utilization rates in the large cabin tied to kind of the energy market, just given the sell-off in oil we've seen in the last 6 months?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: We continue to build that business. They've been a positive contributor on both cash and earnings for about the last 2.5, 3 years. We've seen no change in demand as a result of -- no decrease in demand as a result of the changing oil prices. In fact, we'r
componenttext: We continue to build that business. They've been a positive contributor on both cash and earnings for about the last 2.5, 3 years. We've seen no change in demand as a result of -- no decrease in demand as a result of the changing oil prices. In fact, we're seeing higher demand. Backlog -- the pipeline is good and we're adding to the backlog. So in fact, that business is increasingly well positioned.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Howard Rubel from Jefferies.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Howard Rubel from Jefferies.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't want to leave Marine alone here. I mean, you did spend a little time there. So I figured it's probably worn off a little on you. And there's a couple of things that stand out. One was the backlog growth. Second was you got an ALJ [ph]  post-shaked
componenttext: I don't want to leave Marine alone here. I mean, you did spend a little time there. So I figured it's probably worn off a little on you. And there's a couple of things that stand out. One was the backlog growth. Second was you got an ALJ [ph]  post-shakedown availability, which sort of sets you up to introduce some interesting things. And it looks like NASSCO did pretty well in a world where commercial is hard to do. So maybe you could talk a little about some of the variances. And is this a sustainable rate you're seeing in Marine? Or was there some deliveries or some other material items that sort of tweaked the numbers?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think what you can expect is Marine is -- will replicate its behavior in the past, which is pretty steady Eddie. There was no one particular element that drove margin performance. With respect to the sales growth, that's coming from a couple of places.
componenttext: I think what you can expect is Marine is -- will replicate its behavior in the past, which is pretty steady Eddie. There was no one particular element that drove margin performance. With respect to the sales growth, that's coming from a couple of places. We have increased sales at NASSCO on commercial work. And remember, we're moving to -- into the Block IV, which brings with it higher revenue. And also, we're seeing increased revenue on the engineering and design for the Ohio replacement. So all of those are long-term programs that will continue to carry revenue and predictable earnings with them.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And just to follow up for a moment. How is it that -- I mean, what have you done there to make sure, for example, that NASSCO, that there's some opportunity to continue the business because I know that's always challenging from time to time and then also
componenttext: And just to follow up for a moment. How is it that -- I mean, what have you done there to make sure, for example, that NASSCO, that there's some opportunity to continue the business because I know that's always challenging from time to time and then also making sure that Ohio replacement stays on schedule?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So with respect to NASSCO, they've got a nice backlog, commercial and government, maybe new construction. And recall, repair continues to grow for NASSCO. We have a bicoastal presence. Back in -- when I was EVP of the Marine group, we bought a couple
componenttext: Yes. So with respect to NASSCO, they've got a nice backlog, commercial and government, maybe new construction. And recall, repair continues to grow for NASSCO. We have a bicoastal presence. Back in -- when I was EVP of the Marine group, we bought a couple of East Coast repair yards that have done beautifully. And so we've really increased our firing power in repair and we're performing very nicely. The repair business is moving to and the Navy is moving to -- from cost-plus contracts to fixed price in repair in selected instances, and that's a real upside potential for us. We're very pleased with that. So the repair business is robust. NASSCO is performing very well. They keep their cost bases low through continuous improvement, and that is a highly functioning shipyard. So I like where they stand. They're competitive in the commercial market space. And of course, Electric Boat as well continues to drive down its cost structure. And we'll see over time increased margin improvement as we get further into Block IV and continue our continuous improvement. Every time we start a new block, we have some compression in margins that we've given back some of the goodness of the prior block to the Navy. But we, over the last decade-plus, reduced our cost structure and continue to improve margins. So they're very, very well positioned.

componenttext: Okay, great. I was asking if you could dig a little bit more into the growth at Combat. It sounded like it did come through ahead of your expectations. Is that Saudi and the U.K. program starting to ramp? And does that actually accelerate from here? And then a separate question. Presses reported that you pulled out of a couple of programs in the quarter, competition's T-X and manpack. If you could just touch on those as well.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So look, we would expect with the prodigious increase in backlog that we experienced last year that we're beginning to -- we would begin to see that backlog turn into sales and revenue increase, and that's what you're seeing in that group across the
componenttext: Sure. So look, we would expect with the prodigious increase in backlog that we experienced last year that we're beginning to -- we would begin to see that backlog turn into sales and revenue increase, and that's what you're seeing in that group across the portfolio. On our Canadian, Middle East contract, we are finishing up our design efforts and the initial variance and we're going to begin production later this year. The delivery is in '16. On the U.K. program, we're working some small quantities of preproduction. But again, that will begin to ramp up. And there is -- the Army is increasing its capitalization in their wheeled and tracked vehicles. So all of that is upside and that we'd recognize some of that. So look, that backlog will start flowing into sales. And the key there is to perform on that backlog. So let me talk to you, you asked the second question, it's kind of interesting, that we have pulled out of some competitions. Let me give you a sort of a theory of the case here. We are not going to compete for programs that respond to RFPs where we do not believe that we can get a fair and sufficient return. Chasing revenues that don't have good earnings doesn't help us or our shareholders one lick. So this really has more to do with the discipline on how we run our company rather than the response on any particular program. We're just not going to compete in programs where we think that we can't make a fair return and a good return.

componenttext: So we're proceeding well on both. The near-term G500, we had our first flight this quarter and we're on track with no particular surprises. In the G600, we're starting to build the first prototype. And so all is well. We're on track and in line with what our expectation is.

componenttext: You got it. Exactly, that's it in a nutshell. It's not in our core. We had been thinking about participating on -- the Air Force was interested in an off-the-shelf trainer. But once the requirement started to change, there's just no way that becomes an attractive program for us. And so I think the appropriate response and good discipline would required that we just politely bow out.

componenttext: So look, my -- we came out of the gate strong on cash. componenttext: We're seeing a little bit more activity on the budget side. But it really is our win rate has improved. As we continue to take cost out of our business, we become more competitive. headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Quarter 1 2015 General Dynamics Earnings Conference Call. My name is Emma, and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded for replay purposes.A
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the Quarter 1 2015 General Dynamics Earnings Conference Call. My name is Emma, and I will be your operator for today. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this call is being recorded for replay purposes.
And now I'd like to turn the call over to Erin Linnihan, Staff Vice President of Investor Relations. Please proceed, ma'am.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Emma, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to the General Dynamics' First Quarter Conference Call.As always, any forward-looking statements made today represent our estimates regarding the company's outlook. These estimates are subject to some
componenttext:
Thank you, Emma, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to the General Dynamics' First Quarter Conference Call.
As always, any forward-looking statements made today represent our estimates regarding the company's outlook. These estimates are subject to some risk and uncertainties. Additional information regarding these factors is contained in the company's 10-K and 10-Q filings.
With that, I would like to turn the call over to our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Phebe Novakovic.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Erin. Earlier today, we reported first quarter earnings from continuing operations of $2.14 per fully diluted share on revenue of $7.8 billion, operating earnings of slightly over $1 billion and net earnings of $716 million. We beat analyst consen
componenttext:
Thanks, Erin. Earlier today, we reported first quarter earnings from continuing operations of $2.14 per fully diluted share on revenue of $7.8 billion, operating earnings of slightly over $1 billion and net earnings of $716 million. We beat analyst consensus by $0.20, and we're well ahead of analysts' expectations on revenue as well. We were also better than our previous guidance and our own expectations.
I should point out that we enjoyed an effective tax rate of 29% as opposed to consensus of around 30.5%. This accounted for approximately $0.05 of the outperformance. Jason Aiken will more fully discuss the tax rate a little later.
I should further note that the diluted weighted average share count was 334.7 million for the quarter compared to consensus of approximately 332 million. So none of the outperformance comes from a lower-than-expected share count.
I have asked Jason to give you a little more insight into our share repurchase activity when I conclude my remarks.
All in all, this is a truly strong quarter from an operating perspective as evidenced by the operating margin of 13.2% and a return on revenue of 9.2%.
It was a good quarter from a cash perspective as well. We had $745 million net cash provided by operating activity. After capital expenditures of $98 million, we had $647 million of free cash flow from operations, about 90% of net income.
The general comparisons quarter-over-quarter are pretty compelling. Compared to the first quarter 2014, revenue was up $519 million or 7.1%. Total defense revenue was up 10.1%; pretty remarkable.
Our operating earnings was slightly more than $1 billion, up 17.5% over the prior year's quarter leading to 120 basis point improvement in margins. This very strong operating leverage is an important part of the story. Net earnings were up more than operating earnings primarily due to the previously mentioned lower tax rate.
Finally, EPS was up 25.1% over the year-ago quarter as a result of better operating earnings, lower tax rate and lower share count.
Let me provide some commentary and a little perspective around the results of our operating segments. 
First, Aerospace. Sales were down by $17 million compared to Q1 2014, less than 1%; and down $132 million sequentially against a strong fourth quarter. On the other hand, earnings outpaced the year-ago quarter by $27 million, about 6.7% on 140 basis point expansion in operating margin.
Operating earnings were also up $19 million sequentially. The 20.4% operating margin for the group represents a high with both companies contributing. A word of caution here. We are out of the gate fast, but this pace is not sustainable from a margin perspective. 
Orders were not overly strong in the quarter but need to be viewed in the context of a very robust fourth quarter 2014. It was a quarter where the sales pipeline was replenished and strengthened, part of a normal cycle after a strong-order quarter. This is consistent with what we saw in the first quarter of 2014 following the strong fourth quarter of 2013. We're off to a very good start in the Aerospace group. 
Marine Systems. Revenue of $1.94 billion was up $342 million or 21.4% compared to the year-ago quarter and down $97 million sequentially as one would expect against the fourth quarter 2014. Operating earnings were up $22 million or 13.3% against the year-ago quarter and down $5 million sequentially. We had particularly good performance at Electric Boat and NASSCO.
Some of the more striking comparisons are found at Combat Systems. Compared to the first quarter of 2014, sales were up $105 million or 8.3% and earnings were up $65 million or 46.8% on a 400 basis point improvement in operating margins.
Recall that the results in the first quarter of 2014 were impacted by a $29 million restructuring charge at European Land Systems as a result of reductions in the Austrian operations, which were consolidated into Spain and Switzerland. If we disregard that charge, margins would have been 13.4% on a pro forma basis. Even on that basis, the improvement in this year's operating margin is a significant 160 basis point.
Sequentially, revenue was down $251 million and operating earnings were down $67 million as anticipated in a business that always has a very strong fourth quarter largely related to contract delivery. All up [ph], continued strong performance at Combat Systems. It's been a long time since we've been able to report an increase in revenue in this group.
IS&T. The big upside surprise occurred in this group. You might recall that our guidance was to expect a revenue decline of 5.5% year-over-year. Well, that certainly did not happen in the first quarter. Revenue in the quarter was up $89 million or 3.9% against the year-ago quarter and off only $98 million against the powerful fourth quarter 2014. Operating earnings of $217 million in the quarter were $34 million more than the year-ago quarter, up 18.6% on 120 basis point improvement in margin.
On a sequential basis, operating earnings were up $5 million on a 60 basis point improvement in margins. Once again, nice operating leverage. The 9.2% operating margins were the best that this group has achieved in a while and is very encouraging. The trend is in the right direction.
So we're off to a very good start to the year, nicely ahead of our expectations. We do not, as a practice, change guidance at the end of the first quarter. It is our practice and has been for 3 years to give you a full review of our expectation at the midpoint of the year. Suffice it to say that we're ahead of the operating plan upon which our guidance was based. We will work to consolidate our improvements and to continue to outperform.
I'd like to now turn the call over to our CFO, Jason Aiken.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Phebe, and good morning. I want to start with a subject that we haven't talked about a lot in the past, and that's foreign exchange rates. With our increasing international revenue base and the continued strengthening of the dollar, we're seein
componenttext:
Thank you, Phebe, and good morning. I want to start with a subject that we haven't talked about a lot in the past, and that's foreign exchange rates. With our increasing international revenue base and the continued strengthening of the dollar, we're seeing an impact in our reported results. Now to be clear, this doesn't involve any economic gain or loss in any of our contracts. What I'm referring to is the translation of our international operating results from their local currencies to U.S. dollars for reporting purposes.
Absent the movement of foreign currency translation rates, the growth in our revenues and earnings over the first quarter of 2014 would have been even more robust than the numbers you see. Specifically, our U.S. dollar reported revenues and operating earnings in the quarter were reduced by approximately $120 million and $20 million, respectively, compared with the exchange rates that prevailed in the first quarter of last year.
In addition, our backlog was reduced by approximately $450 million from year end due to the same translation issue. Setting the FX impact aside, our Combat Systems backlog would have been essentially unchanged from year end, and our IS&T backlog would have been up slightly more than reported.
Moving on to a couple of items on our income statement. Net interest expense in the quarter was $21 million versus $22 million in the first quarter of 2014. During the quarter, we repaid $500 million of maturing fixed rate notes with proceeds from marketable securities on hand. At the end of the first quarter, our balance sheet reflects a net cash position, that's cash in excess of debt, of $1 billion, essentially unchanged from year end.
As Phebe mentioned earlier, our effective tax rate was a bit lower than we had forecast and a bit lower than analyst consensus of around 30.5%. The effective rate was 29% for the quarter versus 30.1% a year ago, and the primary driver was some R&D tax credit claims that were settled during the quarter.
For the year, we're now anticipating an effective tax rate more in the ballpark of 29.5%. On the capital deployment front, you may recall that in the first quarter of last year, we repurchased a little over 14 million shares, including about 11 million shares under an accelerated share repurchase program. Since the end of the first quarter of 2014, our diluted share count is down another 12.5 million shares, the result of almost 20 million additional shares repurchased in the past 4 quarters. And that includes approximately 4.7 million shares repurchased in the first quarter of this year.
All together, we spent $826 million on share repurchases and dividends during the first quarter or 1.3x our free cash flow from operations.
Erin, that concludes my remarks, and I'll turn the time back over to you for the Q&A.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015

componenttext: Could you talk a little bit more about Aerospace and the margin? I mean, you said that it was not sustainable, but there were a couple of headwinds that you had identified before about why -- what might hold the margins back this year. And so I guess, what of that did we not see in the quarter?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So as we talked about before, Aerospace margins tend to be lumpy, and estimating them with precision is kind of like putting a tail on a moving donkey. But that said, in the quarter, we had a very favorable service mix, high service levels with a good mix
componenttext: So as we talked about before, Aerospace margins tend to be lumpy, and estimating them with precision is kind of like putting a tail on a moving donkey. But that said, in the quarter, we had a very favorable service mix, high service levels with a good mix. We recognized some tax credits, a supplier settlement in jet. So it was really more on the upside than really any headwinds. But at the risk of getting out ahead of our second quarter guidance, I've already noted to you that our quarter 1 margins were above our expectations. And we're going to beat the guidance I gave you in January. I'm just not sure by what amount. So I want to reserve those -- that commentary to the second quarter.

componenttext: It's actually Jon Raviv on for Jason. Phebe, just in a notional question or a high-level question about your net cash position. What are you seeing in terms of deployment opportunities here given your very attractive balance sheet?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we're in a net cash position at the moment, which Jason referred to, and we tend to settle for no net debt position, not trying to stay net cashed. I think we gave you a guidance and our intentions in the January call. We will deploy -- in the absen
componenttext: Well, we're in a net cash position at the moment, which Jason referred to, and we tend to settle for no net debt position, not trying to stay net cashed. I think we gave you a guidance and our intentions in the January call. We will deploy -- in the absence of any alternatives and there aren't any, we will deploy all of our free cash flow and then some to share repurchases and dividends. And that strategy hasn't changed.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Phebe, I wondered if you might elaborate a little bit on the big surprise in the top line in IS&T. Obviously, it's your shorter-cycle business. Quite a big revenue delta from what you had talked about in the prior quarter. I wonder if you could just give
componenttext: Phebe, I wondered if you might elaborate a little bit on the big surprise in the top line in IS&T. Obviously, it's your shorter-cycle business. Quite a big revenue delta from what you had talked about in the prior quarter. I wonder if you could just give us some color on what it was that shifted or came in into the quarter. How should we think about thinking of the impacts on the remainder of the year in terms of performance? And just any color you could give would be great.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we had an increased sales activity across both Mission Systems and our GDIT business. On Mission Systems, it was driven in part by the lower cost structure that we anticipated as a result of combining AIS and C4, which made us more competitive. And tha
componenttext: So we had an increased sales activity across both Mission Systems and our GDIT business. On Mission Systems, it was driven in part by the lower cost structure that we anticipated as a result of combining AIS and C4, which made us more competitive. And that tends to be a pretty quick turnaround business, so some of the orders quickly turned into sales. We added good book-to-bill, by the way, in that program -- or in that whole group, so that also positions us well for greater growth. And as we combined those 2 businesses, we're seeing some additional sales volume that comes in by the strength of going to market. On the IT business, they have won most of what they have been bidding on, and they are a power in their market space. And so look, I don't have a sense of where we're going to end up in that business in particular given all the puts and takes by the end of the year, but we'll have a real good sense of that by the end of next quarter. But a solid, solid bead on revenues, and we're very pleased.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And your next question comes from the line of Robert Stallard from Royal Bank of Canada.
componenttext: And your next question comes from the line of Robert Stallard from Royal Bank of Canada.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Phebe, I was wondering if you could comment on the Aerospace side in terms of the large-cabin market and maybe give us a feel of what some of the different regions are doing, particularly looking overseas, outside the U.S.
componenttext: Phebe, I was wondering if you could comment on the Aerospace side in terms of the large-cabin market and maybe give us a feel of what some of the different regions are doing, particularly looking overseas, outside the U.S.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. The activity level, I would call it careful. In other words, we've got plenty of pipeline but slow to contract, not unlike what we've seen in prior quarters. In short, North America and the Mideast are okay. Russia, Latin America and China are slowe
componenttext: Sure. The activity level, I would call it careful. In other words, we've got plenty of pipeline but slow to contract, not unlike what we've seen in prior quarters. In short, North America and the Mideast are okay. Russia, Latin America and China are slower at the moment. 650 and 650ER demand is robust. So we're holding our own and then some. I think, however, it's important to understand the theory of the case behind how we run this business, how we have historically and how we will continue to do so. The only decline we worry about is a decline in earnings. So accordingly, we always pull production down in the face of weak orders. We have no intention of doing so this year. Given our large 650 backlog, we can to some degree feather in more 650s to cover potential downfalls. And of course, we always take cost out of that business. So I think the way to think about Gulfstream for the next 2 years is not necessarily as a strong revenue growth story. Growth will return when the new airplanes enter into service. And this is pretty much in line with what we had anticipated and predictable in a business that continues to refresh its product line with clean-sheet design airplanes. So I thought it would be helpful to just give you a little sense of when we see changes in demand how we act. But as I say, the first quarter was cautious coming after a robust fourth quarter. And this is pretty much what we have seen in the first quarters for the last couple years.

componenttext: Phebe, just maybe pick up on that last question. I think you said the next couple of years. componenttext: Yes. So we'll start to recognize activity in 2017 in anticipation of entering into service in the first quarter of 2018. And it's really this the next 2 years, and it's a transition period. I think that's how you should think about it, and we anticipated that as well. And you would expect that given that we've got new airplanes coming on.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just continuing on with Gulfstream. When you look at the transition period and think about what the trajectory might be for 450 and 550 deliveries. Could you give us a sense on how you envision that going or sort of what the backlogs are right now for tho
componenttext: Just continuing on with Gulfstream. When you look at the transition period and think about what the trajectory might be for 450 and 550 deliveries. Could you give us a sense on how you envision that going or sort of what the backlogs are right now for those airplanes? And then when you think about it, as you said before, you have the ability to take 650 up given a lot of strong demand for that airplane. Do you see the potential to increase rates some on 650 within that next 2-year period?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we tend -- we haven't given you the backlog and broken it up by aircraft model. But again, let's just talk about the theory of the case. When you're bringing in new aircraft, the trick is to feather in that production with the existing plane and so tha
componenttext: So we tend -- we haven't given you the backlog and broken it up by aircraft model. But again, let's just talk about the theory of the case. When you're bringing in new aircraft, the trick is to feather in that production with the existing plane and so that you have a nice, smooth transition. And that's what we're striving for and that's what we will achieve. I have -- again, there's no reason to think that, that isn't going to happen. The 650 has a -- quite a significant order book. And in fact, the deliveries now -- the next available airplanes have actually slipped to the fourth quarter of '17. So that healthy and long backlog gives us some flexibility -- nice flexibility to feather in some more 650s to offset that transition period, the feathering in as we move to the new airplanes. So it wouldn't be all together a bad thing either to reduce the wait time on those 650s and the 650ER given demand.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So you are seeing the potential to the demand out there to do some earlier 650 deliveries if you want to.
componenttext: So you are seeing the potential to the demand out there to do some earlier 650 deliveries if you want to.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. But we're going to be prudent about it. It's not wise to eat through your backlog. But to the extent that we can and want to, we will feather in some additional 650s. So I think that makes sense.
componenttext: Sure. But we're going to be prudent about it. It's not wise to eat through your backlog. But to the extent that we can and want to, we will feather in some additional 650s. So I think that makes sense.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Jason, I've got one for you if I could. It's on the free cash flow, which was really quite strong in the quarter. I think Phebe said last quarter that international advanced timing would put some pressure on free cash flow this year. And it did in the qua
componenttext: Jason, I've got one for you if I could. It's on the free cash flow, which was really quite strong in the quarter. I think Phebe said last quarter that international advanced timing would put some pressure on free cash flow this year. And it did in the quarter, but collections looked very strong. Could you talk about working capital and how we should think about the cadence of free cash flow as we go forward through the year?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. We were, as you said, off to a strong start in the first quarter and, to be quite frank, stronger than even we had expected. As we signaled coming into the year, we were expecting a bit of a softer cash flow outlook. And as you, I think, would expec
componenttext: Sure. We were, as you said, off to a strong start in the first quarter and, to be quite frank, stronger than even we had expected. As we signaled coming into the year, we were expecting a bit of a softer cash flow outlook. And as you, I think, would expect in response to that, our businesses turned toward sort of a war on operating working capital and went after it hard in the first quarter. And really, that is the story. You could see even despite a pretty big drawdown in the customer advances related with some of those international programs. Otherwise -- excluding that, OWC was down in the quarter, so really strong performance out of the gate. I would caution you that we don't necessarily expect the first quarter to be reflective of the full year. We're still expecting a tough road ahead with some of the headwinds that we talked about. But really, our focus is all about that management at OWC and going after the collection as well as the supply side.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Is there any particular timing we should think about where some of this strength reverses? I mean, I guess, for the year, you'll do about 100% as you normally do or a little better. But is there a weak quarter in here?
componenttext: Is there any particular timing we should think about where some of this strength reverses? I mean, I guess, for the year, you'll do about 100% as you normally do or a little better. But is there a weak quarter in here?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q1 2015 Earnings Call, Apr 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: We're -- I would suggest the second half is where the most pressure is on that front. So we'll be managing that through the balance of the year.
componenttext: We're -- I would suggest the second half is where the most pressure is on that front. So we'll be managing that through the balance of the year.
