componenttext: [Operator Instructions] And your first question comes from the line of Ronald Epstein of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just maybe a quick question on the biz jet market. The way you characterized it, it sounds great. Just -- but other suppliers have said maybe not so. So my sense is are you guys picking up share? I mean, you have a primary competitor who is kind of wounde
componenttext: Just maybe a quick question on the biz jet market. The way you characterized it, it sounds great. Just -- but other suppliers have said maybe not so. So my sense is are you guys picking up share? I mean, you have a primary competitor who is kind of wounded out there right now. And I'm just curious if you're picking up share in the large jet market.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. There's been an awful lot of discussion about reported weakness in that large-cabin market, but not from us. And it's not actually schematic that the factors that are impacting others are impacting us. We really don't think about share. The way we co
componenttext: Yes. There's been an awful lot of discussion about reported weakness in that large-cabin market, but not from us. And it's not actually schematic that the factors that are impacting others are impacting us. We really don't think about share. The way we conduct our business is that we look at our order book which was robust and our pipeline, which remained strong. So I'm not in a position to comment what others are seeing, but we are continuing to see interest across all of our product lines.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay, great. And then if I can just a quick follow-on, something that you didn't talk about too much on your prepared remarks is how's it going on the Ohio class program now? And the ship business? And if you can give us an update on that, and how the out
componenttext: Okay, great. And then if I can just a quick follow-on, something that you didn't talk about too much on your prepared remarks is how's it going on the Ohio class program now? And the ship business? And if you can give us an update on that, and how the outlook for that looks?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Ohio, engineering and Virginia construction are really the 2 main drivers of increased revenue, which is not what you asked but it gives us a certain context, and let me give you some color. We're in the middle of the Ohio replacement design developmen
componenttext: So Ohio, engineering and Virginia construction are really the 2 main drivers of increased revenue, which is not what you asked but it gives us a certain context, and let me give you some color. We're in the middle of the Ohio replacement design development program, and it's progressing on schedule. We're the prime and we are working on all the ship arrangement systems, components, development, missile system compartment in order to support the start of the lead ship, which is in 2021. So we're going very, very well by all indicators in our engineering and design efforts.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of David Strauss of UBS.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of David Strauss of UBS.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Phebe, during the quarter, I guess last couple of quarters, we've seen some of your competitors make some moves in terms of M&A, Lockheed with Sikorsky and then Raytheon with Websense. Can you just talk about how you view M&A today? And how you're thinkin
componenttext: Phebe, during the quarter, I guess last couple of quarters, we've seen some of your competitors make some moves in terms of M&A, Lockheed with Sikorsky and then Raytheon with Websense. Can you just talk about how you view M&A today? And how you're thinking about capital deployment overall?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I see M&A today the way I have been seeing it. There is nothing that we are looking at now. Our capital deployment strategy is consistent with what we've been talking to you about. In the absence of accretive and good acquisition candidates in our spac
componenttext: So I see M&A today the way I have been seeing it. There is nothing that we are looking at now. Our capital deployment strategy is consistent with what we've been talking to you about. In the absence of accretive and good acquisition candidates in our space, we're going to continue to return cash in the form of dividends and share repurchases.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And as a quick follow-up, the Gulfstream order activity in the quarter, could you give us any color in terms of by product line? What you saw maybe on the 650? And what the order activity looks like on the new products, the 500 and 600?
componenttext: And as a quick follow-up, the Gulfstream order activity in the quarter, could you give us any color in terms of by product line? What you saw maybe on the 650? And what the order activity looks like on the new products, the 500 and 600?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So we're not going to dissect for you the demand by product, and by airplane, but let's just -- suffice it to say that we had good demand across our entire portfolio, and that means our entire portfolio. And when we look at the pipeline, the interest that
componenttext: So we're not going to dissect for you the demand by product, and by airplane, but let's just -- suffice it to say that we had good demand across our entire portfolio, and that means our entire portfolio. And when we look at the pipeline, the interest that we see in the pipeline likewise translates to demand signal across our portfolio.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Robert Stallard of Royal Bank of Canada.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Robert Stallard of Royal Bank of Canada.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Phebe, just a point of clarification. Did you cut your Aerospace revenue forecast by $350 million versus your previous guidance? And if so, what has changed there?
componenttext: Phebe, just a point of clarification. Did you cut your Aerospace revenue forecast by $350 million versus your previous guidance? And if so, what has changed there?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Look, we reduced I think between $250 million and $300 million, and there are an awful lot of moving parts in this business that as we get halfway through the year, we get some additional clarity. It's really nothing more than across the whole line of our
componenttext: Look, we reduced I think between $250 million and $300 million, and there are an awful lot of moving parts in this business that as we get halfway through the year, we get some additional clarity. It's really nothing more than across the whole line of our products and services. This is really some moving around among quarters, between fiscal years. But the business is still growing. I don't particularly see the reduction of the increase in estimate from 8% to 6%, is particularly dispositive for any market factors. So simply the management of the business.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Is there particular models that have come up more than you originally anticipated? I know you don't like to give a lot of detail on this, but is this generally what's happened?
componenttext: Is there particular models that have come up more than you originally anticipated? I know you don't like to give a lot of detail on this, but is this generally what's happened?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: No, no. It's just as we look -- we've got a whole series of moving parts in that business, including building additional airplanes for the test program, mix in our service business and then the mix in any one particular quarter over the fiscal years of de
componenttext: No, no. It's just as we look -- we've got a whole series of moving parts in that business, including building additional airplanes for the test program, mix in our service business and then the mix in any one particular quarter over the fiscal years of deliveries in large cabin and medium cabin. So we are likely to see some medium cabin, about 3 or 4 of them move into next year, but that's largely a question of preference on the part of the customers. So there's nothing material here. It's simply an update as we get halfway through the year to give you just some more clarity of what we see.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Sam Pearlstein of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Sam Pearlstein of Wells Fargo.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to go back on the Marine side. I mean, normally a fairly predictable business to go from 2% growth to 6% growth seems unusual, so I'm assuming it's Ohio class. And then wouldn't that cause kind of a negative margin shift rather than a 10 basis po
componenttext: I wanted to go back on the Marine side. I mean, normally a fairly predictable business to go from 2% growth to 6% growth seems unusual, so I'm assuming it's Ohio class. And then wouldn't that cause kind of a negative margin shift rather than a 10 basis point increase? And I don't know if you can highlight. You said they have a lot of work to do in the second half on the margin front. What needs to happen there?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so it's a couple of things that are driving -- a couple of programs that are driving our revenue. One is increased Virginia-class construction. Ohio engineering revenue has increased quite a bit over the last year, both of those. And then the commerc
componenttext: Yes, so it's a couple of things that are driving -- a couple of programs that are driving our revenue. One is increased Virginia-class construction. Ohio engineering revenue has increased quite a bit over the last year, both of those. And then the commercial ship construction at NASSCO is increasing, is our backlog of the Ecotankers and our construction cycles. So those are the 3 factors that are increasing our outlook for the year. On margins, we just have some work to do across the portfolio. If you think about what the history has been on blocks of submarines. Block IV is still in its early stages, and so as we continue our reengineering efforts, we expect to realize some cost savings, which will improve performance and margins on Block IV. That's going to be a longer-term proposition. Because we historically, throughout that program, have recognized higher margins as we progress further into the construction. So we see some long-term margin expansion opportunities there, and we're seeing some -- we're seeing very good performance at NASSCO on their Ecotanker construction and on the MLP for the Navy, and then we've got some margin compression at Bath Iron Works that we need to continue to work through on our DDG 1000 program. Not unexpected, but often typical of a new class of ship, particularly one that is this powerful and transformational warship as DDG 1000 is. So we've got a little ways to go on that, and we're working with our Navy customer, and our vendors and their vendors to get that first ship into sea trials, so more to come.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Robert Spingarn of Crédit Suisse.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Robert Spingarn of Crédit Suisse.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Phebe, I wonder if we could turn to IS&T or back to IS&T for a minute, talk about what's driving the strength there? How you look at that business over time? And particularly, on the margins, how much of this is just -- is volume driven versus cost reduct
componenttext: Phebe, I wonder if we could turn to IS&T or back to IS&T for a minute, talk about what's driving the strength there? How you look at that business over time? And particularly, on the margins, how much of this is just -- is volume driven versus cost reduction as we go forward?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: There's an interesting correlation between volume increases and cost reduction. As you may recall, we have integrated 2 of our previous standalone businesses in IS&T and created Mission Systems and they had a particularly strong quarter across the board.
componenttext: There's an interesting correlation between volume increases and cost reduction. As you may recall, we have integrated 2 of our previous standalone businesses in IS&T and created Mission Systems and they had a particularly strong quarter across the board. So -- and I'm continuing to see good continuing strength in those areas, and I'm particularly pleased with their margin improvement, which is driving the higher earnings and frankly allows them to increase their win rate. Their cost-cutting efforts have been exemplary and there's more to come in that business. On our service business, it's steady year-over-year. And sequentially, they just need to work their margins hard, which is always their challenge in their highly competitive business. But all in all, IS&T is doing extremely well, and I think will continue to do well. And again, our win rate is better because our performance operationally is good, and our costs are coming down and are increasingly -- pace of which is increasing in cost cutting. So very impressive.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. And then just as a second question or a follow-up, maybe for Jason. On the cash flow conversion for the year, how are you thinking about that relative to before, especially now that the forecast is a bit higher from a performance standpoint?
componenttext: Yes. And then just as a second question or a follow-up, maybe for Jason. On the cash flow conversion for the year, how are you thinking about that relative to before, especially now that the forecast is a bit higher from a performance standpoint?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I think our expectations for the full year are consistent with what we've said right from the beginning a weaker than -- or softer than typical year. Our priority is always to pull cash forward. So we had a pretty decent performance in the first half. I t
componenttext: I think our expectations for the full year are consistent with what we've said right from the beginning a weaker than -- or softer than typical year. Our priority is always to pull cash forward. So we had a pretty decent performance in the first half. I think we had close to 80% conversion rate free cash flow to net income, but we had predicted before and are still looking at a softer second half as we profile a lot of the supplier payments associated with the advances that we got on some large contracts last year and the year before, flowing out in the balance of the year. So I think our expectations are essentially consistent with what we started in the year.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Myles Walton of Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Myles Walton of Deutsche Bank.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the one question I have for you was on the backlog in bookings at Gulfstream, in particular. Some of the manufacturers have seen the fleet buyers kind of come back and place orders. How much of the strength here is fleet buying? It sounds like it's not
componenttext: So the one question I have for you was on the backlog in bookings at Gulfstream, in particular. Some of the manufacturers have seen the fleet buyers kind of come back and place orders. How much of the strength here is fleet buying? It sounds like it's not, but I just want to confirm that. And also as it relates to your search for upward bias on the G650 rates, how comfortable are you with where the supply chain can take us?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So let's first define our terms. When we say fleet, what we mean is Fortune 500 companies coming back in and replenishing their entire fleet. And so not surprisingly, the preponderance of our backlog is in public and private companies and high net worth i
componenttext: So let's first define our terms. When we say fleet, what we mean is Fortune 500 companies coming back in and replenishing their entire fleet. And so not surprisingly, the preponderance of our backlog is in public and private companies and high net worth individuals. They comprise a majority of our backlog. I don't track our -- what you can call fractional owners, fractional buyers, but it's not significant, and I don't really worry about it too much. It's a very steady backlog, and we look at it. We know these people in the backlog, they've been here before and a lot of strengths and consistency.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: And then the supply chain for the 650?
componenttext: And then the supply chain for the 650?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so the supply chain for the 650, we are thinking about feathering in the 650 over additional 1s and 2 units over time, and the supply chain can easily manage that. We've been in discussions with them, and we're not talking about massive changes in th
componenttext: Yes, so the supply chain for the 650, we are thinking about feathering in the 650 over additional 1s and 2 units over time, and the supply chain can easily manage that. We've been in discussions with them, and we're not talking about massive changes in the production rate, but simply onesies and twosies, to smooth the transition period.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Doug Harned of Bernstein.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Doug Harned of Bernstein.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to follow-up on the 650 question, because as you've talked about potentially feathering in some earlier, what are you looking for as a trigger to make a decision to bring some 650s forward?
componenttext: I just wanted to follow-up on the 650 question, because as you've talked about potentially feathering in some earlier, what are you looking for as a trigger to make a decision to bring some 650s forward?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, when we look at our plan for the next couple of years and get some clarity around that, then we'll have the ability to ramp up. Again, not in large order of magnitude numbers but in ones that are easily manageable. So that will be largely our planni
componenttext: Well, when we look at our plan for the next couple of years and get some clarity around that, then we'll have the ability to ramp up. Again, not in large order of magnitude numbers but in ones that are easily manageable. So that will be largely our planning process that we do in the fall, and that will set the guidance that we will give you in the fourth quarter, first quarter of next year. There's no catalytic trigger, it's more internal planning.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: But when you think about this also in terms of margins, you'd said recently that the margins had not, on the 650, hadn't quite reached the level of the 550. When you look at -- how do you look at the margin trajectory now? And how does that tie into poten
componenttext: But when you think about this also in terms of margins, you'd said recently that the margins had not, on the 650, hadn't quite reached the level of the 550. When you look at -- how do you look at the margin trajectory now? And how does that tie into potential changes in rate?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the margin potential on the 650, I think we've got another 1 year to 18 months before it eclipses the 550. So I don't really think about bringing forward 650s to boost our margins. I'm thinking about bringing them forward to just move the entire busine
componenttext: So the margin potential on the 650, I think we've got another 1 year to 18 months before it eclipses the 550. So I don't really think about bringing forward 650s to boost our margins. I'm thinking about bringing them forward to just move the entire business, and so there are less perturbations as we go through our transition. But we're -- we've talked about this quite a bit. The margin performance on the 650, we haven't seen how good we can get there.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jason Gursky of Citi.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jason Gursky of Citi.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: It's actually Jon Raviv on for Jason. A question about Jet Aviation and the planned reduction at Basel later in the year, curious what's driving that? And how -- what you're doing to manage that? And to what extent that's driving the lower Aerospace sales
componenttext: It's actually Jon Raviv on for Jason. A question about Jet Aviation and the planned reduction at Basel later in the year, curious what's driving that? And how -- what you're doing to manage that? And to what extent that's driving the lower Aerospace sales outlook?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: That is a -- think about it this way. We added significantly to the backlog of Jet Aviation with single aisle and double aisle airplane completions in the first half. So we need to --  and we're in the process of doing the engineering work, so that we can
componenttext: That is a -- think about it this way. We added significantly to the backlog of Jet Aviation with single aisle and double aisle airplane completions in the first half. So we need to --  and we're in the process of doing the engineering work, so that we can induct these airplanes in the first quarter and second quarter of next year into the production cycle. So this is a -- when you have an inflow of order -- orders, and the completions on these airplanes require a fair amount of high-level engineering on the front end, engineering and design. So to integrate that, get that engineering design done, done, so we're ready to move into full rate production at a very efficient rate is I think judicious and was part of our plan all along. You need to do that in order to produce these things that are at a effective margin level and profitability. The Jet Aviation has some impact in the second quarter, if you will imagine, particularly given their double-digit contribution in the last few quarters.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of George Shapiro of Shapiro Research.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of George Shapiro of Shapiro Research.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Phebe, if I look at the Aerospace margin for the 6 months, it's 19.9%. And I would venture for the second quarter if I took out maybe $75 million or $100 million of probably 0 margin preowned sales, it would have been north of 20%. So what gets the margin
componenttext: Phebe, if I look at the Aerospace margin for the 6 months, it's 19.9%. And I would venture for the second quarter if I took out maybe $75 million or $100 million of probably 0 margin preowned sales, it would have been north of 20%. So what gets the margin down to 17.5% or so on average in the second half, or even 17% to get you to average only 18.5% for the year?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: George, for years, I've enjoyed your complex questions that are built on a series of assumptions. Let me try to simplify this in the way that we think about it. In the first half, we had a number of factors that contributed to higher margins. One was a fa
componenttext: George, for years, I've enjoyed your complex questions that are built on a series of assumptions. Let me try to simplify this in the way that we think about it. In the first half, we had a number of factors that contributed to higher margins. One was a fairly significant settlement that we had with a supplier. The second was some R&D tax credit. And then going forward, we're going to increase our R&D spend. Jet Aviation is going to have significantly lower in the half earnings and margin rate as we just discussed. And we've got a whole lot of mix shift that's issued in the service and when airplanes come into green delivery and final delivery. So it's an awful lot of moving parts. That help you?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, that helps some. And just also is it fair to say that revenues in preowned were 75 to 100 in this quarter, with probably 0 profit contribution?
componenttext: Yes, that helps some. And just also is it fair to say that revenues in preowned were 75 to 100 in this quarter, with probably 0 profit contribution?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: I don't really follow that, but that would feel about right. But look, the way to think about this, there is nothing happening in the second half of this year that should cause concern to the underlying structure of the business. It's simply a matter of d
componenttext: I don't really follow that, but that would feel about right. But look, the way to think about this, there is nothing happening in the second half of this year that should cause concern to the underlying structure of the business. It's simply a matter of different moving parts, it's a mix in the business, the R&D spend as we build more airplanes into the test program. So I think the way to think about this realistically is there is no underlying systemic issue here. It's just the normal puts and takes.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Cai Von Rumohr of Cowen and Company.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Cai Von Rumohr of Cowen and Company.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So could you give us a little more sense of the low quarterly in Aerospace in the third and the fourth quarter? And maybe, you have 2 quarters here, where you've beaten kind of the cautious guidance you've given us. And maybe the specific variances in the
componenttext: So could you give us a little more sense of the low quarterly in Aerospace in the third and the fourth quarter? And maybe, you have 2 quarters here, where you've beaten kind of the cautious guidance you've given us. And maybe the specific variances in the second quarter as to why in that quarter, you were so much better than you kind of indicated you might be?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, we had a wholesome mix on the service side. Service revenue is up and the mix was very wholesome, and Jet Aviation had a terrific quarter. So all in all, that helped drive our, what you might think of as outperformance. But look I think we've tried
componenttext: Well, we had a wholesome mix on the service side. Service revenue is up and the mix was very wholesome, and Jet Aviation had a terrific quarter. So all in all, that helped drive our, what you might think of as outperformance. But look I think we've tried to talk over the last few years about the futility of attempting to get and predict precise quarterly margin rates at this business that has so many different moving parts. Different products, different service, mix is an issue, it's about Jet Aviation in there. So it's -- we're comfortable that we're directionally correct. Do we have, with exact precision, what third quarter margins are going to be? They're going to be less, and they're going to be significantly less and a little bit better in the fourth quarter. So I think that's reflecting -- that flows down into the overall guidance that we gave you in terms of progression of EPS, which is a lighter third quarter compared to second and our fourth quarter that looks a lot like the second quarter and Gulfstream contributes to that.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: That's very helpful. And then on the order front, you talked about the strength in the U.S. and Fortune 500 companies. You didn't mention emerging markets. I guess there's been some talk of weakness in China, Russia, Latin America. Could you talk about th
componenttext: That's very helpful. And then on the order front, you talked about the strength in the U.S. and Fortune 500 companies. You didn't mention emerging markets. I guess there's been some talk of weakness in China, Russia, Latin America. Could you talk about the foreign markets? And are you seeing just overall, in your Aerospace business, requests for pushouts or deferrals or requests for accelerations of planes?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So we have very carefully controlled and monitored our exposure to the emerging markets because of their great volatility. So we are cautious, and I think you've seen that behavior in our dealing and in our interchange with emerging markets. We have
componenttext: Yes. So we have very carefully controlled and monitored our exposure to the emerging markets because of their great volatility. So we are cautious, and I think you've seen that behavior in our dealing and in our interchange with emerging markets. We have some very good reliable customers in each of those markets, but they tend to be hyperbolic in their demand. They're in 1 quarter, out the next quarter. So there really hasn't been much activity in the emerging market space for a number of quarters now. I would add that the Mid East continues to be pretty wholesome for us. And -- but the real powerhouse here is North America. And by the way, it's nice not to have too much exposure to highly volatile markets. You can get yourself down in a box canyon in a big hurry.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Howard Rubel of Jefferies.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Howard Rubel of Jefferies.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: When you became CEO, the agenda was relatively clear, set some standards, and if we kind of look back for a moment, the numbers are pretty darn good today. And -- so how do you -- I mean, we get the bar in the increase right now, but when we look at sort
componenttext: When you became CEO, the agenda was relatively clear, set some standards, and if we kind of look back for a moment, the numbers are pretty darn good today. And -- so how do you -- I mean, we get the bar in the increase right now, but when we look at sort of the numbers going forward, they're pretty darn good. So how do you raise the bar from here? And what are sort of some of the agenda items because in some cases, this year is well understood and it's really the challenges beyond that.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So let's give a little bit of retrospective since this management team took over. In 2013, we were inwardly focused on improving our operations and retiring a considerable amount of risks that we found in the company. We did all of that. So 2014 and conti
componenttext: So let's give a little bit of retrospective since this management team took over. In 2013, we were inwardly focused on improving our operations and retiring a considerable amount of risks that we found in the company. We did all of that. So 2014 and continuing into this year was about building that backlog, taking the lower-cost structure that we had invested in and the cost reductions that we made, along with our strong operating discipline and increasing our backlog very significantly. And that worked. And we're not done. You never can take your eye off of operations. Without solid operating performance, everything else becomes ephemeral. So we got to continue to focus on taking costs out, our continuous improvement reengineering efforts aren't done and we're -- so we take those, that low-cost basis. And given the backlog, we are poised for growth this year, next year and through my current planning horizon. Our defense companies are growing. We've talked about the transition at -- in Aerospace, but fundamentally these defense companies across the board are -- they have the backlog in Combat and Marine and IS&T to continue to grow. So now it's about growing -- it's about growing earnings, about growing EPS based on increases in revenue and then it's our productivity. So I think you're going to see more of the same. Focus on the core, blocking and tackling, might not be the sexiest thing but, boy, it really makes all the difference in performance.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, I don't think you're going to get too many complaints. You've talked about, or Jason talked about the strength of the dollar, but that's a strength of your European operations. They now become lower cost on the international market, and we did see r
componenttext: Well, I don't think you're going to get too many complaints. You've talked about, or Jason talked about the strength of the dollar, but that's a strength of your European operations. They now become lower cost on the international market, and we did see recent order of I think it was out of Denmark. But could you talk for a moment about how that integration has worked? And what kind of aperture that has opened up in terms of opportunities both there and you do a little bit of IS&T also and how that's being pulled through, please?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So when we look x U.S. and x North America, our efforts in the U.K. and our European Land Systems have been exemplary, and they really are the sort of the parable that describes what the journey that General Dynamics has been on. We -- take the ELS, for e
componenttext: So when we look x U.S. and x North America, our efforts in the U.K. and our European Land Systems have been exemplary, and they really are the sort of the parable that describes what the journey that General Dynamics has been on. We -- take the ELS, for example. We always knew that we were going to have to invest in that business, because when we purchased it, it had excess infrastructure. So we made that investment, and their cost structure and their wrap rate now is at highly competitive levels. That, with the competency of that management team, they are really performing. And all of our expectations were realized because they did what they needed to do, and we supported them in that. So they have increasingly won every bid that they've been in. And the Denmark win was significant for them. It's a replacement of the M113 fleet, about $500 million. We've been in Denmark for a while, but it was European Land Systems. Both their design excellence, their operating performance and their understanding of that very important customer that allowed them to execute and win. In the U.K., that's really been out of the phoenix, right? I mean, out of the ashes rose the phoenix. We had to dismantle that entire business and turn it over to Land Systems to run the SD program, so the guys we knew how to build Combat vehicles, actually were building the Combat vehicle and we turned over the remaining IS&T businesses to Mission Systems, and both have done a superb job of taking costs out, increasing their competitiveness. So I think you may just have heard, I think it's earlier this week, maybe even last week, the U.K. government announced another $630 million service and support contract for the SC program. You don't get that unless you demonstrate your performance and with a very affordable cost structure, so that you can support the needs of your customers. So that to me is a -- I said it's a parable of what can go right when you do what you need to do.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q2 2015 Earnings Call, Jul 29, 2015
componenttextpreview: So the next major milestone for the first ship -- costs plus ship is going to sea trials. In the Navy, we have worked very, very closely with. They have, by the way, retained the integration responsibility for this class of ships. So we work very closely
componenttext: So the next major milestone for the first ship -- costs plus ship is going to sea trials. In the Navy, we have worked very, very closely with. They have, by the way, retained the integration responsibility for this class of ships. So we work very closely with them to work schedule and production, so that we minimize any rework, which is particularly challenging on a first-of-class ship, but we're not seeing enormous amounts of rework. This is simply integrating, building and integrating a significantly -- this is a huge, huge warship with an array of new technologies. And so that's some of the challenge. That said, the fleet is anxious to get it because of its clear war fighting capability. So this is a 3 class -- 3-ship class and our close relationship with the Navy has been important in all of us working together to get this war fighting battle star out to the fleet.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the General Dynamics Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call maybe recorded. I would now like to turn the conference to Erin Linnihan, General
componenttext: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the General Dynamics Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call maybe recorded. I would now like to turn the conference to Erin Linnihan, General Dynamics' Director of Investor Relations.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Nicole, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to the General Dynamics' Third Quarter Conference Call.As always, any forward-looking statements made today represent our estimates regarding the company's outlook. These estimates are subject to so
componenttext:
Thank you, Nicole, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to the General Dynamics' Third Quarter Conference Call.
As always, any forward-looking statements made today represent our estimates regarding the company's outlook. These estimates are subject to some risks and uncertainties. Additional information regarding these factors is contained in the company's 10-K and 10-Q filings.
With that, I would like to turn the call over to our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Phebe Novakovic.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning. As is obvious from our press release, we enjoyed another strong quarter. We reported EPS from continuing operations of $2.28 per fully diluted share on revenue of $7.99 billion and income from continuing operations of $733 million. This is $
componenttext:
Good morning. As is obvious from our press release, we enjoyed another strong quarter. We reported EPS from continuing operations of $2.28 per fully diluted share on revenue of $7.99 billion and income from continuing operations of $733 million. This is $0.23 per share better than the year-ago quarter and $0.15 per share better than consensus.
Against the year-ago quarter, revenue is up $243 million or 3.1%; operating earnings are up $35 million, a 3.5% increase; and income from continuing operations is up $39 million, a 5.6% increase.
This quarter's operating earnings of $1,034,000,000 reflects 12.9 operating margin, consistent with the 12.9 operating margin of third quarter 2014. By the way, this is the fourth consecutive quarter that we have had both operating earnings and EBIT in excess of $1 billion.
Sequentially, revenue is up $112 million or 1.4%, operating earnings are down $47 million and operating margin is down 80 basis points. Recall, however, that last quarter's earnings included a gain on the sale of our cyber commercial security business. Excluding that gain, the operating earnings for the quarter rather similar.
On a year-to-date basis, revenue is up $1.17 billion, a 5.2% increase; operating earnings are up $320 million, a very strong 11.3% increase; and operating margins are up 80 basis points. Once again reflecting our emphasis on continuous improvement in operations.
With respect to cash. We had $652 million of free cash flow from operations in the quarter. That is 89% of net income from continuing operations. We have $1.81 billion year-to-date, 82% of net income from continuing operations. You may recall that we received significant advanced payments on international orders last year and on commercial shipbuilding orders a year before. That cash is being deployed this year and next, as we had previously advised you. 
We are also hampered by OWC growth at Gulfstream, which is the natural result of building test articles and preproduction build-up of parts and wings for the G500 and G600. All of the foregoing makes performance at 100% of net income this year and next problematic.
In the quarter, we purchased 7.15 million shares for over $1 billion. We have purchased approximately 19.3 million shares year-to-date for about $2.7 billion. This is consistent with our prior guidance to you that we would repurchase shares and pay dividends in amounts in excess of this year's free cash flow.
To help you size that, we have spent $3,380,000,000 on share repurchases and dividends year-to-date compared to free cash flow of $1.81 billion. That is a delta of $1.75 billion. That delta is likely to grow in the fourth quarter.
As you can see from the charts attached to press release, a very healthy backlog is holding nicely. Once again, there was a good intake of orders in all segments other than the Marine group, where we have received several multiyear orders in prior quarters. The Marine group has the largest backlog of all of our operating segments. We ended the quarter with total backlog for the company at $68.7 billion, down modestly from the end of last quarter.
Let me say a few words about each of our businesses -- business groups, and I'll start with Aerospace. Aerospace had another very good quarter. Revenue, earnings and margins are all up from the year-ago quarter as well as for the first 9 months of the year. The group reported sales of $2.34 billion, up from the third quarter of 2014 by $54 million or 2.4%. This represents the group's highest ever revenue quarter.
Operating earnings increased $15 million or 3.6% to $426 million on an operating margin of 18.2%, a 20 basis point improvement on the year-ago quarter. By the way, this is the fifth consecutive quarter with operating earnings in excess of $400 million. 
On a sequential basis, the group experienced some margin compression from the first half, but was nevertheless better than our expectations and guidance to you. We had good order intake in the group at 0.8:1 book to bill measured in dollar value of orders and 0.9:1 in number of units sold. The distribution of the orders is also attractive, with the G650 and 650 ER leading the way. Only 4 of the orders were from models not yet in production.
Much like the automobile industry, general business aviation market is increasingly North America focused, with particularly strong interest from Fortune 500 companies. However, the G650 continues to see activity even in areas experiencing political or economic challenges. We had G650 orders in China, Japan, Brazil and Eastern Europe in the quarter. Our pipeline of projects and active sales discussions are good. So we are reasonably optimistic about order intake for the fourth quarter.
Next, Combat Systems. Combat had a very good quarter with revenue of $1.35 billion, operating earnings of $218 million and a really strong 16.2% operating margins. However, margins are up somewhat against the third quarter 2014 when we enjoyed an operating margin that was 40 basis points higher. Compared to third quarter of 2014, revenue was off $50 million and earnings were off $14 million. Importantly, however, year-to-date revenue was flat against 2014, operating earnings are up $57 million or 9.6% and operating margin is at [ph] 15.7%, up 130 [ph] basis points. Combat Systems remains on course for a very strong year.
The Marine group's revenue is higher than 2014, both for the third quarter and for the first 9 months. Revenue in the quarter is up by $267 million, a 14.7% increase to $2.09 billion. Year-to-date, revenue has increased by $759 million or 14.4% to over $6 billion. The growth in both periods is attributable to the group's submarine programs, both construction, repair and engineering and to a lesser degree, commercial ship construction activities. This is the strongest revenue quarter ever for the Marine group. 
Operating earnings at $181 million are up modestly compared to last year's quarter. The group's operating margins were down 60 basis points in the quarter and 50 basis points year-to-date as a result of mix shift and a onetime charge at NASSCO and a warranty item in the quarter. However, margins for the first 9 months of the year remain a respectable 9.2% and should improve a bit in the fourth quarter.
And finally, IS&T. It continue to outperform our revenue expectations. Revenue at $2.2 billion is off [ph] $28 million against last year's quarter, but up $113 million or 1.7% year-to-date. Recall that we had initially expected a 5.5% revenue decline for the year and instead, we are up almost 2%.
Operating earnings of $219 million are up $17 million or 8.4% compared to the third quarter of last year on the strength of a 90 basis point improvement in operating margin. Year-to-date, operating earnings are up $100 million, a 17.5% increase on a 130 basis point improvement in operating margins. This is a very good news story with both revenue and operating margin higher than expected.
So what does all this mean as far as the year's concerned? While stronger-than-expected operating results in the quarter, a lower-than-planned tax rate and somewhat lower share count enable us to increase guidance for the year by $0.20. Our guidance goes from a range of $8.70 to $8.80 to a range of $8.90 to $9.
I'll now turn the call over to our CFO, Jason Aiken, for some more detail.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Phebe, and good morning. I'll be brief as I've got just a couple of things to cover before we start the Q&A period.As we discussed throughout this year, we're seeing more of an impact on our financial results from foreign exchange rate volati
componenttext:
Thank you, Phebe, and good morning. I'll be brief as I've got just a couple of things to cover before we start the Q&A period.
As we discussed throughout this year, we're seeing more of an impact on our financial results from foreign exchange rate volatility this year than we have in the past. Still not material in the aggregate, but it's having a negative impact on some of our segments, particularly Combat Systems. As Phebe pointed out, the group's revenue is held steady over the first 9 months compared with last year, but had foreign exchange rates, particularly the U.S. dollar to the euro and the Canadian dollar, held constant from 2014 to this year, the group's sales would have been up by 8% year-to-date.
As Combat Systems shifts away from a heavy reliance on U.S. Military sales to an increasing level of international activity, we expect foreign currency fluctuations to continue to be a part of the group's story.
Moving on to interest expense. The net expense in the quarter was $23 million versus $21 million in the third quarter of 2014. The slight increase is due to lower interest income, as we've deployed over $1 billion this year from the balance sheet towards share repurchases and dividend payments. For the full year, we expect net interest expense to be approximately $85 million.
At the end of the quarter, our balance sheet reflects a net debt position at just about breakeven, a total of $41 million debt in excess of cash. This compares to a net cash balance of about $660 million at the end of the second quarter, and that change again is due to the capital deployment activity in the quarter.
Our effective tax rate was 27.6% for the quarter, lower than we expected as a result of increased international earnings as well as favorable contract closeouts and other true-ups associated with the filing of our tax return.
For the full year, reflecting our favorable performance to date, we now expect an effective tax rate closer to 28%.
We funded our pension plan as expected in the quarter and continue to expect cash pension contributions for 2015 to be approximately $185 million.
Erin, that concludes my remarks, and I'll turn the time back over to you for our Q&A.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Phebe, thanks for the additional detail and color in your opening remarks. It's very helpful. I just have one quick follow-up question though on some of the comments that you made around the book to bill at Gulfstream with regard to value versus units. It
componenttext: Phebe, thanks for the additional detail and color in your opening remarks. It's very helpful. I just have one quick follow-up question though on some of the comments that you made around the book to bill at Gulfstream with regard to value versus units. It sounds like a number of units were a little bit better than the value, and you had -- you followed up all this with some positive commentary about the G650. So I'm just wondering if you could dive and a little bit more about the difference between the 2? And what that might say about the pricing environment that you're seeing today for -- particularly the 450 and 550.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, largely the difference between the 2 book-to-bill calculations is really about mix. And let me give you -- let me take this opportunity I think to give you a little bit of color and detail and I'm going to parse for you sort of the demand picture. B
componenttext: Well, largely the difference between the 2 book-to-bill calculations is really about mix. And let me give you -- let me take this opportunity I think to give you a little bit of color and detail and I'm going to parse for you sort of the demand picture. Because I think I want you all to understand the demand signals in their totality. So what I'm going to talk to you about is what we have seen so far this year, and I think this context is important. First, Gulfstream continues to perform well in the market. This is our strongest third order intake for -- in the last 4 years. And by the way, it follows the strongest second quarter intake that we've had in 7 years last quarter. Second, our North American sales activity remains good. And this quarter, we saw some resurgence in the international market. Interestingly, with about half of our orders coming from x U.S. Asia, Pacific, Australia, Latin America, Middle East. So nice broad order interests and order activity. So our book to bill, as you noted, is wholesome. And fourth, and I think this is also important to recall and understand, our firm backlog for this quarter is $13.6 billion. That's right around the median of our backlog total for 3 years. So what does that mean? It means that the backlog has been remarkably stable. And by the way, recall that our orders come with good deposits and strong contracts, so they're rather sticky. So let me give a little bit of color going forward. Our pipeline is good as it's been all year. And if you're interested in the piece parts constituents of the pipeline, it's heavily North American, which is whole some public private companies, high net worth individuals and these are sophisticated buyers who are interested in fleet replacement and augmentation. So I think it's context that gives you a little bit of color on what we're seeing now with all of that said, there are some non-macro headwinds. We had a competitor with wide tails in the of 450 and 550 space at very low prices. There are also 5 to 6 preowned 550s on the market that are less than 5 years old, and these newer airplanes are still under warranty. And for some customers, they can be competitive with our new offering. So with all of that said, we remain pretty cautiously optimistic. I think I give you a little bit more there but I wanted you to understand how we're seeing the entire market because I think it's important to see it is in totality.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Phebe, you talked about the disconnect between cash generation and cash deployment and consistently in the past has been 100% conversion and you [indiscernible] up the '15 and '16 explanation thereof. So I'm just curious how much of the deployment this ye
componenttext: Phebe, you talked about the disconnect between cash generation and cash deployment and consistently in the past has been 100% conversion and you [indiscernible] up the '15 and '16 explanation thereof. So I'm just curious how much of the deployment this year, I think you said somewhere around $3.3 billion year-to-date is deployed and presumably there will be more of that in the fourth quarter. How much of that is indicative of what you think free cash flow is once you get through this kind of negative headwind you're seeing in '15 and '16? Is that the underlying cash generative base of business that you see out in the '17, '18 period of time?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, to the extent that I think I can fully understand your question, we'll give you my color on '16 as we always do in January of that year. But I'll try to give you some context of -- for '15 and '16 and not beyond that. What we see in terms of the cas
componenttext: Well, to the extent that I think I can fully understand your question, we'll give you my color on '16 as we always do in January of that year. But I'll try to give you some context of -- for '15 and '16 and not beyond that. What we see in terms of the cash headwinds. We had those international deposits that we're deploying as you would expect and we're building our operating working capital also as you would expect if you think about it at Gulfstream. So that all flushes out at the end of '16. So those -- if the essence of your question is there any structural cash generation issue at our company, the answer is no.

componenttextpreview: Just a quick one on IS&T. Obviously, the results there have been much better than you expected. I wondered if you might give us some color on where you're seeing the strength? And sort of break out the more traditional service-oriented offerings versus th
componenttext: Just a quick one on IS&T. Obviously, the results there have been much better than you expected. I wondered if you might give us some color on where you're seeing the strength? And sort of break out the more traditional service-oriented offerings versus the product-oriented offerings? And maybe comment on the cost structure and your efforts there? And what impact that's having? The cello bit more color on the successes you've been having there.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So this is a good news story for us and it's across both Mission Systems and information technology. They both had a strong quarter and they're improving their performance year-to-date. And there's no single area that's driving strength, given the nu
componenttext: Yes. So this is a good news story for us and it's across both Mission Systems and information technology. They both had a strong quarter and they're improving their performance year-to-date. And there's no single area that's driving strength, given the number of programs that we had in that portfolio, that's just constant flux and mix and timing. They have been -- but because of the increased costs or decreased cost structure, they've been winning more than their fair share, so that has added nicely to our book to bill, which I think year-to-date is about 1:1 and no short-cycle businesses. That's pretty impressive. So I think it's operating excellence, technical ability and just focus. So we're very pleased with what we've done.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Doug Harned of Bernstein.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to get back to Gulfstream and just 2 things to understand. One, you've talked in the past about potentially moving forward since G650 production perhaps adding some -- in the near term, which would help the revenue top line. Can you comment on th
componenttext: I wanted to get back to Gulfstream and just 2 things to understand. One, you've talked in the past about potentially moving forward since G650 production perhaps adding some -- in the near term, which would help the revenue top line. Can you comment on that? And then also were this availability stand on the 450 and 550 now in terms of months ahead?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me take them in the inverse order. The 450 and 550 are about 3 to 4 quarters, so not much of a change there. With respect to the 650, our production is as we anticipated this is, so no changes to that. By going forward, as we prepare our plan for
componenttext: Yes, let me take them in the inverse order. The 450 and 550 are about 3 to 4 quarters, so not much of a change there. With respect to the 650, our production is as we anticipated this is, so no changes to that. By going forward, as we prepare our plan for next year, we'll look to feather in a couple of -- and I'm talking about 1 and 2 to -- just a handful 1 Cs [ph] and 2 Cs [ph] feathering some 650s to help offset some of -- as we make that transition to entering into service on the new airplane. So that's pretty much what we've been seeing all year and saying is exactly what we're continuing to see.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015

componenttext: So Phebe, yes, if you could just give us some color on how the flight test program is going, because it's kind of our to follow as an outsider. Just what milestones are happening? And if you could just kind of paint the picture for that?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So our flight tech program is going very well. On the G550, we've surpassed G500. We've surpassed more than 100 hours of flight and we've successfully completed about I think 45 missions. On the 600, we've begun construction and is well underway on
componenttext: Sure. So our flight tech program is going very well. On the G550, we've surpassed G500. We've surpassed more than 100 hours of flight and we've successfully completed about I think 45 missions. On the 600, we've begun construction and is well underway on construction on test aircraft. And we plan to fly that in 2016. And our entry into service remains unchanged, so its very, very well.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just as a quick follow-on is there any chance that, that entry into service kind of happened in build earlier kind of if everything continues to go smooth?
componenttext: Just as a quick follow-on is there any chance that, that entry into service kind of happened in build earlier kind of if everything continues to go smooth?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, that's our to predict but I we don't -- but I'm not going to get out the head of Gulfstream. We're sticking right now to what our original entry into service is. And if we go and we mature and get down the tests flight program, we'll have a little b
componenttext: Well, that's our to predict but I we don't -- but I'm not going to get out the head of Gulfstream. We're sticking right now to what our original entry into service is. And if we go and we mature and get down the tests flight program, we'll have a little bit more clarity. But right now, that's what we still see.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015

componenttext: Can you give us an update on your kind of general thoughts on your latest thought on the budget deal? What that -- if there's any material impact in terms of your overall plan? And just regarding, in particular, regarding combat. I mean, it seems like the mix they're continues to favor the margin performance. If you could just update how we see the mix going forward?

componenttext: Well, the budget -- the perspective budget agreement will be very well the news I think from a national security perspective and certainly for asked, the program are fully funded in the president's requests. And as we understand, the proposed budget agreement. So I think that's a very, very good progress made quickly. So we're pleased with that and we would encourage and hope that, that continues and see -- we're hopeful that that's all on track. And on combat, we're continuing -- it's between last year and this year, it had some mix issues as we came off of mature programs that were in development at the end of their production runs and started up on the whole series of new programs. But that backlog and a coupled with the operating excellence of their entire group is -- positions us quite well for nice earnings growth and we'll hold -- yes, margins should increase over time. If that's -- if you think about that business as we've got our platform businesses, but we also have a Ordnance and Tactical Systems business, and they have an absolutely terrific quarter. So they are a highly focused on their cost structure, operating leverage. And they had a very wholesome book to bill in excess of 1:1. So for a short cycle business, that's very, very good.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I think -- one way to think about it this we would never review a net cash position is being optimal even a breakeven situation is not optimal. I don't necessarily think we characterize it as having a target leverage position so much as we think about
componenttext: So I think -- one way to think about it this we would never review a net cash position is being optimal even a breakeven situation is not optimal. I don't necessarily think we characterize it as having a target leverage position so much as we think about having the preservation of the strong balance sheet that allows us to be poised to quickly and readily take a strategic direction when the opportunity percent itself. And as far as capital deployment goes, I'll look at my boss and say I'm not going to speak to our plans for next year and get out ahead of her, but that's going to -- where we are today is trying to normalize that deployment of capital to a net income level given that we see free cash flow being somewhat less than net income this year.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015

componenttext: Okay. Maybe a quick follow-up, Jason. On the foreign exchange, you mentioned this is something we should watch. What's your hedging situation/ Do you have some of these export revenue hedged?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So that's -- yes, 2 parts answer to that question. From the perspective of actual economic exposure and having a foreign currency revenue or expense item in a particular business, we have that 100% hedged and we're totally secured to on that front. What I
componenttext: So that's -- yes, 2 parts answer to that question. From the perspective of actual economic exposure and having a foreign currency revenue or expense item in a particular business, we have that 100% hedged and we're totally secured to on that front. What I'm referring to strictly is the translation of our indigenous businesses in Spain, in the U.K., in Canada and so on translating those operating results back into U.S. dollars for consolidated reporting. So it's not an economic loss we're talking about. It's a headwind for my U.S. consolidated reporting perspective. So -- but from a natural exposure economic standpoint, we're very comfortably hedged.

componenttext: So the fourth quarter is going to be lighter than the third quarter, and let me take you back to last quarter when we talked about Jet Aviation and that we were going to see some margin compression in the second half as we began to spend on engineering and the preproduction activities at Basel that we need to do in anticipation of the start of production, which begins early next year. componenttext: Well, as you would expect, we took in a fair -- a large number of orders into the backlog in '14 and if you look at the engineering cycle and typically when programs start production, you could reasonably expect that production to begin in 2016. componenttext: Well, your supposition is right. Cost management is going to be key. The margin compression that we've seen in Jet reverses in the first quarter of 2016 as they begin production. Right now they're simply in the doing face and engineering for these large body and narrow-body airline completions. So that's a fair amount of engineering work. We'll get into production when -- starting in the first quarter of next year, but that headwind as behind us.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, so they talked a little bit about 1000. As we've said before, this is a highly complex and revolutionary surface combatant. And first of which, we've got 3 in the backlog and 3 under construction. The first of which is nearing sea trial. So we're con
componenttext: Yes, so they talked a little bit about 1000. As we've said before, this is a highly complex and revolutionary surface combatant. And first of which, we've got 3 in the backlog and 3 under construction. The first of which is nearing sea trial. So we're continuing to work with the Navy to resolve over any developmental issues that they see. And I think we all agree that we are working through all of the technical challenges on this first ship. And by the way, I think [indiscernible] that we used to think about performance on that ship is you may recall that the complete redesign of the deck house on the third ship was reassigned to us. That design is nearly complete and construction is proceeding quite nicely. So that's just considerable learning, and I'm very pleased with at least that performance there. We do have some risks going forward. We'll manage that accordingly, and we're working very closely with the Navy. And Navy's other subcontractors on this program. Let me give you some sense of magnitude. That is 132nd [ph] of our sales. So we are paying quite a bit of attention to -- so it's a complex floor shift, but I think the context is important here.
