headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the General Dynamics Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call may be recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Erin Linnihan,
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the General Dynamics Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call may be recorded. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to Erin Linnihan, Staff Vice President, Investor Relations. You may begin.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Nicole, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to the General Dynamics' Third Quarter Conference Call.As always, any forward-looking statements made today represent our estimates regarding the company's outlook. These estimates are subject to so
componenttext:
Thank you, Nicole, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to the General Dynamics' Third Quarter Conference Call.
As always, any forward-looking statements made today represent our estimates regarding the company's outlook. These estimates are subject to some risks and uncertainties. Additional information regarding these factors is contained in the company's 10-K and 10-Q filings.
With that, I would like to turn the call over to our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Phebe Novakovic.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning. As is obvious from our press release, we enjoyed another strong quarter. We reported EPS from continuing operations of $2.28 per fully diluted share on revenue of $7.99 billion and income from continuing operations of $733 million. This is $
componenttext:
Good morning. As is obvious from our press release, we enjoyed another strong quarter. We reported EPS from continuing operations of $2.28 per fully diluted share on revenue of $7.99 billion and income from continuing operations of $733 million. This is $0.23 per share better than the year-ago quarter and $0.15 per share better than consensus.
Against the year-ago quarter, revenue is up $243 million or 3.1%; operating earnings are up $35 million, a 3.5% increase; and income from continuing operations is up $39 million, a 5.6% increase.
This quarter's operating earnings of $1,034,000,000 reflects 12.9% operating margin, consistent with the 12.9% operating margin of third quarter 2014. By the way, this is the fourth consecutive quarter that we had had both operating earnings and EBIT in excess of $1 billion.
Sequentially, revenue is up $112 million or 1.4%, operating earnings are down $47 million and operating margin is down 80 basis points. Recall, however, that last quarter's earnings included a gain on the sale of our cyber commercial security business. Excluding that gain, the operating earnings for the quarter rather similar.
On a year-to-date basis, revenue is up $1.17 billion, a 5.2% increase; operating earnings are up $320 million, a very strong 11.3% increase; and operating margins are up 80 basis points, once again reflecting our emphasis on continuous improvement in operations.
With respect to cash. We had $652 million of free cash flow from operations in the quarter. That is 89% of net income from continuing operations. We have $1.81 billion year-to-date, 82% of net income from continuing operations. You may recall that we received significant advanced payments on international orders last year and on commercial shipbuilding orders a year before. That cash is being deployed this year and next, as we have previously advised you. 
We are also hampered by OWC growth at Gulfstream, which is the natural result of building test articles and preproduction build-up of parts and wings for the G500 and G600. All of the foregoing makes performance at 100% of net income this year and next problematic.
In the quarter, we purchased 7.15 million shares for over $1 billion. We have purchased approximately 19.3 million shares year-to-date for about $2.7 billion. This is consistent with our prior guidance to you that we would repurchase shares and pay dividends in amounts in excess of this year's free cash flow. To help you size that, we have spent $3,380,000,000 on share repurchases and dividends year-to-date compared to free cash flow of $1.81 billion. That is a delta of $1.75 billion. That delta is likely to grow in the fourth quarter.
As you can see from the charts attached to press release, our very healthy backlog is holding nicely. Once again, there was a good intake of orders in all segments other than the Marine group, where we have received several multi-year orders in prior quarters. The Marine group has the largest backlog of all of our operating segments. 
We ended the quarter with total backlog for the company at $68.7 billion, down modestly from the end of last quarter.
Let me say a few words about each of our businesses -- business groups, and I'll start with Aerospace. Aerospace had another very good quarter. Revenue, earnings and margin are all up from the year-ago quarter as well as for the first 9 months of the year. The group reported sales of $2.34 billion, up from the third quarter of 2014 by $54 million or 2.4%. This represents the group's highest ever revenue quarter.
Operating earnings increased $15 million or 3.6% to $426 million on an operating margin of 18.2%, a 20 basis point improvement on the year-ago quarter. By the way, this is the fifth consecutive quarter with operating earnings in excess of $400 million. 
On a sequential basis, the group experienced some margin compression from the first half, but was nevertheless better than our expectations and guidance to you. We had good order intake in the group at 0.8:1 book to bill measured in dollar value of orders and 0.9:1 in number of units sold. The distribution of the orders is also attractive, with the G650 and 650ER leading the way. Only 4 of the orders were from models not yet in production.
Much like the automobile industry, general business aviation market is increasingly North America focused, with particularly strong interest from Fortune 500 companies. However, the G650 continues to see activity even in areas experiencing political or economic challenges. We had G650 orders in China, Japan, Brazil and Eastern Europe in the quarter. Our pipeline of projects and active sales discussions are good, so we are reasonably optimistic about order intake for the fourth quarter.
Next, Combat Systems. Combat had a very good quarter with revenue of $1.35 billion, operating earnings of $218 million and a really strong 16.2% operating margins. However, margins were off somewhat against the third quarter 2014 when we enjoyed an operating margin that was 40 basis points higher. Compared to third quarter of 2014, revenue was off $50 million and earnings were off $14 million. Importantly, however, year-to-date revenue was flat against 2014; operating earnings are up $57 million or 9.6%; and operating margin is at 15.7%, up 130 basis points. Combat Systems remains on course for a very strong year.
The Marine group's revenue was higher than 2014, both for the third quarter and for the first 9 months. Revenue in the quarter is up by $267 million, a 14.7% increase to $2.09 billion. Year-to-date, revenue has increased by $759 million or 14.4% to over $6 billion. The growth in both periods is attributable to the group's submarine programs, both construction, repair and engineering, and to a lesser degree, commercial ship construction activities. This is the strongest revenue quarter ever for the Marine group. 
Operating earnings at $181 million are up modestly compared to last year's quarter. The group's operating margins were down 60 basis points in the quarter and 50 basis points year-to-date as a result of mix shift and a one-time charge at NASSCO on a warranty item in the quarter. However, margins for the first 9 months of the year remain a respectable 9.2% and should improve a bit in the fourth quarter.
And finally, IS&T. It continue to outperform our revenue expectations. Revenue at $2.2 billion was off $28 million against last year's quarter, but up $113 million or 1.7% year-to-date. Recall that we had initially expected a 5.5% revenue decline for the year and instead, we are up almost 2%.
Operating earnings of $219 million are up $17 million or 8.4% compared to the third quarter of last year on the strength of a 90 basis point improvement in operating margin. Year-to-date, operating earnings are up $100 million, a 17.5% increase on a 130 basis point improvement in operating margins. This is a very good news story with both revenue and operating margin higher than expected.
So what does all this mean as far as the year is concerned? While stronger-than-expected operating results in the quarter, a lower-than-planned tax rate and somewhat lower share count enable us to increase guidance for the year by $0.20. Our guidance goes from a range of $8.70 to $8.80 to a range of $8.90 to $9.
I'll now turn the call over to our CFO, Jason Aiken, for some more detail.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Phebe, and good morning. I'll be brief as I've got just a couple of things to cover before we start the Q&A period.As we discussed throughout this year, we're seeing more of an impact on our financial results from foreign exchange rate volati
componenttext:
Thank you, Phebe, and good morning. I'll be brief as I've got just a couple of things to cover before we start the Q&A period.
As we discussed throughout this year, we're seeing more of an impact on our financial results from foreign exchange rate volatility this year than we have in the past. Still not material in the aggregate, but it's having a negative impact on some of our segments, particularly Combat Systems. 
As Phebe pointed out, the group's revenue is held steady over the first 9 months compared with last year, but had foreign exchange rates, particularly the U.S. dollar to the euro and the Canadian dollar, held constant from 2014 to this year, the group's sales would have been up by 8% year-to-date. As Combat Systems shifts away from a heavy reliance on U.S. Military sales to an increasing level of international activity, we expect foreign currency fluctuations to continue to be a part of the group's story.
Moving on to interest expense. The net expense in the quarter was $23 million versus $21 million in the third quarter of 2014. The slight increase is due to lower interest income, as we've deployed over $1 billion this year from the balance sheet towards share repurchases and dividend payments. For the full year, we expect net interest expense to be approximately $85 million.
At the end of the quarter, our balance sheet reflects a net debt position at just about breakeven, a total of $41 million debt in excess of cash. This compares to a net cash balance of about $660 million at the end of the second quarter, and that change, again, is due to the capital deployment activity in the quarter.
Our effective tax rate was 27.6% for the quarter, lower than we expected as a result of increased international earnings as well as favorable contract closeouts and other true-ups associated with the filing of our tax return. For the full year, 9:12 PM reflecting our favorable performance to date, we now expect an effective tax rate closer to 28%.
We funded our pension plans as expected in the quarter and continue to expect cash pension contributions for 2015 to be approximately $185 million.
Erin, that concludes my remarks, and I'll turn the time back over to you for the Q&A.

componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Jason Gursky of Citi.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I just had one quick follow-up question though on some of the comments that you made around the book to bill at Gulfstream with regard to value versus units. It sounds like a number of units were a little bit better than the value, and then you had -- you
componenttext: I just had one quick follow-up question though on some of the comments that you made around the book to bill at Gulfstream with regard to value versus units. It sounds like a number of units were a little bit better than the value, and then you had -- you followed all this with some positive commentary about the G650. So I'm wondering if you could dive in a little bit more about the difference between the 2? And what that might say about the pricing environment that you're seeing today for -- particularly the 450 and 550?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, it was largely the difference between the 2 book-to-bill calculations is really about mix. And let me give you -- let me take this opportunity, I think, to give you a little bit of color and detail. I'm going to parse for you sort of the demand pict
componenttext: Well, it was largely the difference between the 2 book-to-bill calculations is really about mix. And let me give you -- let me take this opportunity, I think, to give you a little bit of color and detail. I'm going to parse for you sort of the demand picture, because I think I want to -- I want you all to understand the demand signals in their totality. So what I'm going to talk to you about is what we have seen so far this year, and I think this context is important. First, Gulfstream continues to perform well in the market. This was our strongest third order intake for -- in the last 4 years. And by the way, it follows the strongest second quarter intake that we had in 7 years last quarter. Second, our North American sales activity remains good. And this quarter, we saw some resurgence in the international market. Interestingly, with about half of our orders coming from ex U.S, Asia-Pacific, Australia, Latin America, Middle East. So nice broad order interests and order activity. Third, our book to bill, as you noted, is wholesome. And fourth, and I think this is also important to recall and understand, our firm backlog for this quarter is $13.6 billion. That's right around the median of our backlog total for 3 years. So what does that mean? It means that the backlog has been remarkably stable. And by the way, recall that our orders come with good deposits and strong contract terms, so they're rather sticky. So let me give you a little bit of color going forward. Our pipeline is good as it's been all year. And if you're interested in the piece parts constituents of the pipeline, it's heavily North American, which is wholesome. Public, private companies, high-net-worth individuals and these are sophisticated buyers who are interested in fleet replacement and augmentation. So I think it's context that gives you a little bit of color on what we're seeing now. With all of that said, there are some non-macro headwinds. We have a competitor with wide tails in the of 450 and 550 space at very low prices. There are also 5 to 6 pre-owned 550s on the market that are less than 5 years old, and these newer airplanes are still under warranty. And for some customers, they can be competitive with our new offerings. So with all of that said, we remain pretty cautiously optimistic. I think I gave you a little bit more there, but I wanted you to understand how we're seeing the entire market because I think it's important to see it in totality.

componenttext: Phebe, you talked about the disconnect between cash generation and cash deployment, and consistently in the past there's been 100% conversion and you teed up the '15 and '16 explanation thereof. So I'm just curious, how much of the deployment this year -- I think, you said somewhere around $3.3 billion year-to-date is deployed and presumably there would be more of that in the fourth quarter. How much of that is indicative of what you think free cash flow is once you get through this kind of negative headwind you're seeing in '15 and '16? Is that the underlying cash generative base of business that you see out in the '17, '18 period of time?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, to the extent that I think I can fully understand your question, we'll give you more color on '16 as we always do in January of that year. But I'll try to give you some context for '15 and '16 and not beyond that what we see in terms of the cash hea
componenttext: Well, to the extent that I think I can fully understand your question, we'll give you more color on '16 as we always do in January of that year. But I'll try to give you some context for '15 and '16 and not beyond that what we see in terms of the cash headwinds. We have those international deposits that we're deploying as you would expect, and we're building our operating working capital also, as you would expect if you think about it, at Gulfstream. So that all flushes out at the end of '16. So there's -- if the essence of your question is there any structural cash generation issue at our company, the answer is no.

componenttext: Just a quick one on IS&T. Obviously, the results there have been much better than you expected. I wondered if you might give us some color on where you're seeing the strength and sort of break out the more traditional service-oriented offerings versus the product-oriented offerings? And maybe comment on the cost structure and your efforts there, and what impact that's having? Just a little bit more color on the successes you've been having there.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So this is a good news story for us, and it's across both Mission Systems and information technology. They both had a strong quarter and they're improving their performance year-to-date. And there's no single area that's driving strength given the nu
componenttext: Yes. So this is a good news story for us, and it's across both Mission Systems and information technology. They both had a strong quarter and they're improving their performance year-to-date. And there's no single area that's driving strength given the number of programs that we have in that portfolio, there's just constant flux and mix and timing. They have been -- but because of the increased cost or decreased cost structure they've been winning more than their fair share. So that has added nicely to our book to bill, which, I think, year-to-date is about 1:1 and no short-cycle businesses. That's pretty impressive. So I think it's operating excellence, technical ability and just focus. So we're very pleased with what they've done.

componenttext: I wanted to get back to Gulfstream and just 2 things to understand. One, you've talked in the past about potentially moving forward since G650 production perhaps adding some in the near term, which would help the revenue top line. Can you comment on that? And then also where does availability stand on the 450 and 550 now in terms of months ahead?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me take them in the inverse order. The 450 and 550 are about 3 to 4 quarters, so not much of a change there. With respect to the 650, our production is as we anticipated this year, so no changes to that. But going forward, as we prepare our plan
componenttext: Yes, let me take them in the inverse order. The 450 and 550 are about 3 to 4 quarters, so not much of a change there. With respect to the 650, our production is as we anticipated this year, so no changes to that. But going forward, as we prepare our plan for next year, we'll look to feather in a couple of -- and I'm talking about 1 and 2  -- just a handful, 1 Cs and 2 Cs feathering some 650s to help offset some of -- as we make that transition to entering into service on the new airplane. So that's pretty much what we've been seeing all year and saying is exactly what we're continuing to see.

componenttext: So Phebe, yes, just if you could give us some color on how the flight test program is going, because it's kind of hard to follow as an outsider. Just what milestones are happening? And if you could just kind of paint a picture for that?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So our flight test program is going very well. On the G550, we've surpassed G500. We've surpassed more than 100 hours of flight, and we've successfully completed about, I think, 45 missions. On the 600, we've begun construction and is well underway
componenttext: Sure. So our flight test program is going very well. On the G550, we've surpassed G500. We've surpassed more than 100 hours of flight, and we've successfully completed about, I think, 45 missions. On the 600, we've begun construction and is well underway on construction on test aircraft. And we plan to fly that in 2016. And our entry into service remains unchanged, so it's very, very well.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015

componenttext: Just as a quick follow-on, is there any chance that, that entry into service can happen a little earlier if kind of everything just continues to go smooth?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, that's hard to predict, and we don't -- but I'm not going to get out ahead of Gulfstream. We're sticking right now to what our original entry into service is. And as we go and we mature and get down the test flight program, we'll have a little bit m
componenttext: Well, that's hard to predict, and we don't -- but I'm not going to get out ahead of Gulfstream. We're sticking right now to what our original entry into service is. And as we go and we mature and get down the test flight program, we'll have a little bit more clarity. But right now, that's what we still see.

componenttext: Can you give us an update on your kind of general thoughts on the latest talk on the budget deal? What that -- if there's any material impact in terms of your overall plan? And just regarding -- in particular, regarding Combat, I mean, it seems like the mix there continues to favor the margin performance. If you could just update how we see the mix going forward?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the budget -- the perspective budget agreement would be very well in the news, I think, from a national security perspective. And certainly for us, our programs are fully funded in the president's request and in the -- as we understand, the proposed
componenttext: Well, the budget -- the perspective budget agreement would be very well in the news, I think, from a national security perspective. And certainly for us, our programs are fully funded in the president's request and in the -- as we understand, the proposed budget agreement. So I think that's a very, very good progress made quickly. So we're pleased with that and we would encourage and hope that, that continue and see now -- we're hopeful that that's all on track. And on Combat, we're continuing -- it's between last year and this year, it had some mix issues as we came off of mature programs that were in development at the end of their production runs and started up on the whole series of new programs. But that backlog, coupled with the operating excellence of that entire group, positions us quite well for nice earnings growth. And we'll hold -- margins should increase over time. If that's -- if you think about that business as we've got our platform businesses, but we also have a -- our Ordnance and Tactical Systems business, and they had an absolutely terrific quarter. So they are highly focused on their cost structure, operating leverage and they had a very wholesome book to bill in excess of 1:1. So for a short-cycle business, that's very, very good.

componenttextpreview: I would ask my obvious question, again, maybe from a different direction. The buyback and the dividend exceeding free cash flow this year. Do you think that's something that we should expect again next year? And do you have a sort of leverage target in mi
componenttext: I would ask my obvious question, again, maybe from a different direction. The buyback and the dividend exceeding free cash flow this year. Do you think that's something that we should expect again next year? And do you have a sort of leverage target in mind? You've gone back to sort of net debt to cash of basically 0 BC. I should move into a net debt situation going forward?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I think one way to think about it is we would never view a net cash position as being optimal and even a breakeven situation is not optimal. I don't necessarily think we'd characterize it's having a target leverage position so much as we think about ha
componenttext: So I think one way to think about it is we would never view a net cash position as being optimal and even a breakeven situation is not optimal. I don't necessarily think we'd characterize it's having a target leverage position so much as we think about having preservation of the strong balance sheet that allows us to be poised to quickly and readily take a strategic direction when the opportunity present itself. And as far as capital deployment goes, I'll look at my boss and say I'm not going to speak to our plans for next year and get out ahead of her, but that's going to -- you know where we are today is trying to normalize that deployment of capital to a net income level given that we see free cash flow being somewhat less than net income this year.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Maybe a quick follow-up, Jason, as well. On the foreign exchange, you mentioned this is something we should watch. What's your hedging situation? Do you have most of these export revenue hedged?
componenttext: Okay. Maybe a quick follow-up, Jason, as well. On the foreign exchange, you mentioned this is something we should watch. What's your hedging situation? Do you have most of these export revenue hedged?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So that's -- yes, 2 parts answer to that question. From the perspective of actual economic exposure and having a foreign currency revenue or expense item in a particular business, we have that 100% hedged and we're totally secured on that front. What I'm
componenttext: So that's -- yes, 2 parts answer to that question. From the perspective of actual economic exposure and having a foreign currency revenue or expense item in a particular business, we have that 100% hedged and we're totally secured on that front. What I'm referring to strictly is the translation of our indigenous businesses in Spain, in the U.K., in Canada and so on, translating those operating results back into U.S. dollars for consolidated reporting. So it's not an economic loss we're talking about, it's a headwind from a U.S. consolidated reporting perspective. So -- but from an actual economic exposure standpoint, we're very comfortably hedged.

componenttext: Well, so far, we've seen nothing particular note that's interesting at accretive prices. So I think that -- that's just the best way to think about it. componenttext: So the fourth quarter is going to be lighter than the third quarter. And let me take you back to last quarter when we talked about Jet Aviation and that we were going to see some margin compression in the second half as we began to spend on engineering and the preproduction activities at Basel that we need to do in anticipation of the start of production, which begins early next year. That has happened, and it will continue into next quarter. So couple that with you got a higher R&D and lower-launch assistance, and that's essentially the story from where we sit right now.

componenttext: Yes on the latter question. And on the G500 and 600, customer interest has been good, and we expect that interest and demand increases. We progressed through the development program, and we frankly get closer to EIS. So this is an attractive airplane set for our customers.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, as you would expect, we took in a fair -- a large number of orders into the backlog in '14. And if you look at the engineering cycle and typically when programs start production, you could reasonably expect that production to begin in 2016. And I th
componenttext: Well, as you would expect, we took in a fair -- a large number of orders into the backlog in '14. And if you look at the engineering cycle and typically when programs start production, you could reasonably expect that production to begin in 2016. And I think we've been pretty clear about that. But I don't want to get into any more detail on what '16 looks like till we finish our plan.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Notwithstanding what you just said about not getting into 2016, I was wondering if you could comment on how the profitability headwind from Jet carries over -- in Aerospace from Jet Aviation carries over from Q4 into 2016? Since you've got some pretty tou
componenttext: Notwithstanding what you just said about not getting into 2016, I was wondering if you could comment on how the profitability headwind from Jet carries over -- in Aerospace from Jet Aviation carries over from Q4 into 2016? Since you've got some pretty tough margin comps in the first half of the year, the Gulfstream margin was around 20%. And I thought that the cost management in Aerospace was one of the ways to help manage this transition on the 550, 450 to the 500, 600.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, your supposition is right. Cost management is going to be key. The margin compression that we've seen in Jet reverses in the first quarter of 2016 as they begin production. Right now they're simply in the doing phase and engineering for these large-
componenttext: Well, your supposition is right. Cost management is going to be key. The margin compression that we've seen in Jet reverses in the first quarter of 2016 as they begin production. Right now they're simply in the doing phase and engineering for these large-body and narrow-body airline completions. So that's a fair amount of engineering work. We'll get into production then -- starting in the first quarter of next year. So that headwind is behind us.

componenttextpreview: Phebe, there was some press in the quarter about Bath on the DDG 1000. Can you give us your thoughts on that program? Just how it's going? And if there's any financial risks going forward related to that?
componenttext: Phebe, there was some press in the quarter about Bath on the DDG 1000. Can you give us your thoughts on that program? Just how it's going? And if there's any financial risks going forward related to that?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So they talked a little bit about 1000. As we've said before, this is a highly complex and revolutionary surface combatant. And first of which, we've got 3 in the backlog and 3 under construction. The first of which is nearing sea trial. So we're con
componenttext: Yes. So they talked a little bit about 1000. As we've said before, this is a highly complex and revolutionary surface combatant. And first of which, we've got 3 in the backlog and 3 under construction. The first of which is nearing sea trial. So we're continuing to work with the Navy to resolve any developmental issues that they see. And I think we all agree that we are working through all of the technical challenges on this first ship. And by the way, I think [indiscernible] that we used to think about performance on that ship is. You may recall that the complete redesign of the deckhouse on the third ship was reassigned to us. That design is nearly complete, and construction is proceeding quite nicely. So that suggests considerable learning, and I'm very pleased with, at least, that performance there. We do have some risks going forward. We'll manage that accordingly that we're working very closely with the Navy and Navy's other subcontractors on this program. And let me give you some sense of magnitude, that is 132nd of our sales. So we are paying quite a bit of attention to whether it's a complex warship. But I think the context is important here.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the General Dynamics Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call may be recorded. I would now like to turn the conference over to Erin Linnihan,
componenttext:
Good day, ladies and gentlemen, and welcome to the General Dynamics Third Quarter 2015 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] As a reminder, this conference call may be recorded. 
I would now like to turn the conference over to Erin Linnihan, Staff Vice President, Investor Relations. You may begin.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Nicole, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to the General Dynamics Third Quarter Conference Call.As always, any forward-looking statements made today represent our estimates regarding the company's outlook. These estimates are subject to som
componenttext:
Thank you, Nicole, and good morning, everyone. Welcome to the General Dynamics Third Quarter Conference Call.
As always, any forward-looking statements made today represent our estimates regarding the company's outlook. These estimates are subject to some risks and uncertainties. Additional information regarding these factors is contained in the company's 10-K and 10-Q filings.
With that, I would like to turn the call over to our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, Phebe Novakovic.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Good morning. As is obvious from our press release, we enjoyed another strong quarter. We reported EPS from continuing operations of $2.28 per fully diluted share on revenue of $7.99 billion and income from continuing operations of $733 million. This is $
componenttext:
Good morning. As is obvious from our press release, we enjoyed another strong quarter. We reported EPS from continuing operations of $2.28 per fully diluted share on revenue of $7.99 billion and income from continuing operations of $733 million. This is $0.23 per share better than the year-ago quarter and $0.15 per share better than consensus.
Against the year-ago quarter, revenue is up $243 million or 3.1%; operating earnings are up $35 million, a 3.5% increase; and income from continuing operations is up $39 million, a 5.6% increase.
This quarter, operating earnings of $1,034,000,000 reflects 12.9% operating margin, consistent with the 12.9% operating margin of third quarter 2014. By the way, this is the fourth consecutive quarter that we have had both operating earnings and EBIT in excess of $1 billion.
Sequentially, revenue is up $112 million or 1.4%; operating earnings are down $47 million; and operating margin is down 80 basis points. Recall, however, that last quarter's earnings included a gain on the sale of our cyber commercial security business. Excluding that gain, the operating earnings for the quarter, rather similar.
On a year-to-date basis, revenue is up $1.17 billion, a 5.2% increase; operating earnings are up $320 million, a very strong 11.3% increase; and operating margins are up 80 basis points, once again reflecting our emphasis on continuous improvement in operations.
With respect to cash. We had $652 million of free cash flow from operations in the quarter. That is 89% of net income from continuing operations. We have $1.81 billion year-to-date, 82% of net income from continuing operations. You may recall that we received significant advanced payments on international orders last year and on commercial shipbuilding orders the year before. That cash is being deployed this year and next as we have previously advised you. 
We are also hampered by OWC growth at Gulfstream, which is the natural result of building test articles and preproduction build-up of parts and wings for the G500 and G600. All of the foregoing makes performance at 100% of net income this year and next problematic.
In the quarter, we purchased 7.15 million shares for over $1 billion. We have purchased approximately 19.3 million shares year-to-date for about $2.7 billion. This is consistent with our prior guidance to you that we would repurchase shares and pay dividends in amounts in excess of this year's free cash flow. To help you size that, we have spent $3,380,000,000 on share repurchases and dividends year-to-date compared to free cash flow of $1.81 billion. That is a delta of $1.57 billion. That delta is likely to grow in the fourth quarter.
As you can see from the charts attached to the press release, our very healthy backlog is holding nicely. Once again, there was a good intake of orders in all segments other than the Marine group, where we have received several multiyear orders in prior quarters. The Marine group has the largest backlog of all of our operating segments. 
We ended the quarter with total backlog for the company at $68.7 billion, down modestly from the end of last quarter.
Let me say a few words about each of our businesses -- business groups, and I'll start with Aerospace. Aerospace had another very good quarter. Revenue, earnings and margin are all up from the year-ago quarter as well as for the first 9 months of the year. The group reported sales of $2.34 billion, up from the third quarter of 2014 by $54 million or 2.4%. This represents the group's highest-ever revenue quarter.
Operating earnings increased $15 million or 3.6% to $426 million on an operating margin of 18.2%, a 20 basis point improvement on the year-ago quarter. By the way, this is the fifth consecutive quarter with operating earnings in excess of $400 million. 
On a sequential basis, the group experienced some margin compression from the first half but was nevertheless better than our expectations and guidance to you. We had good order intake in the group at 0.8:1 book-to-bill measured in dollar value of orders and 0.9:1 in number of units sold. The distribution of the orders is also attractive with the G650 and 650ER leading the way. Only 4 of the orders were from models not yet in production.
Much like the automobile industry, general business aviation market is increasingly North America focused with particularly strong interest from Fortune 500 companies. However, the G650 continues to see activity even in areas experiencing political or economic challenges. We had G650 orders in China, Japan, Brazil and Eastern Europe in the quarter. Our pipeline of projects and active sales discussions are good, so we are reasonably optimistic about order intake for the fourth quarter.
Next, Combat System. Combat had a very good quarter, with revenue of $1.35 billion, operating earnings of $218 million and a really strong 16.2% operating margin. However, margins are off somewhat against the third quarter 2014 when we enjoyed an operating margin that was 40 basis points higher. Compared to third quarter of 2014, revenue was off $50 million and earnings were off $14 million. Importantly, however, year-to-date revenue was flat against 2014; operating earnings are up $57 million or 9.6%; and operating margin is at 7 -- 15.7%, up 130 basis points. Combat Systems remains on course for a very strong year.
The Marine group's revenue was higher than 2014, both for the third quarter and for the first 9 months. Revenue in the quarter is up by $267 million, a 14.7% increase to $2.09 billion. Year-to-date, revenue has increased by $759 million or 14.4% to over $6 billion. The growth in both periods is attributable to the group's submarine programs, both construction, repair and engineering, and to a lesser degree, commercial ship construction activities. This is the strongest revenue quarter ever for the Marine group. 
Operating earnings at $181 million are up modestly compared to last year's quarter. The group's operating margins were down 60 basis points in the quarter and 50 basis points year-to-date as a result of mix shift and a onetime charge at NASSCO on a warranty item in the quarter. However, margins for the first 9 months of the year remain a respectable 9.2% and should improve a bit in the fourth quarter.
And finally, IS&T. They continue to outperform our revenue expectations. Revenue at $2.2 billion is off $28 million against last year's quarter but up $113 million or 1.7% year-to-date. Recall that we had initially expected a 5.5% revenue decline for the year, and instead, we're up almost 2%.
Operating earnings of $219 million are up $17 million or 8.4% compared to the third quarter of last year on the strength of a 90 basis point improvement in operating margin. Year-to-date, operating earnings are up $100 million, a 17.5% increase on a 130 basis point improvement in operating margins. This is a very good news story with both revenue and operating margin higher than expected.
So what does all this mean as far as the year is concerned? While stronger-than-expected operating results in the quarter, a lower-than-planned tax rate and somewhat lower share count enable us to increase guidance for the year by $0.20. Our guidance goes from a range of $8.70 to $8.80 to a range of $8.90 to $9.
I'll now turn the call over to our CFO, Jason Aiken, for some more detail.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Phebe, and good morning. I'll be brief as I've got just a couple of things to cover before we start the Q&A period.As we've discussed throughout this year, we're seeing more of an impact on our financial results from foreign exchange rate vol
componenttext:
Thank you, Phebe, and good morning. I'll be brief as I've got just a couple of things to cover before we start the Q&A period.
As we've discussed throughout this year, we're seeing more of an impact on our financial results from foreign exchange rate volatility this year than we have in the past. Still not material in the aggregate, but it's having a negative impact on some of our segments, particularly Combat Systems. 
As Phebe pointed out, the group's revenue has held steady over the first 9 months compared with last year but had foreign exchange rates, particularly the U.S. dollar to the euro and the Canadian dollar, held constant from 2014 to this year, the group's sales would have been up by 8% year-to-date. As Combat Systems shifts away from a heavy reliance on U.S. Military sales to an increasing level of international activity, we expect foreign currency fluctuations to continue to be a part of the group's story.
Moving on to interest expense. The net expense in the quarter was $23 million versus $21 million in the third quarter of 2014. The slight increase is due to lower interest income as we've deployed over $1 billion this year from the balance sheet towards share repurchases and dividend payments. For the full year, we expect net interest expense to be approximately $85 million.
At the end of the quarter, our balance sheet reflects a net debt position at just about breakeven, a total of $41 million debt in excess of cash. This compares to a net cash balance of about $660 million at the end of the second quarter, and that change, again, is due to the capital deployment activity in the quarter.
Our effective tax rate was 27.6% for the quarter, lower than we expected as a result of increased international earnings as well as favorable contract closeouts and other true-ups associated with the filing of our tax return. For the full year, reflecting our favorable performance to-date, we now expect an effective tax rate closer to 28%.
We funded our pension plans as expected in the quarter and continue to expect cash pension contributions for 2015 to be approximately $185 million.
Erin, that concludes my remarks, and I'll turn the time back over to you for the Q&A.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Jason Gursky of Citi.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question comes from the line of Jason Gursky of Citi.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Phebe, thanks for the additional detail and color in your opening remarks. It's very helpful. I just had one quick follow-up question, though, on some of the comments that you made around the book to bill at Gulfstream with regard to value versus units. I
componenttext: Phebe, thanks for the additional detail and color in your opening remarks. It's very helpful. I just had one quick follow-up question, though, on some of the comments that you made around the book to bill at Gulfstream with regard to value versus units. It sounds like a number of units were a little bit better than the value, and then you had -- you followed all of this with some positive commentary about the G650. So I was wondering if you could dive in a little bit more about the difference between the 2 and what that might say about the pricing environment that you're seeing today for -- particularly the 450 and 550?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, it was largely the difference between the 2 book-to-bill calculations. It's really about mix. And let me give you -- let me take this opportunity, I think, to give you a little bit of color and detail. I'm going to parse for you sort of the demand p
componenttext:
Well, it was largely the difference between the 2 book-to-bill calculations. It's really about mix. And let me give you -- let me take this opportunity, I think, to give you a little bit of color and detail. I'm going to parse for you sort of the demand picture because I think I want to -- I want you all to understand the demand signals in their totality. So what I'm going to talk to you about is what we have seen so far this year, and I think this context is important. First, Gulfstream continues to perform well in the market. This was our strongest third order [ph] intake for -- in the last 4 years. And by the way, it follows the strongest second quarter intake that we had in 7 years last quarter. 
Second, our North American sales activity remains good. And this quarter, we saw some resurgence in the international market. Interestingly, with about half of our orders coming from ex U.S -- Asia-Pacific, Australia, Latin America, Mid-East. So nice broad order interests and order activity. 
Third, our book-to-bill, as you noted, is wholesome. And fourth, and I think this is also important to recall and understand, our firm backlog for this quarter is $13.6 billion. That's right around the median of our backlog total for 3 years. So what does that mean? It means that the backlog's been remarkably stable. And by the way, recall that our orders come with good deposits and strong contract terms, so they're rather sticky. So let me give you a little bit of color going forward. Our pipeline is good as it's been all year. And if you're interested in piece parts, constituents of the pipeline, it's heavily North American, which is wholesome. Public, private companies, high-net-worth individuals, and these are sophisticated buyers who are interested in fleet replacement and augmentation. 
So I think it's context that, that gives you a little bit of color on what we're seeing now. With all of that said, there are some non-macro headwinds. We had a competitor with white tails in the 450 and 550 space at very low prices. There are also 5 to 6 preowned 550s on the market that are less than 5 years old, and these newer airplanes are still under warranty. And for some customers, they can be competitive with our new offerings. So with all of that said, we remain pretty cautiously optimistic. I think I gave you a little bit more there, but I wanted you to understand how we're seeing the entire market because I think it's important to see it in its totality.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Phebe, you talked about the disconnect between cash generation and cash deployment, and consistently in the past, there's been 100% conversion, and you teed up the '15 and '16 explanation thereof. So I'm just curious, how much of the deployment this year
componenttext: Phebe, you talked about the disconnect between cash generation and cash deployment, and consistently in the past, there's been 100% conversion, and you teed up the '15 and '16 explanation thereof. So I'm just curious, how much of the deployment this year -- I think that you said somewhere around $3.3 billion year-to-date is deployed and presumably there'd be more of that in the fourth quarter. How much of that is indicative of what you think free cash flow is once you get through this kind of negative headwind you're seeing in '15 and '16? Is that the underlying cash generative base of business that you see out in the '17-'18 period of time?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, to the extent that I think I can fully understand your question, we give you more color on '16 as we always do in January of that year. But I'll try to give you some context of -- for '15 and '16 and not beyond that what we see in terms of the cash
componenttext: Well, to the extent that I think I can fully understand your question, we give you more color on '16 as we always do in January of that year. But I'll try to give you some context of -- for '15 and '16 and not beyond that what we see in terms of the cash headwinds. We have those international deposits that we're deploying as you would expect, and we're building our operating working capital also, as you would expect if you think about it, at Gulfstream. So that all flushes out at the end of '16. So there's -- if the essence of your question, is there any structural cash generation issue at our company, the answer's no. [indiscernible]

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: By '17, you see it largely resolved back to the kind of the kind of that GD evolved with 100% conversions?
componenttext: By '17, you see it largely resolved back to the kind of the kind of that GD evolved with 100% conversions?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just a quick one on IS&T. Obviously, the results there have been much better than you expected. I wondered if you might give us some color on where you're seeing the strength and sort of break out the more traditional service-oriented offerings versus the
componenttext: Just a quick one on IS&T. Obviously, the results there have been much better than you expected. I wondered if you might give us some color on where you're seeing the strength and sort of break out the more traditional service-oriented offerings versus the product-oriented offerings? And maybe comment on the cost structure and your efforts there, and what impact that's having? Just a little bit more color on the successes you've been having there.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So this is a good news story for us, and it's across both mission systems and information technology. They both had a strong quarter, and they're improving their performance year-to-date. And there's no single area that's driving strength given the n
componenttext: Yes. So this is a good news story for us, and it's across both mission systems and information technology. They both had a strong quarter, and they're improving their performance year-to-date. And there's no single area that's driving strength given the number of programs that we have in that portfolio. There's just constant flux in mix and timing. They have been -- but because of the increased cost or decreased cost structure, they've been winning more than their fair share. So that has added nicely to our book-to-bill, which, I think, year-to-date is about 1:1 and no short-cycle businesses. That's pretty impressive. So I think it's operating excellence, technical ability and just focus. So we're very pleased with what they've done.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Doug Harned of Bernstein.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Doug Harned of Bernstein.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I wanted to get back to Gulfstream and just 2 things to understand. One, you've talked in the past about potentially moving forward some G650 production, perhaps adding some in the nearer term, which would help the revenue top line. Can you comment on tha
componenttext: I wanted to get back to Gulfstream and just 2 things to understand. One, you've talked in the past about potentially moving forward some G650 production, perhaps adding some in the nearer term, which would help the revenue top line. Can you comment on that? And then also, where does availability stand on the 450 and 550 now in terms of months ahead?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes, let me take them in the inverse order. The 450 and 550 are about 3 to 4 quarters, so not much of a change there. With respect to the 650, our production is as we anticipated this year, so no changes to that. But going forward, as we prepare our plan
componenttext: Yes, let me take them in the inverse order. The 450 and 550 are about 3 to 4 quarters, so not much of a change there. With respect to the 650, our production is as we anticipated this year, so no changes to that. But going forward, as we prepare our plan for next year, we'll look to feather in a couple of -- and I'm talking about 1 and 2  -- just a handful, onesies and twosies, feather in some 650s to help offset some of -- as we make that transition to entering into service on the new airplane. So that's pretty much what we've been seeing all year and saying is exactly what we're continuing to see.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ron Epstein of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ron Epstein of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So Phebe, yes, just if you could give us some color on how the flight test program's going because it's kind of hard to follow as an outsider. Just what milestones are happening? And if you could just kind of paint a picture for that?
componenttext: So Phebe, yes, just if you could give us some color on how the flight test program's going because it's kind of hard to follow as an outsider. Just what milestones are happening? And if you could just kind of paint a picture for that?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Sure. So our flight test program is going very well. On the G550, we've surpassed -- G500, we've surpassed more than 100 hours of flight, and we've successfully completed about, I think, 45 missions. On the 600, we've begun construction and is well underw
componenttext: Sure. So our flight test program is going very well. On the G550, we've surpassed -- G500, we've surpassed more than 100 hours of flight, and we've successfully completed about, I think, 45 missions. On the 600, we've begun construction and is well underway on construction on the test aircraft. And we plan to fly that in 2016. And our entry into service remains unchanged, so is very, very well.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Just as a quick follow-on, is there any chance that, that entry into service can happen a little earlier if kind of everything just continues to go smooth?
componenttext: Just as a quick follow-on, is there any chance that, that entry into service can happen a little earlier if kind of everything just continues to go smooth?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, that's hard to predict, since we don't -- but I'm not going to get out ahead of Gulfstream. We're sticking right now to what our original entry into service is. And as we go and we mature and get down the test flight program, we'll have a little bit
componenttext: Well, that's hard to predict, since we don't -- but I'm not going to get out ahead of Gulfstream. We're sticking right now to what our original entry into service is. And as we go and we mature and get down the test flight program, we'll have a little bit more clarity. But right now, that's what we still see.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of George Armant [ph] with Sterne Agee.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of George Armant [ph] with Sterne Agee.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Can you give us an update on your kind of general thoughts of the latest talk on the budget deal? What that -- if there's any material impact in terms of your overall plan? And just regarding -- in particular, regarding Combat. I mean, it seems like the m
componenttext: Can you give us an update on your kind of general thoughts of the latest talk on the budget deal? What that -- if there's any material impact in terms of your overall plan? And just regarding -- in particular, regarding Combat. I mean, it seems like the mix there continues to favor the margin performance. If you could just update how we see the mix going forward?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, the budget -- the prospective budget agreement would be very welcome news, I think, from a national security perspective. And certainly for us, our programs are fully funded in the president's request and in the -- as we understand, the proposed bud
componenttext: Well, the budget -- the prospective budget agreement would be very welcome news, I think, from a national security perspective. And certainly for us, our programs are fully funded in the president's request and in the -- as we understand, the proposed budget agreement. So I think that's very, very good progress made quickly. So we're pleased with that, and we would encourage and hope that, that continue and see now -- we're hopeful that that's all on track. And on Combat, we're continuing -- it's between last year and this year -- it's had some mix issues as we came off of mature programs that were in development and at the end of their production runs and started up on the whole series of new programs. But that backlog coupled with the operating excellence of that entire group positions us quite well for nice earnings growth. And we'll hold -- margins should increase over time. If that's -- if you think about that business as we've got our platform businesses, but we also have a -- our Ordnance and Tactical Systems business, and they had an absolutely terrific quarter. So they are highly focused on their cost structure, operating leverage, and they had a very wholesome book-to-bill in excess of 1:1. So for a short-cycle business, that's very, very good.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015

componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Robert Spingarn of Credit Suisse.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015

componenttext: Yes, think about the submarines in 2 ways. We're at our -- and this will be steady state on Virginia Block IV revenues, so what we're seeing now will continue. And we'll continue to see and anticipate growth in the Ohio Replacement design work, which has been growing at a very healthy clip, and the growth will slow down, but it will continue to grow. So that business is very well positioned for additional revenue increases.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: I would ask my obvious question, again, maybe from a different direction. The buyback and the dividend exceeding free cash flow this year. Do you think that's something that we should expect again next year? And do you have a sort of leverage target in mi
componenttext: I would ask my obvious question, again, maybe from a different direction. The buyback and the dividend exceeding free cash flow this year. Do you think that's something that we should expect again next year? And do you have a sort of leverage target in mind? You've gone back to sort of net debt to cash of basically 0. But do you see it actually moving to a net debt situation going forward?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So I think one way to think about it is we would never view a net cash position as being optimal and even a breakeven situation's not optimal. I don't necessarily think we'd characterize as having a target leverage position so much as we think about havin
componenttext: So I think one way to think about it is we would never view a net cash position as being optimal and even a breakeven situation's not optimal. I don't necessarily think we'd characterize as having a target leverage position so much as we think about having the preservation of the strong balance sheet that allows us to be poised to quickly and readily take a strategic direction when the opportunity presents itself. And as far as capital deployment goes, I'll look at my boss and say I'm not going to speak to our plans for next year and get out ahead of her, but that's gotten -- you know where we are today is trying to normalize that deployment of capital to a net income level given that we see free cash flow being somewhat less than net income this year.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Okay. Maybe a quick follow-up, Jason, as well. On the foreign exchange, you mentioned this is something we should watch. What's your hedging situation? Do you have most of these export revenues hedged?
componenttext: Okay. Maybe a quick follow-up, Jason, as well. On the foreign exchange, you mentioned this is something we should watch. What's your hedging situation? Do you have most of these export revenues hedged?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: So that's -- yes, 2 parts answer to that question. From the perspective of actual economic exposure and having a foreign currency revenue or expense item in a particular business, we have that 100% hedged, and we're totally secure on that front. What I'm
componenttext: So that's -- yes, 2 parts answer to that question. From the perspective of actual economic exposure and having a foreign currency revenue or expense item in a particular business, we have that 100% hedged, and we're totally secure on that front. What I'm referring to strictly is the translation of our indigenous businesses in Spain, in the U.K., in Canada and so on, translating those operating results back into U.S. dollars for consolidated reporting. So it's not an economic loss we're talking about. It's a headwind from a U.S. consolidated reporting perspective. So -- but from an actual economic exposure standpoint, we're very comfortably hedged.

componenttext: So I think some of the wait times, if not all of them by your aircraft platform at Gulfstream actually increased a little bit last quarter, including 450 and 550 by [ph] the CBU. You've indicated there's some headwinds there in that market right now, call it crosswinds, if you will, from obviously a competitor. So the question is, have you actually scaled back on 450 production at all this year as it relates to the next couple years of rate? And can you remind us what the wait time is for the 650 right now?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So our production for this year is exactly on track. No changes. We're setting -- we're in the process of setting our production rates for next year, and we'll give you that color when we give -- report fourth quarter and give you guidance. And the 6
componenttext: Yes. So our production for this year is exactly on track. No changes. We're setting -- we're in the process of setting our production rates for next year, and we'll give you that color when we give -- report fourth quarter and give you guidance. And the 650, actually, we are 1 or 2 slots away from moving to a second quarter 2018 availability. So that backlog, as wholesome as it is, continues to grow.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015

componenttext: I want to go back to the same question, I guess, in terms of the free cash flow. componenttext: Well, so far, we've seen nothing particular note that's interesting at accretive prices. So I think that -- I think that's just the best way to think about it. We're really not looking because there isn't much out there from our perspective. So we just continue to keep our powder dry, and you'll continue to see us to deploy through the year -- buy back shares as it makes sense tactically.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015

componenttext: Okay. And if I can follow up, is there anyway you can size the warranty issue at NASSCO?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: No. It had to do with a bearing on a driveshaft, and that's the extent to which I understand the shipbuilding challenge there. But we took the warranty and NASSCO is -- we took the charge, and NASSCO is all set to -- it is poised to recover for next quart
componenttext: No. It had to do with a bearing on a driveshaft, and that's the extent to which I understand the shipbuilding challenge there. But we took the warranty and NASSCO is -- we took the charge, and NASSCO is all set to -- it is poised to recover for next quarter. So that was a onetime event in our [indiscernible].

componenttext: It'll be a little bit like I'm trying to pull teeth here, but we'll see if I can succeed. Your outlook for Gulfstream sort of -- they've continued to surprise you. What -- and yet you're being very conservative about the fourth quarter. Could you elaborate a little bit more on some of the challenges? Is it higher R&D? Is it mix? Is it something else that causes you some concern about profitability?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015

componenttext: So the fourth quarter is going to be lighter than the third quarter. And let me take you back to last quarter when we talked about Jet Aviation and that we were going to see some margin compression in the second half as we began to spend on engineering and the preproduction activities at Basel that we need to do in anticipation of the start of production, which begins early next year. That has happened, and it will continue into next quarter. So couple that with you got a higher R&D and lower launch assistance, and that's essentially the story from where we sit right now.

componenttext: Well, as I told you, we're seeing a significant margin compression at Jet. And I think that if you back in the math, it's fourth quarter maybe somewhere around 18%. Yes. componenttext: Phebe, just looking at Combat, just given the strong order flow over there of the past 18 months or so and the FX pressure that you're seeing this year, I mean, what's the growth for that segment look like next year? Some of the international contracts flowing through but just being offset by FX. And does that annualize next year?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, as you would expect, we took in a fair -- a large number of orders into the backlog in '14. And if you look at the engineering cycle, and typically when programs start production, you could reasonably expect that production to begin in 2016. And I t
componenttext: Well, as you would expect, we took in a fair -- a large number of orders into the backlog in '14. And if you look at the engineering cycle, and typically when programs start production, you could reasonably expect that production to begin in 2016. And I think we've been pretty clear about that. But I don't want to get into any more detail on what '16 looks like till we finish our plan.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Notwithstanding what you just said about not getting into 2016, I was wondering if you could comment on how the profitability headwind from Jet carries over -- or in Aerospace from Jet Aviation carries over from Q4 into 2016? Since you've got some pretty
componenttext: Notwithstanding what you just said about not getting into 2016, I was wondering if you could comment on how the profitability headwind from Jet carries over -- or in Aerospace from Jet Aviation carries over from Q4 into 2016? Since you've got some pretty tough margin comps in the first half of the year, the Gulfstream margin was around 20%. And I thought that the cost management in Aerospace was one of the ways to help manage this transition from the 550, 450 to the 500, 600.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Well, your supposition is right. Cost management is going to be key. The margin compression that we've seen in Jet reverses in the first quarter of 2016 as they begin production. Right now they're simply in the dueling phase and engineering for these larg
componenttext: Well, your supposition is right. Cost management is going to be key. The margin compression that we've seen in Jet reverses in the first quarter of 2016 as they begin production. Right now they're simply in the dueling phase and engineering for these large-body and narrowbody airline completions. So that's a fair amount of engineering work. We'll get into production then starting in the first quarter of next year. So that headwind is behind us.

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Phebe, there was some press in the quarter about Bath on the DDG 1000. Can you give us your thoughts on that program, just how it's going, and if there's any financial risk going forward related to that?
componenttext: Phebe, there was some press in the quarter about Bath on the DDG 1000. Can you give us your thoughts on that program, just how it's going, and if there's any financial risk going forward related to that?

headline: General Dynamics Corporation, Q3 2015 Earnings Call, Oct 28, 2015
componenttextpreview: Yes. So they talked a little bit about 1000. As we've said before, this is a highly complex and revolutionary surface combatant. And first of which, we've got 3 in the backlog and 3 under construction. The first of which is nearing sea trials. So we're co
componenttext: Yes. So they talked a little bit about 1000. As we've said before, this is a highly complex and revolutionary surface combatant. And first of which, we've got 3 in the backlog and 3 under construction. The first of which is nearing sea trials. So we're continuing to work with the Navy to resolve any developmental issues that they see. And I think we all agree that we are working through all of the technical challenges on this first ship. And by the way, I think the bellwether that we used to think about performance on that ship is -- you may recall that the complete redesign of the deckhouse on the third ship was reassigned to us. That design is nearly complete, and construction is proceeding quite nicely. So that suggests considerable learning, and I'm very pleased with, at least that performance there. We do have some risks going forward. We'll manage that accordingly that we're working very closely with the Navy and Navy's other subcontractors on this program. And let me give you some sense of magnitude. Bath is 1/32 of our sales. So we are paying quite a bit of attention to what is a complex warship. But I think the context is important here.
